Yulo joined Diaz in the history books after winning the gold in the Paris Olympics 2024 men's floor exercise in gymnastics. -HIDILYN DIAZ INSTAGRAM\n\nMANILA, Philippines -- From one Olympic gold medalist to another.\n\nTeam Philippines' first ever gold medalist Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo congratulated gymnast and fellow Tokyo Olympian Carlos Yulo after making history in the Paris Olympics 2024 and joining an elite crowd in the country's sports history.\n\nDiaz, who delivered the country's first Olympic gold medal three years ago, expressed how proud she is of Yulo after the Filipino gymnast ruled the floor exercise final on Saturday at Bercy Arena in France.\n\n\"For you, Caloy, I'm proud of you. Enjoy the fruits of your hard work. Always give back to God and the country, because all our successes are not just for ourselves,\" wrote the weightlifting champion in Filipino in an Instagram post, attaching a photo of her and Yulo from their Tokyo stint.\n\nYulo, who failed to bring home a medal in his Olympic debut in the pandemic-delayed Games, won the country's first gold medal in Paris and became the maiden Filipino gymnast to rule the Olympics in his second appearance.\n\nDiaz thanked the 24-year-old Yulo for bringing glory to the country and reminded the young gymnast that she is always there for him.\n\n\"Thank you for all the good and wonderful things you have done and will continue to do for God and the country!\" she said. \"Congratulations! Your Ate Haidie is always here for you!\"\n\nREAD: Gymnast Carlos Yulo gives PH its second Olympic gold\n\nThe Philippines' first two Olympic gold medals broke barriers with Diaz setting Olympic records for the weightlifting women's 55-kilogram division with a total lift of 224 kg in July 26, 2021.\n\nThree years later, Yulo performed with grace and a near-flawless routine for 15.000 points, giving the competitors a run for their money including the erstwhile defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel, who wound up with silver.\n\nThe newly-crowned Olympic champion has been receiving praise from his fellow countrymen and is set to get a major financial windfall that include P10 million from the government and a condo unit worth P24 million from Megaworld.\n\nYulo is expected to receive more incentives from public and private organizations just like Diaz when she ended the country's gold medal drought in the Olympics.\n\nMore importantly, Yulo has another chance to win {"uri": "8257716738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "17:50:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T17:50:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T17:49:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/resilience-challenging-path-carlos-yulo-gold-medal-paris-olympics-2024/", "title": "Resilience amid challenging path leads Carlos Yulo to Olympic gold", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - It has not been a year since Carlos Yulo went home empty-handed from the last World Artistic Gymnastics Championships - a campaign that marked one of the lowest points of his decorated career.\n\nBut Yulo plodded on and found his way back to the top of the sport.\n\nYulo made history for the Philippines as he won the country its first-ever medal in Olympic gymnastics, striking gold in the men's floor exercise in the Paris Games on Saturday, August 3.\n\n\"I'm really grateful that I did not give up despite the challenges,\" Yulo said in an interview with Olympic broadcaster One Sports in a mix of Filipino and English. \"I'm here, I showed up, and I got good results.\"\n\nThe past year proved to be a difficult one for Yulo as he parted ways with his long-time Japanese coach Munehiro Kugimiya, who molded him into becoming a world champion in floor exercise and vault.\n\nAlthough he secured a return trip to the Olympics, Yulo failed to win a medal in the world championships in October in Antwerp, Belgium, a stunning turn of events considering he won at least one in each of the four editions prior.\n\nHis disappointing run in the world championships cast doubt on his chances of winning an Olympic medal, but Yulo - having learned the lessons from his experiences, both good and bad - never lost heart.\n\nYulo bounced back in style in the Asian Men's Artistic Gymnastics Championships in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, in May, capturing the elusive all-around gold and repeating as champion in floor exercise, vault, and parallel bars.\n\nAnd in his second Olympic stint, Yulo made the most out of his opportunities as he reached the final of all-around, floor exercise, and vault.\n\nYulo saved his best in the floor exercise final, netting 15.000 points to dethrone Israel's Artem Dolgopyat (14.966) and become the Philippines' second Olympic champion after weightlifting ace Hidilyn Diaz.\n\n\"This is the experience that will leave a mark in my heart and in the entire Philippines,\" said Yulo.\n\nYulo, who is now coached by Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda, said his victory also belongs to people who have helped him along the way, including Gymnastics Association of the Philippines president Cynthia Carrion.\n\n\"Every place I've been to, every result I've got, there are people who helped me, especially ma'am Cynthia,\" said Yulo. \"She really supported me through the ups and downs.\"\n\nYulo hopes to win one more as he competes in the vault final on Sunday, August 4. - Rappler.com", "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", {"uri": "8258872307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:34:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:34:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:33:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/05/sports/yulo-gifts-ph-with-2nd-gold/1961868", "title": "Yulo gifts PH with 2nd gold", "body": "(UPDATE) GYMNAST Carlos \"Caloy\" Yulo has cemented his status as the greatest Filipino Olympian. About 24 hours after ruling the floor exercise final, Yulo conquered the vault competition at the Paris Olympics men's artistics gymnastics, emerging as the first Filipino Olympic multi-gold medalist at the Bercy Arena on Sunday night, Aug. 4 (Manila time).\n\nHis confidence through the roof after delivering the Philippines first gymnastics Olympic medal on Saturday, the 4-foot-11 dynamo unleashed his magic anew to top the vault with an average score of 15.116 points.\n\nThe 24-year-old dazzled with a high-level execution of dragulescu pike in his first vault, just needing a little hop to gain balance after his landing and netting 15.433 points -- 6.000 in difficulty and 9.433 in execution. Fourth to perform in the final, Yulo then executed a kasamatsu double in his second vault, which was not as good as his first vault but still solid for 14.800 points -- 5.600 in difficulty and 9.200 in execution.\n\nAfter each vault, Yulo, as he has been all tournament, threw his fists into the air in high satisfaction of his performance. When the last four performers wound up with lower scores, Yulo was once again in disbelief after pulling off an Olympic feat no other Filipino athlete has done before.\n\nWith Yulo's two-gold haul, the Philippines will finish the Paris Games with at least four medals, the other two being guaranteed bronzes - one each for Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nWhen Yulo comes home to the Philippines, he will get more than a hero's welcome -- he stands to receive at least P23 million in incentives from the government and a posh condominium worth P24 million from real estate giant Megaworld.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBefore winning his second gold, Yulo delivered a dazzling performance that netted him 15.0 points and the gold medal at the Paris Olympics men's gymnastics floor exercise at the Bercy Arena on Saturday evening, August 3 (Manila time).\n\nThe gold was the first medal for the Philippines in Olympic gymnastics.\n\nPresident Ferdinand Marcos Jr. congratulated Yulo on his social media account.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first Gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the President said, adding that he is \"confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he said.\n\nUnder Republic Act 10699, also known as the Sports Benefits and Incentives Act of 2001, Filipino Olympic gold medalists will receive P10 million on top of the Olympic Gold Medal of Valor to be issued by the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC).\n\nSilver medalists will be given P5 million, while bronze medalists will get P2 million.\n\nThe House of Representatives, meanwhile, chipped in a P3 million reward to the gold medalist.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" Speaker Martin Romualdez said of the cash incentive.\n\nThe House will also give Yulo a congressional medal for his achievement.\n\nMeanwhile, Megaworld on August 2 pledged a fully-furnished two-bedroom residential condominium unit worth P24 million inside the company's 50-hectare McKinley Hill township in Taguig City.\n\nFollowing Yulo's golden medal performance, Megaworld posted on Facebook:\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"IT'S A GOLD FOR THE PHILIPPINES! Congratulations Carlos Yulo! Welcome to your McKinley Hill home!\"\n\nThat served as the caption in a graphic congratulating Yulo and the \"fully-furnished 2-bedroom condominium unit in McKinley Hill, valued at P24M\" in the image.\n\nExpect more companies to give whatever they will to Yulo, just like they did with the first Filipino Olympic gold medalist, Hidilyn Diaz, three years ago.\n\nDiaz, Obiena lead celebrations\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe country's first Olympic gold medalist, Hidilyn Diaz, was among the first to congratulate Yulo.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Diaz said there were \"different emotions\" in Yulo's victory and thanked all the Filipino athletes.\n\n\"Para sa iyo, Caloy: Proud ako sa iyo. I-enjoy mo ang bunga ng pinagpaguran mo. At lagi mong ibabalik -- sa Diyos at bayan, dahil lahat ng tagumpay natin ay hindi pansarili. Salamat sa lahat ng maganda at mabuting ginagawa at gagawin mo pa para sa Diyos at bayan (I am so proud of you. Enjoy the fruits of your hard work. And always remember to give back -- to God and country -- because our success is not for ourselves alone. Thank you for all the good things you have done and will continue to do for God and country)!\" she wrote on Facebook.\n\nWhile she will not be in the Olympics as an athlete, Diaz is headed for Paris as an official for the International Weightlifting Federation, as the Olympic events will start on August 7.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMeanwhile, hours after his qualification to the pole vault finals, Ernest John \"EJ\" Obiena also congratulated Yulo on his Instagram story, with a simple \"Yes, sir!\"\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Abraham Tolentino on Facebook congratulated Yulo, accompanied by photos together with the country's newest Olympic champion in the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nThe Gymnastics Association of the Philippines (GAP) also called Yulo's gold medal win a \"golden comeback\" from his run in the previous Olympics in Tokyo. GAP President Cynthia Carrion was in Paris to witness Yulo's win.\n\n\"Our country's first gold medal for Men's Artistic Gymnastics was brought home by our Golden Boy, Carlos Yulo!\" GAP wrote on Facebook.\n\nSenators sent their congratulations, too.\n\n\"Caloy overcame various setbacks and challenges, which included a change of coach and moving back to the Philippines from Japan for his training, to get to this moment,\" Sen. Nancy Binay said in a statement.\n\n\"You are a shining example, Caloy, of how we can strive to achieve balance in our lives despite the pursuit of glory,\" Binay said\n\nWITH REPORTS FROM ARIC JOHN SY CUA, CATHERINE VALENTE, REINA C. TOLENTINO, BERNADETTE E. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz struck gold at the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\n\"I just went for it, I didn't hesitate,\" the former world champion said after his perfectly executed routine gave him a score of 15.000 points.\n\nArtem Dolgopyat of Israel took silver with 14.966, while Britain's Jake Jarman achieved 14.933 to claim bronze.\n\n\"I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" said Yulo, who has a chance of winning another medal in the vault final.\n\nFilipino athletes have been promised a fully furnished, two-bedroom condominium if they win a gold medal. {"uri": "8257647350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "16:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T16:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T16:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/sports/othersports/915822/who-is-carlos-yulo/story/", "title": "Who is Olympic gold winner Carlos Yulo?", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics Artistic Gymnastics - Men's Floor Exercise Victory Ceremony August 03, 2024. Gold medallist Carlos Yulo of Philippines celebrates on the podium with his medal. REUTERS/Hannah Mckay\n\nCarlos Yulo, a Filipino gymnast, is the Philippines' second Olympic gold medalist after ruling the men's floor exercise finals in the 2024 Paris Olympics on Saturday.\n\nHe followed weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz who won the country's first Olympic gold back in Tokyo 2020 three years ago.\n\nA 24-year old gymnast from Manila, the Paris Games is Yulo's second Olympic appearance as he also competed in Tokyo.\n\nYulo has been dominating the sports scene for more than five years now since he got one of his first international medals in the 2018 World Championships where he claimed bronze in floor exercise.\n\nA grassroots product of Manila, Yulo eventually qualified for the Tokyo Olympics as he won the gold in the World Championships for floor exercise the year after. In the Southeast Asian Games in Manila, Yulo won two gold medals in team and floor exercise, and five silver medals from the other apparatus: pommel horse, still rings, vault, parallel bars, and horizontal bars.\n\nIn the Tokyo Olympics, Yulo missed the floor exercise finals, but qualified in the vault finals where he fell just short -- 0.017 points short of a bronze medal.\n\nAfter his Tokyo stint, Yulo continued to rake in medals for the Philippines, notable of which are: his World Championships gold medal for vault in 2021, 10 gold medals in three editions of the Asian Championships, and seven gold medals in the Hanoi and Cambodia editions of the Southeast Asian Games.\n\nWhat happened after Tokyo\n\nHowever, things became slightly different after the Tokyo Games.\n\nWhile Yulo tried to excel as well in other apparatuses, a major change happened when he parted ways with former Japanese coach Munehiro Kugimiya. He is now training with Filipino coach Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda.\n\nStill, Yulo said he is grateful to Kugimiya.\n\n\"Siya po talaga 'yung nakakakita ng potential ko. Sobrang thankful po ako sa taong 'yun, sobrang talino. Na-provide niya po lahat ng needs nung nandun ako sa Japan,\" Yulo said in JP Soriano's 24 Oras interview last April.\n\nAside from a coaching change, Yulo previously said he plans to excel in the all-around event.\n\n\"Ang goal ko rin po kasi sa Olympics, maka-individual all-around. Hindi lang floor, hindi lang vault, hindi lang p-bar,\" he said.\n\nIndeed, come Paris, he excelled in the individual all-around as he also qualified for its finals where he finished 12th.\n\nHowever, not all is over for Yulo as he still has to compete in the vault finals on Sunday.", "source": {"uri": "gmanetwork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GMA Network"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8257709502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "17:42:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T17:42:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T17:40:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/sports/othersports/915828/marcos-congratulates-carlos-yulo-for-winning-olympic-gold/story/", "title": "Marcos congratulates Carlos Yulo for winning Olympic gold", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Artistic Gymnastics - Men's Floor Exercise Victory Ceremony. Gold medallist Carlos Edriel Yulo of the Philippines celebrates on the podium with his medal. REUTERS/Hannah Mckay\n\nPresident Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos congratulated gymnast Carlos Yulo for winning the Philippines' first Olympic gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nYulo won the gold for floor exercise in Olympic gymnastics, making him the second Olympic gold medalist after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz back in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn a Facebook post, Marcos said the country is proud of Yulo's achievement.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you,\" the caption of the post read.\n\nMarcos also said he is confident about the country's medal chances in the Summer Games.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the caption said. \"I am confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nYulo will have a chance for another medal when he competes in the vault finals on Sunday.\n\nAside from Yulo, boxers Aira Villegas and Nesthy Petecio are still on the running for a possible medal, while pole vaulter EJ Obiena qualified for the men's pole vault finals.\n\nHurdlers John Cabang Tolentino and Lauren Hoffman, golfers Dottie Ardina and Bianca Pagdanganan, and weightlifters John Ceniza, Vanessa Sarno, I always say experience, experience and there's no problem there but this is the one that will leave a mark in my heart and the whole Philippines.\"\n\nWith Team Philippines' medal hopes resting on Yulo's broad shoulders, the 24-year-old pulled off his best performance in his young career.\n\nYulo tallied 15.000 points to seal the Philippines' first gold medal in the Paris Games and became the first Filipino gymnast to make the podium in the Olympics.\n\nBut making history, however, was certainly no easy task.\n\n\"I couldn't sleep properly for two days because of this. I was always nervous but I'm grateful that I didn't quit on the challenges,\" said Yulo.\n\n\"I showed up and this is the result I got but I'm not the only one who won this.\"\n\nWhile Yulo's Saturday night win was one for the books, he has one more shot at further solidifying his legacy.\n\nIt's easy to get lost in euphoria after such a historic victory but for Yulo, there's one more job to {"uri": "2024-08-443783729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:53:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:53:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:51:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/08/05/2375539/millions-incentives-coming-yulo", "title": "Millions in incentives coming in for Yulo", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- When he comes home, gold medalist Carlos Yulo's 2024 Paris Olympic Games victory will be made even sweeter with more prizes, courtesy of the country's tycoons.\n\nAndrew Tan's property giant Megaworld Corp. is rewarding Yulo with a fully furnished two-bedroom residential condominium unit in Bonifacio Global City valued at P24 million.\n\nThe men's gymnastics champion's new condominium is located within Megaworld's 50-hectare McKinley Hill township in Taguig.\n\n\"That's our commitment, not just for him, but to every Filipino Olympic athlete who will get gold,\" Megaworld vice president for public relations Harold Geronimo told The STAR yesterday.\n\nThe SM Group of the Sy family, meanwhile, has pledged P1 million worth of products from SM Retail, both department stores and supermarkets, consumable within one year.\n\nPopular buffet restaurant chain Vikings pledged on its official Facebook page a lifetime free buffet to the celebrated athlete.\n\nAnother tycoon-led group will also be announcing today its reward for Yulo, The STAR has learned.\n\nYulo, who topped the floor exercise finals of the men's gymnastics in the Paris Olympics, is the country's second Olympic gold medalist after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz.\n\nDiaz, who won her gold medal during the Tokyo Olympics three years ago, received hefty cash prizes and incentives from companies and tycoons such as Manuel V. Pangilinan and Ramon Ang.\n\nAside from the prizes coming from the country's most notable tycoons, the government - according to Section 8 of Republic Act 10699 - will be awarding Yulo with P10 million and an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor to be issued by the Philippine Sports Commission.\n\nSenators commend Yulo\n\nSenators commended Yulo, the country's first gymnast to win a gold medal in the Paris Olympics.\n\nSen. Sherwin Gatchalian \"joined the Filipino people in congratulating Carlos Yulo for clinching an Olympic gold in the floor exercises in gymnastics. This historic win brings a special moment of pride for our country, and proves that the Olympic gold is no longer elusive for Filipino athletes. He has inspired countless Filipinos with his exceptional performance.\"\n\nGatchalian said, \"Our task as a nation is to ensure that future generations of athletes have all the support they need to succeed on the world stage. This is why we created the National Academy of Sports, where promising young athletes will be honed to achieve their full potential.\n\n\"The whole country is cheering and proud of you! Mabuhay ka, Caloy!\" he added.\n\nSen. Nancy Binay said, \"A tribute to the country's first gymnast gold medalist, Carlos Yulo! The nation cried, screamed, and applauded alongside Caloy's historic day at the Paris Olympics.\"\n\nShe noted that Yulo garnered a 15.000 score in the men's floor exercise on Aug. 3 to become the first Filipino gymnast to reach the medal podium in the quadrennial games. \"His win is also the Philippines' first medal in the ongoing Olympics.\"\n\nBinay said Yulo overcame various setbacks and challenges, which included a change of coach and moving back to the Philippines from Japan for his training, to get to this moment.\n\n\"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster,\" Binay said. \"Thank you very much for displaying what Filipinos can achieve, Caloy. Mabuhay ka!\"\n\nSen. Bong Go offered his congratulatory message, and said, \"Your winning of the gold medal at the Olympics gives great honor to the entire nation. You are a big reason for Filipinos to be more united at a time when the stability of our people is being tested due to the challenges of the times. Carlos, you bring honor to the Filipino!\"\n\n\"As chairperson of the Senate Sports Committee and Senate Youth Committee, I will continue to support people like you and young Filipinos who also want to be champions in the future. It's a great feeling when you work hard and sweat for your win. This is proof that when the people support our athletes, they will go far,\" he said.\n\n\"This is also a challenge for us to continue and strengthen our sports programs to give other athletes the opportunity and inspiration to show their talent and win, not only in sports, but in any field they choose in life,\" Go said. \"To our other athletes and coaches at the 2024 Paris Games, we wish you success! Your success is also the success of Filipinos! Fight Philippines! Go, go for gold!\"\n\nMore prizes from the House\n\nYulo stands to receive some P3 million in cash incentives from the House of Representatives.\n\nSpeaker Martin Romualdez said Yulo will also be conferred a \"congressional medal for his exceptional achievement and contribution to Philippine sports.\"\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" he noted.\n\nRomualdez added that Yulo's historic victory, \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people.\"\n\nEarlier, Romualdez extended financial assistance to 22 Filipino athletes participating in the Paris Olympics.\n\nHe also initiated a fundraising campaign among his House colleagues to provide additional cash incentives to Yulo.\n\n\"We celebrate a monumental achievement that resonates deeply with every Filipino heart. Carlos Edriel Yulo has not only soared to the pinnacle of athletic excellence, but has also emerged as a sports hero and national treasure, igniting a beacon of hope and inspiration for all Filipinos,\" he said.\n\nHero's welcome\n\nA \"hero's welcome\" is now being prepared for Yulo and other Paris Olympics athletes.\n\nManila Mayor Honey Lacuna-Pangan said the \"grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians.\"\n\nPangan added that the local government would present Yulo with cash incentives, awards and symbols of \"eternal gratitude\" from Manila.\n\n\"We sang along as Caloy sang the Philippine national anthem. Tears welled up in our eyes and flowed in streams on our faces as the Philippine flag rose in Paris,\" the mayor said in a statement. -- Cecille Suerte Felipe, Sheila Crisostomo, Mark Ernest Villeza", {"uri": "8259662162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:57:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:57:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:56:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/carlos-yulo-good-night-sleep-gold-medal-run-over-paris-olympics-2024/", "title": "With golden Olympic run over, Carlos Yulo finally gets a good night's sleep", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - Hefty rewards await Carlos Yulo following his golden romp in the Paris Games that saw him become the Philippines' first double Olympic champion.\n\nWith his pair of gold medals, Yulo is entitled to get a total of P20 million under the law on top of other incentives that include a house and lot, a posh condominium unit, and free food for a lifetime.\n\nBut as he lets his historic feat sink in, the best reward Yulo can give himself is a good night's sleep.\n\nYulo can finally get the kind of rest the greatest Filipino gymnast deserves after losing sleep over anticipation of the floor exercise and vault finals over the weekend.\n\nStill, Yulo delivered, dethroning Israel's Artem Dolgopyat for the floor exercise crown on Saturday, August 3, and redeeming himself from a fourth-place finish in the Tokyo Olympics as he captured the vault title on Sunday, August 4.\n\n\"Last night, I couldn't sleep. This morning, I was so sleepy,\" Yulo said after the vault final. \"I slept in the bus, I slept after the podium training. I slept before going to the competition area... But I did it today.\"\n\nYulo said he was at ease going into the vault final knowing he already did his part by ruling the floor exercise to capture the Philippines' first-ever medal in Olympic gymnastics.\n\nThat, however, did not prevent the 24-year-old star from making history anew as he edged Armenia's Artur Davtyan for the vault gold that made him the first Filipino to win multiple medals in a single Olympics.\n\nYulo netted 15.433 and 14.800 points from his two vaults for an average of 15.116 points.\n\n\"Today, I was more chilled and relaxed. It helped me give it all because there was nothing to lose anymore. And that's what happened,\" said Yulo.\n\nAll the sleepless nights bore fruit for Yulo.\n\n\"This kept me up at night for two days,\" Yulo said in Filipino about his floor exercise gold in an interview with Olympic broadcaster Cignal. \"But it's really worth it.\"\n\nExpected to be feted with a hero's welcome once he returns home, Yulo said he is ready for a grueling schedule ahead.\n\n\"I'm really excited but I know it's also going to be tough for me because it's kind of outside gymnastics,\" said Yulo. \"Lots of interviews, lot of media, but I'm really excited to do {"uri": "8258915898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:21:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:21:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:20:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/04/yulo-completes-golden-double", "title": "Yulo completes Golden Double", "body": "CARLOS Yulo stands to receive a financial windfall when he gets back from his two-gold haul in the 2024 Paris Olympics. Yulo won the floor exercise gold on Saturday and took his second gold after topping the vault on Sunday at the Bercy Arena in Paris.Lionel BONAVENTURE/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE\n\nCarlos Yulo is now a double Olympic gold medalist and a living legend.\n\nA day after ruling the floor exercise in gymnastics for the Philippines' first gold in the Paris Olympics, Yulo added the vault to his vast and growing collection late Sunday at the Bercy Stadium.\n\nYulo propelled his way to a total score of 15.116 and the gold medal, sending the vault's main man Artur Davtyan settling for silver with a score of 14.966.\n\nHarry Hepworth of Great Britain pocketed the bronze with a score of 14.949.\n\nYulo was the fourth to perform in the cast of eight top vaulters and after the first three registered close scores, the 24-year-old Filipino issued a strong statement with a total of 15.116 from his first jump of 15.433 (Ri Se Gwang) and second of 14.880 (Kasamatsu double twist).\n\n\"I just wish that I would be safe (while doing my routine). I was relaxed because I had nothing to lose. This experience was crazy,\" Yulo told the media in Paris following the awarding ceremony.\n\nIt was a landmark win for Yulo, who had lost to the seasoned Davtyan in the vault in the 2022 world championships in Liverpool, England.\n\nThis time, there was no stopping Yulo from getting back at the 31-year-old Davtyan, who was bronze medalist in Tokyo, where Yulo fared miserably.\n\nAs Yulo runs away with his second gold, the riches he stands to receive when he gets back home should make his bank account fatter.\n\nUnder the law, an Olympic gold has a corresponding reward of P10-million. And since Yulo has snatched two, the amount will likely be doubled.\n\nCondos await\n\nEarlier, Megaworld pledged a condominium unit at BGC worth P24 million for every gold won in Paris.\n\nThe House of Representatives also promised to award him P3 million following his first gold, and the amount could hit double after his vault exploit.\n\nGiven that he will be bringing home two gold medals, Yulo should be getting two units from the real estate company.\n\nThe second Yulo gold now makes the country's campaign in Paris as the Philippines' finest ever, even better than the 1-2-1 haul in Tokyo three years ago behind weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz's gold and the two silvers and bronze produced by boxing.\n\nThe current collection of two could go up to as high as five or possibly more in the coming days with boxing sending two in the medal round and athletics pinning its hopes on EJ Obiena.\n\nWorld No. 2 Obiena is still in the thick of the fight after making the final scheduled Tuesday.\n\n\"Answered prayers... We already broke the record in the Olympics,\" said Philippine Olympic Committee president Abraham 'Bambol' Tolentino, who was in attendance during Yulo's epic showing.\n\nSince making its Olympic {"uri": "2024-08-443119599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "20:26:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T20:26:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T20:18:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/03/sport/carlos-edriel-yulo-olympic-moment-of-the-day/index.html", "title": "Olympic moment of the day: Philippines' Carlos Edriel Yulo gets his nation a historic gold - and himself a new house", "body": "Carlos Edriel Yulo of Philippines reacts after winning gold.\n\nCarlos Edriel Yulo might have only been an inch or two taller than his rivals when he stood in the center of the podium Saturday afternoon, but he had just accomplished something that put him head and shoulders above any man from his nation who'd ever competed at the Olympics.\n\nWith his victory in the men's floor exercise final, Yulo on Saturday became the first Filipino man ever to win an Olympic gold medal, the first Filipino to win any medal in gymnastics and the second Filipino to ever win a gold medal.\n\n\"We are a really small country and the portion of athletes is not the same as the US or UK, so to be able to get a gold medal is really big for us,\" he said after. \"I dedicate this to the Filipinos who supported me. I'm really grateful to them. I want to say thank you for watching and praying for me throughout the competition.\"\n\nAnd while the six-time world champion has made a lot of history for his country, it still seemed like long odds for the Manila native to be standing on that center podium with gold around his neck.\n\nJust before the 2023 World Championships, Yulo and his longtime coach Munehiro Kugiyama decided to part ways. Since then, Yulo has worked without a coach and instead has bounced around the world to train with some of the best athletes in his sport. When he's not traveling, he's returned to Manila - a move he's credited with making him feel more connected with his Filipino teammates.\n\nBut those teammates were not on the floor with him on Saturday. Instead it was just the 24-year-old, flipping, twisting and soaring above the floor at the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nHe hardly put a foot wrong from the start, his powerful strides making him appear to glide across the mat and then his explosive twists and flips made it seem like he was a threat to simply burst through the roof and ascend into the clouds.\n\nIt was a tone-setting performance that the rest of the field simply could not match. But Yulo was still forced to sit as performer after performer took to the floor, trying to knock him off the top of the leaderboard.\n\nBut each failed. His score of 15.000 was enough. And the moment hit him like a ton of bricks.\n\nHugely emotional in the moments after winning, Yulo let out an almighty roar and broke into tears. He pumped his fists and, despite that history-making pedigree, looked completely overwhelmed by what he had just done.\n\nThat didn't change when he took to the podium to receive the first gold medal ever put around a Filipino man's neck.\n\nWith the medal hanging above his chest - it's reportedly very heavy thanks to the piece of the Eiffel Tower that is inlaid in every medal at these Games - Yulo raised his hands above his head in triumph. But his eyes were still full of disbelief, and he looked at his medal like it might be taken away from him at any moment.\n\nOh, and he'll get a house from the government for his achievement. Not a bad Saturday.\n\n\"I know that already (that I am going to get a house). But this (pointing at his gold medal) is what really matters to me. My hard work and the people who really helped me. My success is also their success,\" he said. \"I'm so grateful for this experience and to be able to compete in this competition. I am happy that I won a gold medal and also a house.\"", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kyle_feldscher@cnn.com", "name": "Kyle Feldscher", {"uri": "2024-08-443129538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "20:48:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T20:48:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T20:47:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578048/with-gold-carlos-yulo-puts-ph-greatness-on-world-stage-anew", "title": "With gold, Carlos Yulo puts PH greatness on world stage anew", "body": "He zig-zagged his way past the many media pitstops inside a Tokyo arena, trying to explain what had just happened.\n\nWhen he finally came in front of Filipino journalists, there were no more words left -- just an outpour of emotion wrapped in two words: \"It hurts,\" Carlos Yulo said as tears pooled at the sides of his eyes.\n\nThat was three years ago.\n\nOn Saturday, there were no words again, just tears. But boy, were they glorious ones.\n\nThe Filipino dynamo won the floor exercise gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics with an upgraded difficulty in his routine and an execution that laid to rest his mistakes from three years ago.\n\n\"I did not hesitate. I just went for it,\" Yulo told journalists after the medal ceremony.\n\nThe 24-year-old star who fumbled right in his first pass and crashed out of the floor exercise medal hunt in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics sealed his moment of glory with a perfect landing that drew roars of approval from the packed Barcy Arena.\n\nYulo's final run in his routine featured a front full into a three-and-a-half twist, which was impressive on its own. But then he stuck the landing so emphatically that he could not help but roar loudly and pump his arms sideways to let everyone know that he did exactly what he set out to do in the final.\n\nThe judges agreed: The two-time world champion, who submitted a 6.600 and was rewarded for his near-flawless execution of that routine, garnering a 15.000 for the gold.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" said Yulo. \"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\"\n\nHe isn't even done yet.\n\nYulo has a chance of making it two gold medals in the Paris Games when he competes in the vault finals on Sunday. And he might have even better chances there. Yulo fared better in the vault than in the floor exercise during the all-around finale.\n\nArtem Dolgopyat of Israel, the defending floor exercise champion, settled for the silver this time while Great Britain's Jake Jarman rounded out the podium with a bronze. Dolgopyat set the pace with his 14.966 points, giving Yulo a tough act to follow.\n\nBut Yulo was undaunted when he took his turn.\n\nHe opened with a two-and-a-half twist to front double pike. Then, he went into a front double full to front double tuck. He had slight hops at the end of both. But after a full-twisting double, he stuck another landing and it was clear he was in the middle of something special.\n\nThe biggest scare came when Jarman, who topped the floor exercise during the men's all-around final and qualifications, took the floor.\n\nWhile the British gymnast, a friend of Yulo's whose mother is Filipino, executed his routine, Yulo watched with bated breath until it was revealed that Jarman scored 14.933 points.\n\n\"We are a small country. Our [delegation] is not that big. So to be able to win a gold medal is really big for us.\"\n\nYulo became just the second Olympic champion for the Philippines ever. Three years ago, Hidilyn Diaz emboldened an entire nation to chase greatness when she won the weightlifting gold medal in the women's 55kg division.\n\nA day before Diaz's historic, trailblazing triumph, Yulo went from one interview to another, trying to put into words how he missed out on his own shot at glory.\n\nHe couldn't find the right words again Saturday night.\n\n\"I still can't believe I was able to do this,\" he said.\n\nIt was hard to hear him anyway, what with the din of celebration that followed another display of Filipino greatness on the Olympic stage. {"uri": "2024-08-443722802", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:11:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:11:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:04:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/08/05/2375539/millions-incentives-await-yulo", "title": "Millions in incentives await Yulo", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- When he comes home, gold medalist Carlos Yulo's 2024 Paris Olympic Games victory will be made even sweeter with more prizes, courtesy of the country's tycoons.\n\nAndrew Tan's property giant Megaworld Corp. is rewarding Yulo with a fully furnished two-bedroom residential condominium unit in Bonifacio Global City valued at P24 million.\n\nThe men's gymnastics champion's new condominium is located within Megaworld's 50-hectare McKinley Hill township in Taguig.\n\n\"That's our commitment, not just for him, but to every Filipino Olympic athlete who will get gold,\" Megaworld vice president for public relations Harold Geronimo told The STAR yesterday.\n\nThe SM Group of the Sy family, meanwhile, has pledged P1 million worth of products from SM Retail, both department stores and supermarkets, consumable within one year.\n\nPopular buffet restaurant chain Vikings pledged on its official Facebook page a lifetime free buffet to the celebrated athlete.\n\nAnother tycoon-led group will also be announcing today its reward for Yulo, The STAR has learned.\n\nYulo, who topped the floor exercise finals of the men's gymnastics in the Paris Olympics, is the country's second Olympic gold medalist after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz.\n\nDiaz, who won her gold medal during the Tokyo Olympics three years ago, received hefty cash prizes and incentives from companies and tycoons such as Manuel V. Pangilinan and Ramon Ang.\n\nAside from the prizes coming from the country's most notable tycoons, the government - according to Section 8 of Republic Act 10699 - will be awarding Yulo with P10 million and an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor to be issued by the Philippine Sports Commission.\n\nSenators commend Yulo\n\nSenators commended Yulo, the country's first gymnast to win a gold medal in the Paris Olympics.\n\nSen. Sherwin Gatchalian \"joined the Filipino people in congratulating Carlos Yulo for clinching an Olympic gold in the floor exercises in gymnastics. This historic win brings a special moment of pride for our country, and proves that the Olympic gold is no longer elusive for Filipino athletes. He has inspired countless Filipinos with his exceptional performance.\"\n\nGatchalian said, \"Our task as a nation is to ensure that future generations of athletes have all the support they need to succeed on the world stage. This is why we created the National Academy of Sports, where promising young athletes will be honed to achieve their full potential.\n\n\"The whole country is cheering and proud of you! Mabuhay ka, Caloy!\" he added.\n\nSen. Nancy Binay said, \"A tribute to the country's first gymnast gold medalist, Carlos Yulo! The nation cried, screamed, and applauded alongside Caloy's historic day at the Paris Olympics.\"\n\nShe noted that Yulo garnered a 15.000 score in the men's floor exercise on Aug. 3 to become the first Filipino gymnast to reach the medal podium in the quadrennial games. \"His win is also the Philippines' first medal in the ongoing Olympics.\"\n\nBinay said Yulo overcame various setbacks and challenges, which included a change of coach and moving back to the Philippines from Japan for his training, to get to this moment.\n\n\"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster,\" Binay said. \"Thank you very much for displaying what Filipinos can achieve, Caloy. Mabuhay ka!\"\n\nSen. Bong Go offered his congratulatory message, and said, \"Your winning of the gold medal at the Olympics gives great honor to the entire nation. You are a big reason for Filipinos to be more united at a time when the stability of our people is being tested due to the challenges of the times. Carlos, you bring honor to the Filipino!\n\n\"As chairperson of the Senate Sports Committee and Senate Youth Committee, I will continue to support people like you and young Filipinos who also want to be champions in the future. It's a great feeling when you work hard and sweat for your win. This is proof that when the people support our athletes, they will go far,\" he said.\n\n\"This is also a challenge for us to continue and strengthen our sports programs to give other athletes the opportunity and inspiration to show their talent and win, not only in sports, but in any field they choose in life,\" Go said. \"To our other athletes and coaches at the 2024 Paris Games, we wish you success! Your success is also the success of Filipinos! Fight Philippines! Go, go for gold!\"\n\nMore prizes from the House\n\nYulo stands to receive some P3 million in cash incentives from the House of Representatives.\n\nSpeaker Martin Romualdez said Yulo will also be conferred a \"congressional medal for his exceptional achievement and contribution to Philippine sports.\"\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" he noted.\n\nRomualdez added that Yulo's historic victory, \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people.\"\n\nEarlier, Romualdez extended financial assistance to 22 Filipino athletes participating in the Paris Olympics.\n\nHe also initiated a fundraising campaign among his House colleagues to provide additional cash incentives to Yulo.\n\n\"We celebrate a monumental achievement that resonates deeply with every Filipino heart. Carlos Edriel Yulo has not only soared to the pinnacle of athletic excellence, but has also emerged as a sports hero and national treasure, igniting a beacon of hope and inspiration for all Filipinos,\" he said.\n\nHouse appropriations committee chair and Ako Bicol party-list Rep. Elizaldy Co extended his congratulations to Yulo for bringing \"immense pride to our nation.\"\n\n\"Carlos has shown that with determination and resilience, Filipinos can excel and achieve greatness in any field. Carlos has proven that Filipinos can keep up with the world,\" Co said.\n\nOFW party-list Rep. Marissa Magsino also hailed Yulo's golden feat.\n\n\"Carlos Yulo is the epitome of hard work, perseverance, and a positive outlook. His gold medal in the Olympics brings so much pride to every Filipino,\" Magsino said.\n\nHero's welcome\n\nA \"hero's welcome\" is now being prepared for Yulo and other Paris Olympics athletes.\n\nManila Mayor Honey Lacuna-Pangan said the \"grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians.\"\n\nPangan added that the local government would present Yulo with cash incentives, awards, and symbols of \"eternal gratitude\" from Manila.\n\n\"We sang along as Caloy sang the Philippine national anthem. Tears welled up in our eyes and flowed in streams on our faces as the Philippine flag rose in Paris,\" the mayor said in a statement.\n\nYulo is a resident of Leveriza in Malate, Manila. -- Cecille {"uri": "8257758811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "18:37:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T18:37:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T18:36:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/gymnastics-carlos-yulo-seizes-paris-olympics-gold-medal-2024/", "title": "Carlos Yulo seizes 'huge' Olympic gold for 'really small country'", "body": "PARIS, France - Carlos Edriel Yulo produced a spectacular performance to win the men's floor exercise final at the Paris Games on Saturday, August 3, earning the Philippines its first-ever Olympic medal in gymnastics.\n\nYulo's gold medal is also only the second-ever top prize won by the Philippines across both the Summer and Winter Games, and the first in the men's category. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz struck gold in Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"I don't know what to say,\" the 24-year-old, who just missed the vault podium at the Tokyo 2020 Games, said.\n\n\"We are a really small country... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people also who supported me.\"\n\nYulo opened with a tumbling pass that featured a high-flying 2-1/2 double piked front somersault and rounded off the dynamic display with an astonishing 3-1/2 twisting forward somersault.\n\nWhen he stuck his final landing, he punched the air with both fists, let out a huge roar and then saluted the hollering crowd that had leapt to their feet to applaud the virtuoso performance.\n\nHe scored 15.000 points, edging out Tokyo champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by just 0.034 of a point.\n\nTop qualifier Jake Jarman of Britain settled for third, just 0.067 of a point adrift of the gold medal spot after committing small landing errors on his tumbles.\n\nWhen the final score flashed on the big screen at Bercy Arena, Yulo, overcome with emotion, covered his face with his hands as he broke down in tears and collapsed to the ground.\n\nFilipino athletes at the Paris Games have been promised a fully furnished, two-bedroom condominium in Taguig City if they win a gold medal.\n\nYulo said he was grateful for the reward, but that it was secondary to the world title he had just won.\n\n\"It's just a bonus for me. And this is what really matters,\" he said, clutching the medal around his neck.\n\n\"My hard work and the people who really helped me. I know my success is also their success... I'm happy that I won gold. And I also won a house,\" he said, laughing.\n\nYulo, who trained for seven years in Japan due to a lack of opportunity back home, said he hoped his historic win would open the door for children in the Philippines to take up the sport.", "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rappler"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jasmine_payo@rappler.com", "name": "Jasmine Payo", "type": {"uri": "8258105242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "03:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T03:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T03:18:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/marcos-congratulates-carlos-yulo-for-phs-1st-gold-medal-in-2024-paris-olympics", "title": "Marcos congratulates Carlos Yulo for PH's 1st gold medal in 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "PRESIDENT Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos Jr. congratulated gymnast Carlos Yulo for bagging the Philippines' first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nIn a Facebook post, Marcos expressed elation over Yulo's achievement which makes him the second Filipino athlete to win an Olympic gold medal, next to weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the President said in a Facebook post.\n\n\"I am confident that it will not be the last. Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he added.\n\nYulo scored 15.000 in the men's floor exercise finals held on August 3. He won against the defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel who scored 14.966. On the third spot was Jake Jarman of Britain scoring 14.933.\n\nHe will have a chance for another medal when he competes in the vault finals on Sunday, August 4.\n\nYulo said he is dedicating his win to the Filipino people.\n\n\"We are a really small country... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people also who supported me,\" he said.\n\nUnder Republic Act 10699 enacted in 2015, a gold medalist from the Philippines for individual events will receive P10 million.\n\nThe law also set an incentive for silver medalists at P5 million and P2 million for bronze medalists.\n\nYulo will also receive an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor from the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC) and a house and lot from the Philippine Olympic Committee.\n\nThe Megaworld Corporation will also give Yulo a P24-million worth of fully-furnished condominium unit at the Bonifacio Global City.\n\nIn a statement, Ako Bicol partylist representative Elizaldy Co, chairman of the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives said they will also award Yulo P3 million in recognition of his historic accomplishment.\n\n\"This reward reflects our support for his continued success and our commitment to fostering Filipino talent on the international stage,\" Co said.\n\n\"[His] dedication and hard work have brought immense pride to our nation...Siya ay isang inspirasyon sa lahat ng kabataan at sa mga nangangarap. Siya ang patunay na kapag may sipag at tiyaga, walang imposible\" he added. {"uri": "8257886845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "21:19:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T21:19:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T21:18:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/08/04/meet-king-carlo-the-philippines-2nd-olympic-gold-medalist/", "title": "Meet King Carlo: The Philippines' 2nd Olympic gold medalist | Jun Lomibao", "body": "PARIS -- And so it's done. Carlos Yulo is now an Olympic champion in men's floor exercise of gymnastics at the Paris Olympics.\n\n\"This is overwhelming, I could hardly believe this has happened,\" said Yulo, the country's only second Olympic gold medalist after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo won the first three years ago in Tokyo 2020.\n\n\"I thank the Lord God for this, He has watched over me all these years, all throughout my career as a gymnast,\" he added.\n\nYulo was third on the start list and with a routine the International Gymnastics Federation described in its website as highlighted by six fantastic runs with 3.5-twist dismount, the 24-year-old from Leveriza scored 15.000 points and stayed on the hot seat until the last of the eight finalists completed his routine.\n\nArtem Dorgoplyat, who won for Israel its first Olympic gymnastics gold in Tokyo, settled for silver this time with 14.966, while Great Britain's Jaka Jarman, whose mother is from Cebu and who Yulo considers as his toughest opponent in the event, clinched bronze with 14.933.\n\nThere were anxious moments as Yulo had to wait for six gymnasts to perform after him inside the cavernous Bercy Arena that was filled to the rafters.\n\nThe last to perform was another Englishman, Luke Whitehouse, and the very moment after his score was flashed on the jumbotron, Yulo dropped to his knees and cried his mind and heart out.\n\n\"I didn't care anymore how I looked like while I was crying,\" the 2019 world floor exercise champion told BusinessMirror. \"Did I still look good? Or did I look ugly?\n\nHe looked great from all angles -- he's just clinched that Olympic gold medal that was the fruit of years and years of hard work, hundreds of hours in the gym and traded his teenaged life to being full-time as a gymnast.\n\n\"Everything I went through in training, the hard work and sacrifices, my years in Japan, my Tokyo campaign, they flashed into my mind in that short instance,\" said Yulo, who expressed his gratitude to gymnastics association head Cynthia Carrion-Norton, his parents Mark Andrew and Angelika and his girldfriend, Chloe San Jose, who was with all the way here in Paris.\n\n\"Chloe's always there by my side, comforting me and cheering me up,\" he said.\n\nBut Yulo just couldn't celebrate his floor exercise gold medal just yet with the vault final coming up on Sunday at 4 p.m. (11 p.m. in Manila).\n\nHe's also a favorite in the apparatus with his 2022 world championship gold medal.\n\n\"I'll take it [vault] the way in hurdled the floor exercise,\" he said.\n\nAsked by a wires correspondent what his gold medal means to his countrymen, Yulo said: \"We're really small country and the number of our athletes is not the same as those in the US or UK, so today, to get the gold medal is really big for us.\"\n\n\"I dedicate this to the Filipino people who're supporting me and having a hard time bacck home [floods and typhoon] and I'm {"uri": "2024-08-444065929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:42:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:42:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:40:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://usa.inquirer.net/154529/what-awaits-carlos-yulo-after-making-history-in-2024-paris-olympics", "title": "What awaits Carlos Yulo after making history in 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "It's a historic moment for the Philippines as gymnast Carlos Yulo achieved multiple firsts at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nA century ago, the elusive gold medal seemed out of reach for the country. For 100 years of fighting for a podium finish, the Philippines only held one Olympic gold, won by weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz in 2020. Until Saturday night on Aug. 3 (PST), Yulo rose to the occasion and doubled the success.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by FIG Gymnastics (@figymnastics)\n\nDubbed the Philippines' \"Golden Boy,\" Yulo became the first Filipino athlete to win two Olympic gold medals in the same year, triumphing in both the floor exercise and vault finals for men's artistic gymnastics with scores of 15.00 and 15.116 respectively. This remarkable feat also made the 24-year-old world champion the first Filipino multi-medalist in Olympic history since the country's debut in 1924.\n\nWith this, both the government and private sectors have promised significant rewards for his historic achievements. However, these incentives were announced before he clinched his second gold in the vault finals.\n\nWill Yulo receive double the rewards for his unprecedented success?\n\nUnder Republic Act 10699, signed in 2015, Filipino athletes who win Olympic medals receive significant cash incentives based on their placements. Gold medalists like \"Caloy\" are awarded P10,000,000, silver medalists receive P5,000,000, and bronze medalists earn P2,000,000.\n\nAlongside the cash incentives, Yulo will also be awarded the Olympic Gold Medal of Valor by the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC). Additionally, the Philippine Olympic Committee has pledged to give him a house and lot, following the precedent set during the Tokyo Olympics three years ago.\n\nThe House of Representatives will also award Yulo P3 million for his gold medal achievement. In recognition of his success, property development company Megaworld has pledged to give him a fully-furnished 2-bedroom condominium unit in McKinley Hill, BGC, worth P24 million. So, will he get two units after the second win?\n\nYulo will enjoy a lifetime supply of various benefits from all restaurant chains of Vikings, free meals at JT's Kalayaan, free food and drinks at all Tipsy Pig Gastropub branches, free bacsilog from BastaMura Bacsilog, free furniture worth P100,000 from Apollo Home Depot and definitely more to come.\n\nCurrently, the Philippines has three Olympic gold medals: two from Carlos Yulo and one from Hidilyn Diaz in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. There are still Filipino athletes in medal contention, such as boxers Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas, who are guaranteed an Olympic medal, and world No. 2 EJ Obiena, who is competing in the pole vault finals.\n\nWant stories like this delivered straight to your inbox? {"uri": "2024-08-443013538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "17:07:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T17:07:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T16:55:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-carlos-yulo-makes-philippines-gold-medal-history", "title": "Carlos Yulo makes Philippines gold medal history at Olympics", "body": "The Paris Olympics are continuing to be a games to remember. Gymnast Carlos Yulo made history for the Philippines by becoming the first Filipino athlete to win an Olympic medal in gymnastics, per ESPN. Yulo brought home a gold medal for his floor routine in the men's artistic gymnastics floor exercise final in Paris.\n\nYulo tallied 15.000 points in a stunning final performance. He defeated defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel, who finished in a close second. Yulo was overjoyed to win a gold and make history for the Philippines, he said.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" Yulo said, per The Inquirer. \"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\"\n\nYulo's win is just the second gold medal all-time for an athlete from the Philippines. The other person to win gold is weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz. She took it at Tokyo in 2020 for the Women's 55kg event.\n\nYulo completed his winning performance with a triple-twisting dismount during his final tumbling pass, per the Associated Press. He threw his arms up in triumph, certainly warming the hearts of his country's residents and fans.\n\nTeam USA is also having an Olympics to remember\n\nTeam USA may not have won a gold in that particular event, but the Americans are also having a games to remember. In gymnastics events alone, Team USA is racking up the medals. The Americans also lead the total medal count of any country overall at the Paris games, at time of writing.\n\nThe women's gymnastics team already won a gold medal in the team event. Gymnast Simone Biles is smoking the competition, with one stunning performance after another. Biles won her seventh Olympic gold medal Saturday, after taking the women's vault final.\n\nBiles has a chance to win a few more medals. She is competing Monday in the balance beam and floor exercise finals. Her performances are winning over all sorts of fans, including retired swimmer Michael Phelps. Phelps made the bold but accurate claim that Biles is the greatest gymnast of all-time.\n\nThe Americans are also doing well in several other sports. Team USA basketball plays Puerto Rico Saturday, with a chance to earn the top seed in the final rounds of competition. Swimmer Katie Ledecky became the second American to win 13 Olympic medals, joining Michael Phelps. She accomplished that feat by winning silver in the women's 4\u00d7200-meter freestyle relay.\n\nThe Olympics continue through August 11, so there are sure to be many more memories to come.", {"uri": "8258955219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:06:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:06:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:04:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.manila-shimbun.com/category/english/news278263.html", "title": "Yulo wins Philippines' first Olympic gold in Paris, Marcos hopes ''it will not be the last''", "body": "Carlos Yulo won the Philippines' first gold medal in the Paris 2024 Olympics in gymnastics' floor exercise on Saturday.\n\nThis is the country's second straight Olympic gold after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz triumped in Tokyo 2021.\n\nThe 4-foot-11 Yulo came up with a score of 15.00 to dethrone defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel in the event where he was once a world titlist.\n\nIt was redemption for Yulo after he failed in the 2021 Olympics in Tokyo. He had been training in Japan since 2016 for years and much was expected from him.\n\nPresident Ferdinand Marcos Jr congratulated Yulo.\n\n''We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,'' said Marcos in his social media account.\n\n''I am confident that it will not be the last,'' he added.\n\nJapanese Ambassador to the Phiippines Endo Kazuya said in his account on X (formerly Twitter): ''\n\nCongratulations to Carlos Yulo for your gold-medal win! Incredibly floored by your performance tonight,'' he said.\n\n''Japan is honored to have been part of your historic victory for the Philippines,'' added the ambassador.\n\nYulo got a scholarship program from the Japan Olympic Association in 2016. He stayed there, training under coach Munehiro Kugiyima. He changed coaches last year as he trained in the Philippines under Aldrin Castaneda. {"uri": "8258853513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:29:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:29:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:14:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/05/news/national/champ-yulo-gets-more-than-gold/1961863", "title": "Champ Yulo gets more than gold", "body": "WHEN Olympic gold medalist Carlos Yulo comes home to the Philippines, he will get more than a hero's welcome -- he stands to receive at least P13 million in incentives from the government and a posh condominium worth P24 million from real estate giant Megaworld.\n\nYulo delivered a dazzling performance that netted him 15.0 points and the gold medal at the Paris Olympics men's gymnastics floor exercise at the Bercy Arena on Saturday evening, August 3 (Manila time).\n\nThe gold was the first medal for the Philippines in Olympic gymnastics.\n\nPresident Ferdinand Marcos Jr. congratulated Yulo on his social media account.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first Gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the President said, adding that he is \"confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he said.\n\nUnder Republic Act 10699, also known as the Sports Benefits and Incentives Act of 2001, Filipino Olympic gold medalists will receive P10 million on top of the Olympic Gold Medal of Valor to be issued by the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC).\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSilver medalists will be given P5 million, while bronze medalists will get P2 million.\n\nThe House of Representatives, meanwhile, chipped in a P3 million reward to the gold medalist.\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" Speaker Martin Romualdez said of the cash incentive.\n\nThe House will also give Yulo a congressional medal for his achievement.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nYulo could add to his P10 million if he makes the podium anew in the vault final set on Sunday evening, August 4.\n\nMeanwhile, Megaworld on August 2 pledged a fully-furnished two-bedroom residential condominium unit worth P24 million inside the company's 50-hectare McKinley Hill township in Taguig City.\n\nFollowing Yulo's golden medal performance, Megaworld posted on Facebook:\n\n\"IT'S A GOLD FOR THE PHILIPPINES! Congratulations Carlos Yulo! Welcome to your McKinley Hill home!\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThat served as the caption in a graphic congratulating Yulo and the \"fully-furnished 2-bedroom condominium unit in McKinley Hill, valued at P24M\" in the image.\n\nExpect more companies to give whatever they will to Yulo, just like they did with the first Filipino Olympic gold medalist, Hidilyn Diaz, three years ago.\n\nDiaz, Obiena lead celebrations\n\nThe country's first Olympic gold medalist, Hidilyn Diaz, was among the first to congratulate Yulo.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn an Instagram story, Diaz said there were \"different emotions\" in Yulo's victory and thanked all the Filipino athletes.\n\n\"Para sa iyo, Caloy: Proud ako sa iyo. I-enjoy mo ang bunga ng pinagpaguran mo. At lagi mong ibabalik -- sa Diyos at bayan, dahil lahat ng tagumpay natin ay hindi pansarili. Salamat sa lahat ng maganda at mabuting ginagawa at gagawin mo pa para sa Diyos at bayan (I am so proud of you. Enjoy the fruits of your hard work. And always remember to give back -- to God and country -- because our success is not for ourselves alone. Thank you for all the good things you have done and will continue to do for God and country)!\" she wrote on Facebook.\n\nWhile she will not be in the Olympics as an athlete, Diaz is headed for Paris as an official for the International Weightlifting Federation, as the Olympic events will start on August 7.\n\nMeanwhile, hours after his qualification to the pole vault finals, Ernest John \"EJ\" Obiena also congratulated Yulo on his Instagram story, with a simple \"Yes, sir!\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Abraham Tolentino on Facebook congratulated Yulo, accompanied by photos together with the country's newest Olympic champion in the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nThe Gymnastics Association of the Philippines (GAP) also called Yulo's gold medal win a \"golden comeback\" from his run in the previous Olympics in Tokyo. GAP President Cynthia Carrion was in Paris to witness Yulo's win.\n\n\"Our country's first gold medal for Men's Artistic Gymnastics was brought home by our Golden Boy, Carlos Yulo!\" GAP wrote on Facebook.\n\nSenators sent their congratulations, too.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Caloy overcame various setbacks and challenges, which included a change of coach and moving back to the Philippines from Japan for his training, to get to this moment,\" Sen. Nancy Binay said in a statement.\n\n\"You are a shining example, Caloy, of how we can strive to achieve balance in our lives despite the pursuit of glory,\" Binay said.\n\nShe added, \"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster.\"\n\nSen. Robinhood Padilla congratulated Yulo for being \"the first to give our Motherland the first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics.\"\n\n\"Hopefully, this will not be the last gold medal for our athletes in the 2024 Games,\" Padilla said.\n\nFirst gold in Southeast Asia\n\nYulo's gold enabled the Philippines to beat all its Southeast Asian neighbors to the medal table, so far.\n\nIt was the Philippines' first medal in Paris and the first of any color from a gymnast.\n\nThe Philippines will finish the Paris Olympics with at least two medals as boxer Aira Villegas guaranteed herself a bronze after reaching the semifinals of the women's 50 kg division.\n\nVillegas braved the boisterous home crowd and defeated French Wassila Lkhadiri via split decision in the quarterfinals early Sunday, August 4 (Manila time).\n\nVillegas will face Turkish Buse Naz Cakiroglu in the semifinal round on August 7 at 4:18 a.m. in Manila.\n\nVillegas' quarterfinal victory is huge for the Philippine boxing team in Paris after one of its top bets -- Carlo Paalam -- exited the tournament.\n\nA Tokyo Olympics silver medalist, Paalam suffered a tough split decision loss to Aussie Charlie Senior in the men's 57 kg quarterfinals on Saturday evening.\n\nPaalam joined Eumir Marcial (men's 80 kg) and Hergie Bacyadan (women's 75 kg) in the list of Filipino boxers who were eliminated from the medal race.\n\nWITH REPORTS FROM ARIC JOHN SY CUA, CATHERINE VALENTE, REINA C. Carlos proved that Filipinos can keep up on the international stage,\" said Co in a statement.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to the youth and all those who dream. He is proof that nothing is impossible with perseverance and hard work,\" he added.\n\nREAD: Gov't must invest and focus on 'sports economy', say lawmakers\n\nYulo bagged the country's first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics after dominating the men's artistic gymnastic floor exercise final at Bercy Arena on Saturday night (Philippine time). Great Britain's Jake Jarman took the bronze with a score of 14.933.\n\nOLYMPIAN ROCKS TIKTOK OVER CHOCOLATE MUFFINS THAT TASTE 'JUST LIKE CAKE'\n\nReal estate corporation Megaworld announced the incentive and prize in an Aug. 1 statement.\n\n\"This 2024, we are celebrating our 100th year of participating in the Olympic Games, and what a way to celebrate this milestone than by recognizing the superb competitive spirit of our newest Olympic gold medalist and welcoming them to McKinley Hill,\" Megaworld President Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso said in the statement.\n\nMcKinley Hill is a township in Taguig City, which is located in Metro Manila.\n\nThe location is \"a perfect home for Filipino champions who live a life of passion and excellence through and through,\" she said.\n\nThe two-bedroom condominium is valued at 24 million pesos, said Megaworld, which is equal to about $415,000.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nYulo also received kudos from President Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Romualdez Marcos of the Philippines and a cash prize from the country's government.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first GOLD medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" Marcos wrote on his Facebook page.\n\n\"I am confident that it will not be the last. Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\"\n\nThe Philippines' House of Representatives also voted to award Yulo 3 million Philippine pesos (about $51,900) for his gold medal, multiple news outlets from the country reported.\n\nYulo's win not only secured the first medal for the Philippines in gymnastics. It's also the first Olympic gold medal for a Filipino male athlete. It was the second gold medal for the Philippines. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz won the women's 55-kilogram competition in Tokyo.\n\nSIMONE BILES MAKES OLYMPIC HISTORY AFTER WINNING GOLD MEDAL IN WOMEN'S VAULT FINAL\n\nShe, too, was awarded a house at the time.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" Yulo said after his win, via AFP.\n\n\"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\"\n\nYulo, who has trained in Japan since 2017 as part of an Olympic Solidarity program aimed at increasing opportunities for athletes, hopes that his win will inspire others in the Philippines to pursue gymnastics.\n\n\"Hopefully, gymnastics in the country will grow,\" he said, via Reuters.\n\n\"My hard work and the people who really helped me. I know my success is also their success. ... I'm happy that I won gold. And I also won a house.\"\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nYulo has a chance to win another gold medal Sunday. Carlos proved that Filipinos can keep up on the international stage,\" said Co in a statement.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to the youth and all those who dream. He is proof that nothing is impossible with perseverance and hard work,\" he added.\n\nYulo bagged the country's first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics after dominating the men's artistic gymnastic floor exercise final at Bercy Arena on Saturday night (Philippine time). He is the second Filipino to secure a gold medal in the Olympics scene for the country, after Hidilyn Diaz' victory in the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 (women's 55 kg weightlifting category).\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. This reward reflects our support for his continued success and our commitment to fostering Filipino talent on the international stage,\" Co said in a statement.\n\nCo said Yulo's \"dedication and hard work have brought immense pride to our nation.\"\n\n\"Carlos has shown that with determination and resilience, Filipinos can excel and achieve greatness in any field. Napatunayan ni Carlos na kayang makipagsabayan ng mga Pilipino sa buong mundo,\" he added.\n\n(He proved that Filipinos can be at par with others in the world.)\n\n\"Siya ay isang inspirasyon sa lahat ng kabataan at sa mga nangangarap. Siya ang patunay na kapag may sipag at tiyaga, walang imposible,\" Co said, congratulating the Filipino gymnast.\n\n(He is an inspiration to the youth and to all those with dreams. He is proof that when one has diligence and patience, nothing is impossible.)\n\nYulo, 24, became the first-ever Filipino gymnast to ever reach the podium in any edition of the Summer Games, seizing the gold medal in the men's floor exercise at the 2024 Paris Olympics on Saturday at the Bercy Arena.\n\nHe also became the first medalist in the Philippines' campaign in Paris, and the second gold medalist from the country following weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz who won a gold medal for weightlifting at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nAsked for comment after his win, Yulo said, \"I dedicate this to the Filipino people also who supported me.\"\n\nYulo will have another shot at an Olympic medal on Sunday when he competes in the vault finals.\n\nPresident Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos also congratulated Yulo for his victory on Saturday.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you,\" Marcos said in a post on Facebook.\n\nMarcos also said he is confident about the country's medal chances in the Summer Games.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the caption said. \"I am confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nAside from Yulo, boxers Aira Villegas and Nesthy Petecio are still on the running for a possible medal, while pole vaulter EJ Obiena qualified for the men's pole vault finals.\n\nHurdlers John Cabang Tolentino and Lauren Hoffman, golfers Dottie Ardina and Bianca Pagdanganan, and weightlifters John Ceniza, Vanessa Sarno, and Elreen Ando have yet to commence their respective campaigns in the Summer Games. -- KG,
