{"uri": "2024-08-444086991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:14:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:14:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:52:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/mac-cheese-life-philippines-heartfelt-045234135.html", "title": "Mac and cheese for life! Philippines' heartfelt gifts to Carlos Yulo after double Olympic gold", "body": "Mac and cheese for life! Philippines' heartfelt gifts to Carlos Yulo after double Olympic gold\n\nRebecca Ratcliffe South-east Asia correspondent\n\n5 August 2024 at 6:52 am\n\nFilipino gymnast Carlos Yulo's historic double gold medal win at the Paris Olympics has been celebrated across the Philippines, with businesses showering the athlete in gifts - from cash and a new home, to a lifetime supply of mac and cheese.\n\nFerdinand Marcos, the president, said the Philippines had \"witnessed history\" when Yulo became the first Filipino man to win a gold medal after competing in the artistic gymnastic floor exercise on Saturday. He is only the second Filipino athlete to win an Olympic gold, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz in 2020. On Sunday, Yulo soared to the top of the podium again in the vault, thus becoming the first Filipino to win two golds - and at a single Olympics.\n\n\"No words can express how proud we are of you,\" Marcos said. \"Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you.\"\n\nCarlos was described as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\" by speaker of the lower house, Ferdinand Martin Romualdez. Yulo will be given three million Philippines pesos (\u00a340,500/US$51,890) and a congressional medal, and is due to receive P10m under a law that promises incentives to athletes.\n\nPrivate sector companies, big and small, announced a flurry of gifts, including a fully furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24m in Taguig City, Metro Manila. Yulo was also offered lifetime supplies of free buffets, baked mac and cheese, and chicken inasal, a grilled chicken dish, by various chain restaurants.\n\nA car lights specialist offered him a free set of headlights and fog lights for his vehicle, while a wedding photographer pledged free services to the 24-year-old and another business offered a lifetime supply of phone cases. A Filipino doctor pledged free consultation and endoscopic procedures for Yulo when he turned 45, as well as to any patients in need whom Yulo would like to endorse.\n\nYulo collapsed to the ground in tears when he realised he had secured the gold on Saturday. \"I don't know what to say,\" he said. \"We are a really small country ... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people who supported me.\"\n\nYulo has been offered franchises for a coffee and a lemon drink business, and a P10m brand ambassadorship contract for a beauty clinic, according to company announcements on social media.\n\nThose who share the same name as Yulo are also in luck, as celebrations sweep the country. Cafes and restaurants have offered free meals or milkshakes to anyone named Carlos, Caloy (his nickname) or Edriel (his middle name), while a music venue offered free entry over the weekend to anyone {"uri": "8258259769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "06:38:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T06:38:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T06:38:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.bworldonline.com/sports/2024/08/04/611902/carlos-yulo-wins-historic-gold-for-philippines-with-floor-exercise-title/", "title": "Carlos Yulo wins historic gold for Philippines with floor exercise title - BusinessWorld Online", "body": "PARIS -- Carlos Edriel Yulo produced a spectacular performance to win the men's floor exercise final at the Paris Games on Saturday, earning Philippines their first-ever Olympic medal in gymnastics.\n\nMr. Yulo's gold medal is also only the second-ever top prize won by the Philippines across both the Summer and Winter Games, and the first in the men's category. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz struck gold in Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"I don't know what to say,\" the 24-year-old, who just missed the podium at the Tokyo 2020 Games, said.\n\n\"We are a really small country... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people also who supported me.\"\n\nMr. Yulo opened with a tumbling pass that featured a high-flying 2-1/2 double piked front somersault and rounded off the dynamic display with an astonishing 3-1/2 twisting forward somersault.\n\nWhen he stuck his final landing, he punched the air with both fists, let out a huge roar and then saluted the hollering crowd that had leapt to their feet to applaud the virtuoso performance.\n\nHe scored 15.000 points, edging out Tokyo champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by just 0.034 of a point.\n\nTop qualifier Jake Jarman of Britain settled for third, just 0.067 of a point adrift of the gold medal spot after committing small landing errors on his tumbles.\n\nWhen the final score flashed on the big screen at Bercy Arena, Mr. Yulo, overcome with emotion, covered his face with his hands as he broke down in tears and collapsed to the ground.\n\nFilipino athletes at the Paris Games have been promised a fully furnished, two-bedroom condominium in Taguig City if they win a gold medal.\n\nMr. Yulo said he was grateful for the reward, but that it was secondary to the world title he had just won.\n\n\"It's just a bonus for me. And this is what really matters,\" he said, clutching the medal around his neck.\n\n\"My hard work and the people who really helped me. I know my success is also their success... I'm happy that I won gold. And I also won a house,\" he said, laughing.\n\nMr. Yulo, who trained for seven years in Japan due to a lack of opportunity back home, said he hoped his historic win would open the door for children in the Philippines to take up the sport.", "source": {"uri": "bworldonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessWorld"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8258719197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "14:03:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T14:03:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T14:02:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/08/04/king-carlos-yulo-sleepless-in-paris/", "title": "King Carlos Yulo: Sleepless in Paris | Jun Lomibao", "body": "PARIS -- Carlos Yulo practically made it look so easy winning the men's floor exercise gold medal at the Paris Olympics on Saturday night.\n\nBut the now Olympic winner and two-time world champion bared that he didn't get enough sleep ahead of the floor exercise final, especially the night before.\n\n\"Actually, this competition did not let me sleep, especially this floor,\" Yulo told BusinessMirror on Saturday. \"I was really nervous for two days.\"\n\nHe slept early enough on Friday night but was roused several times.\n\n\"I slept early, but I woke up several times because I thought about my performance,\" he said. \"I thought about the moment when I would get the medal.\"\n\nYulo, too, skipped staying at the Olympic Village in favor of a hotel near the Bercy Arena.\n\n\"In the village, we train in the gym,\" he said. \"I got tired of the village, the food, so we prefer to dine somewhere else,\" Yulo said.\n\nThere's no timetable yet on when Yulo will be flying back to Manila but definitely, when he does, he'll be welcomed a hero and greeting him will be millions in rewards.\n\nBut for Yulo, all the forthcoming cash rewards, houses and lots and potential product endorsements, etc., are bonuses for his victory and hard work.\n\n\"They're a huge help for me but right now, I haven't thought about it yet,\" said Yulo as he repeatedly acknowledged the full support from gymnastics association president Cynthia Carrion-Norton and to his partner, Chloe San Jose.\n\n\"They'll be only bonus for me, to have such big money or house,\" he said. \"But of course, God gave them to me and I'm ready to accept it. I'm super grateful for the talent and opportunity.\"\n\nYulo scored 15.000 points to rule his pet floor exercise for the country's first gymnastics gold and second in the Olympics after Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo won in weightlifting in Tokyo 2020.\n\nArtem Dorgoplyat, who won for Israel its first Olympic gymnastics gold in Tokyo, settled for silver this time with 14.966, while Great Britain's Jaka Jarman, whose mother is from Cebu and who Yulo considers as his toughest opponent in the event, clinched bronze with 14.933.\n\nYulo was excellent with his routine, but he admitted he wasn't.\n\n\"My routine, especially on my first pass, I almost fell. I was so nervous,\" he said. \"But when I stood up, I was calm and there was one more difficult one, which was my second pass, I was focused and when I stood up, I was like 'I can do this..\"\n\nHe added: \"I tried to stick with all my landings until the end, but I thought my movement was a bit messy.\n\nWinning gold was far from his mind despite being on the hot seat from his turn at No. 3 to the end of the apparatus.\n\n\"I thought I would not reach 15. When I saw it, I was like, wow!\" he said.\n\nThen he cried almost sprawled on the floor.\n\nYulo was set to compete in the vault final on Sunday afternoon -- he's also a favorite to win the {"uri": "8258473494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "10:08:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T10:08:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T10:08:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/04/house-rewards-p3m-to-yulo-for-olympic-gold-medal-win", "title": "House rewards P3M to Yulo for Olympic gold medal win", "body": "On top of a slew of rewards, including a P24-million condo in McKinley Hill, Taguig City, Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo will receive a P3 million from the House of Representatives for his spectacular performance in the men's floor exercise on Saturday at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, bagging the Philippines' first-ever Olympic medal in gymnastics.\n\nSpeaker Martin Romualdez announced Sunday that the House will reward Yulo in recognition of his \"sheer hard work and unmatched talent,\" which led his way on the global stage, competing with the giants.\n\n\"Today, we celebrate a monumental achievement that resonates deeply with every Filipino heart. Carlos Edriel Yulo has not only soared to the pinnacle of athletic excellence but has also emerged as a sports hero and national treasure, igniting a beacon of hope and inspiration for all Filipinos,\" Romualdez declared.\n\nHe added that Yulo's sensational triumph at the Olympic Games in Paris has brought immense pride and honor to the Philippines.\n\n\"His tireless commitment to his sport, his relentless pursuit of excellence, and his ability to rise above challenges make him a true embodiment of the Filipino spirit. His achievements remind us all of the heights we can reach with perseverance and hard work.\"\n\nThe 24-year-old Yulo made history by becoming the first Filipino male to win a medal in Olympic gymnastics -- and it was gold!\n\nYulo flawlessly executed his routine scoring 15.000 points, outperforming Tokyo 2020 champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by merely 0.034 points, and Great Britain's Jake Jarman -- a half-blooded Filipino.\n\nDolgopyat took home the silver medal with 14.966 points, while Jarman scoring 14.933 points captured the bronze.\n\nThe Filipino gymnast, who placed 11th in the Tokyo Olympics three years ago, where everyone expected him to win, delivered a flawless routine this time, culminating in a perfectly executed three-and-a-half twist dismount that earned him a score of 15.000 -- and the gold.\n\nThe Philippine pride's score is the highest by any gymnast in the floor exercise in the 2024 Olympics.\n\nYulo's gold medal is the second top prize won by the Philippines three years after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz clinched the gold medal at the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nYulo will be conferred a congressional medal for his exceptional victory and contribution to Philippine sports, according to Romualdez, deeming the Olympic gold medalist a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure.\"\n\nApart from the P3 million for gold medalists, the House also pledge P2 {"uri": "2024-08-443895985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:53:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:53:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:53:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578332/yulos-gold-caps-decade-of-struggle", "title": "Carlos Yulo's gold caps decade of struggle", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Carlos Yulo zoomed in on the features of the Olympic gold medal he was tightly clutching, as he was extra motivated by Hidilyn Diaz's kind gesture of letting him hold that precious piece of metal back in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nYulo won't be green with envy anymore after earning his own gold in the ongoing Paris Olympics on Saturday night in a sequence filled with anticipation from a homeland awaiting its next hero after Diaz.\n\nREAD: Gymnast Carlos Yulo gives PH its second Olympic gold\n\nAnd as in the case of Diaz, who gifted the Philippines its first triumph in the Olympics, Yulo's gold medal from the floor exercise was the by-product of more than a decade of struggle for perfection.\n\n\"It's really overwhelming to have this experience. I always say experience, experience and there's no problem there, but this is the one that will leave a mark in my heart and the whole Philippines,\" Yulo told One Sports after the awarding ceremonies where the country's national anthem blared loud and proud.\n\n\"This isn't the perfect competition, but this is the perfect moment for me.\"\n\nThe 24-year-old from Leveriza, Manila, was a curious onlooker during national team practices at nearby Rizal Memorial Sports Complex, and he needed a push from his grandfather, Rodrigo Frisco, who saw a spritely 7-year-old acrobatically throwing himself into the air at a playground back home.\n\nIt was Frisco who brought him for formal training to the Gymnastics Association of the Philippines (GAP) training facility a very short time later.\n\nYulo's baptism of fire came in local tournaments a year later before participating in his first Palarong Pambansa in 2009 held in Tacloban City, Leyte, where he was part of the triumphant gold-winning National Capital Region team in boys' artistic gymnastics.\n\nHe netted his first medal -- a silver -- in the floor exercise, but wound up fifth in the all-around event, prompting the skinny 9-year-old kid to train harder for the next Palarong Pambansa.\n\nWith the full support of his parents Mark Andrew and Angelica Yulo and continuous training at the GAP facility, Yulo captured the gold medal in the individual all-around and floor exercise during the 2010 Palarong Pambansa in Tarlac City where he also claimed a bronze in the vault.\n\nYulo just kept on getting better each year, finally winning the vault as well as the floor exercise and all-around in the 2011 edition of the Palarong Pambansa in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte.\n\nHe followed it up by dominating the Philippine National Games in the same year with golds in the floor exercise, rings and parallel bars.\n\nMove to Japan\n\nStockpiling medals in succeeding Palaro editions, Yulo was ready to take on a bigger challenge in the international level. With coach Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda guiding him, he seized gold medals in the floor exercise and parallel bars in the 2014 Asean School Games.\n\nWhen Yulo participated in the International Junior Competition in Yokohama, Japan, in 2015, his bronze performance in the vault behind Youth Olympic medalists Giarnni Regini-Moran and Yue Ma attracted attention, earning him a scholarship from the International Gymnastics Federation.\n\nWith serious financial backing from the Philippine Sports Commission and the MVP Sports Foundation, Yulo made his move to Japan in 2016 where he was coached by Munehiro Kugimiya, which came with the blessings of the GAP headed by Cynthia Carrion.\n\nThe Japan Olympic Association offered Yulo to train in Japan where he eventually graduated in 2022 with an associate degree in literature at Teikyo University in Itabashi, Tokyo.\n\nIn the 2018 Melbourne World Cup, the Filipino dynamo achieved his first podium performance on a global stage, claiming a bronze medal in the vault.\n\nHe followed it up with a silver in the same event in the Baku World Cup and added another silver in the floor exercise of the Doha World Cup, earning Yulo three medals in the worlds in a span of a month.\n\nInspiration to siblings\n\nThe World Championship in Doha, Qatar, that same year put Yulo level with the world's best after snaring a bronze medal in the floor exercise.\n\nBut it was Yulo's victory in the same discipline in the 2019 World Championships in Stuttgart, Germany that finally installed him as a global force in the sport.\n\nFrom thereon, winning medals for Yulo has turned into an anticipated occasion for the Philippines, especially in the Southeast Asian Games beginning in 2019 in Manila as well his annual stints in the Asian championships.\n\nAt this point, Yulo inspired his younger siblings Karl Jahrel Eldrew and Elaiza to pick up gymnastics. Joriel, his older sister, was a performer of the National University Pep Squad.\n\nParis gold\n\nYulo eventually became a two-time world champion after bagging the gold medal in the vault in the 2021 World Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan, where he also landed a silver in the parallel bars.\n\nBut Yulo's initial journey to the Olympics in Tokyo back in 2021 didn't end well, missing the final in most of his events, except for the vault where he ended up fourth.\n\nOver the next three years, Yulo continued to frolic on the Asian medal stands. He claimed a silver in the vault and a bronze in the floor exercise during the 2022 World Championships in Liverpool, England.\n\nHounded by issues about his split with Kugimiya last year and setting up camp in Manila, Yulo simply brushed the controversy aside and made the Paris Olympics gold a top priority with a sense of urgency.", "source": {"uri": "sports.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "june_navarro@sports.inquirer.net", "name": "June Navarro", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Yulo", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Carlos Yulo"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palarong_Pambansa", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Palarong Pambansa"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_(gymnastics)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Floor (gymnastics)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gold"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-08-443888340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:31:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:31:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:31:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578342/marcos-on-yulos-win-weve-witnessed-history", "title": "Marcos on Yulo's win: 'We've witnessed history'", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., first lady Liza Araneta-Marcos and lawmakers paid tribute to Carlos Edriel Yulo for winning the country's second gold and the first gymnastics medal in the Olympics on Saturday.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the President said in a Facebook post. \"I am confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nOn Sunday, the President was all out in expressing his delight over Yulo's victory.\n\nREAD: Carlos Yulo bags second gold medal, rules vault in Paris Olympics\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he said.\n\nThe first lady also took to social media to congratulate Yulo.\n\n\"Got goosebumps as 'Lupang Hinirang' played at the arena! We are so proud of you!\" she said, referring to the national anthem which was played during the men's artistic gymnastics medal ceremony.\n\nYulo, 24, perfectly executed his routine, ending with a sure-footed landing to score 15.000 points.\n\nHe said earlier that he was \"shooting for the stars\" in Paris. But his acrobatic and technically difficult routine proved a hit.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God,\" said Yulo, who competed in the vault final as of this writing. \"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\"\n\nCash awards, pledges\n\nSpeaker Martin Romualdez on Sunday hailed Yulo as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\" whose victory \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people.\"\n\nRomualdez said the House of Representatives will give Yulo P3 million, as pledged by the Speaker's fellow lawmakers, and also confer on him a congressional medal.\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" Romualdez said.\n\nYulo is also due to receive from the Philippine Sports Commission a P10 million incentive, in accordance with Republic Act No. 10699 or the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act, as well as an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor.\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Bambol Tolentino had also pledged to reward each Olympic winner with a house and lot.\n\nFrom the private sector, property developer Megaworld Corp. said it would award Yulo a fully furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24 million in McKinley Hill, Taguig City.\n\nOther pledges as of this writing include P100,000 worth of furniture from Apollo Home Depot in Cagayan de Oro and a lifetime of free food from several restaurants including Vikings and Tipsy Pig, among others.\n\nHigh hopes for Villegas\n\nRomualdez also cited flyweight boxer and fellow Taclobanon Aira Villegas, who advanced to the quarterfinals on Saturday after winning by split decision over Wassila Lkhadiri of host country France.\n\n\"With her tenacity and talent, Aira still has a chance to bring home either a silver or gold medal. Tacloban City and the entire country are cheering on her every step of the way,\" the Speaker said.\n\nSenators also praised Yulo, with Sen. Sherwin Gatchalian saying that his \"historic win brings a special moment of pride for our country and proves that the Olympic gold is no longer elusive for Filipino athletes.\"\n\n\"Our task as a nation is to ensure that future generations of athletes have all the support they need to succeed [in] the world stage,\" Gatchalian also said, adding that the National Academy of Sports was established precisely \"to hone promising young athletes [so they] can achieve their full potential.\"\n\nSen. Nancy Binay said \"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster.\" -- with reports from Tina G. {"uri": "8259441481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:58:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:58:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:57:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/aug/05/paris-olympics-2024-carlos-yulo-artistic-gymnastics-floor-vault-philippines-gifts-gold", "title": "Mac and cheese for life! Philippines' heartfelt gifts to Carlos Yulo after double Olympic gold", "body": "Pledges of pesos, property and pasta after 'Caloy' makes history for his country with floor exercise and vault victories in artistic gymnastics\n\nFilipino gymnast Carlos Yulo's historic double gold medal win at the Paris Olympics has been celebrated across the Philippines, with businesses showering the athlete in gifts - from cash and a new home, to a lifetime supply of mac and cheese.\n\nFerdinand Marcos, the president, said the Philippines had \"witnessed history\" when Yulo became the first Filipino man to win a gold medal after competing in the artistic gymnastic floor exercise on Saturday. He is only the second Filipino athlete to win an Olympic gold, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz in 2020. On Sunday, Yulo soared to the top of the podium again in the vault, thus becoming the first Filipino to win two golds - and at a single Olympics.\n\n\"No words can express how proud we are of you,\" Marcos said. \"Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you.\"\n\nCarlos was described as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\" by speaker of the lower house, Ferdinand Martin Romualdez. Yulo will be given three million Philippines pesos (\u00a340,500/US$51,890) and a congressional medal, and is due to receive P10m under a law that promises incentives to athletes.\n\nPrivate sector companies, big and small, announced a flurry of gifts, including a fully furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24m in Taguig City, Metro Manila. Yulo was also offered lifetime supplies of free buffets, baked mac and cheese, and chicken inasal, a grilled chicken dish, by various chain restaurants.\n\nA car lights specialist offered him a free set of headlights and fog lights for his vehicle, while a wedding photographer pledged free services to the 24-year-old and another business offered a lifetime supply of phone cases. A Filipino doctor pledged free consultation and endoscopic procedures for Yulo when he turned 45, as well as to any patients in need whom Yulo would like to endorse.\n\nYulo collapsed to the ground in tears when he realised he had secured the gold on Saturday. \"I don't know what to say,\" he said. \"We are a really small country ... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people who supported me.\"\n\nYulo has been offered franchises for a coffee and a lemon drink business, and a P10m brand ambassadorship contract for a beauty clinic, according to company announcements on social media.\n\nThose who share the same name as Yulo are also in luck, as celebrations sweep the country. Cafes and restaurants have offered free meals or milkshakes to anyone named Carlos, Caloy (his nickname) or Edriel (his middle name), while a music venue offered free entry over the weekend to anyone The condominium - which comes with two balconies, a separate maid's room, and a parking slot - will be turned over \"designed and fully furnished.\"\n\nThis is just one of the incentives Yulo will get upon his return to the motherland.\n\nThe government, other private companies, and some brands have already announced rewards for Filipino athletes returning with medals from the Olympics.\n\nUnder Republic Act 10699 or the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act, Olympic gold medalists will be awarded P10 million.\n\nHouse Speaker Martin Romualdez on Monday said Yulo will also be getting at least P6 million from the lower chamber after securing the country two gold medals.\n\nThe Philippine Olympic Committee will also award Yulo with a house and lot. - Rappler.com", {"uri": "8258848062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:09:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:09:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:08:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/04/make-way-for-caloy", "title": "Make way for Caloy", "body": "Carlos Yulo displays winning form in the Paris Olympics.Paul ELLIS/agence france-presse\n\nCarlos Yulo used to roam the streets of Malate district in Manila just like an ordinary kid looking for fun and excitement.\n\nHe started proper gymnastics training when he was seven years old after being discovered at a local park while doing numerous svelte and suave tumbling acts.\n\nSoon after, Yulo, who bagged the gold medal in floor exercise in the Paris Olympics last Saturday, found himself undergoing training at the Gymnastics Association of the Philippine facility at the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex.\n\nSeventeen years after that seemingly uneventful day in 2007, Yulo is about to face a life that has been totally alien to him.\n\nWhile he has already earned a lot from his fruitful stints all over the world, nothing will compare to what he is bound to receive once he sets foot on local soil soon.\n\nApart from the P10 million cash reward that the government will give him as stated in RA 10699 (National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act), the 24-year-old Yulo is also going to be awarded with a P24-million condominium unit from Megaworld.\n\nEven Philippine Olympic Committee president Abraham \"Bambol\" Tolentino has promised a house and lot in Tagaytay City.\n\nThe City of Manila, whose Mayor Honey Lacuna is setting the stage for a grand welcome for the kid from Malate, is giving Yulo a cash reward and other recognition for his sensational showing that gave the Philippines its second Olympic gold medal after lifter Hidilyn Diaz's first in Tokyo 2021.\n\nThe House of Representatives has also pledged to give a P3-million cash reward.\n\nBuffet restaurant chain Vikings has also declared that Yulo will be given the opportunity to feast on their culinary treats for the rest of his life.\n\nWhether Yulo will receive what Diaz had received during her coronation three years ago remains to be seen.\n\nThe Zamboanga strongwoman reportedly got P60 million in total.\n\nBut Yulo's road to Olympic glory, however, wasn't paved.\n\nWhen he was first given the chance at stardom in Tokyo, he flopped big time and failed to podium after a forgettable stint.\n\nLast year, Yulo was forced to go separate ways with his longtime coach Munehiro Kugiyama, who is widely credited for turning him into a world champion in floor in 2019 in Stuttgart, Germany, and in vault in 2021 in Kitakyushu, Japan.\n\nAfter a heartbreaking campaign in the world championships in Belgium last year, things didn't look rosy at all for Yulo as he battled personal issues as well.\n\nBut he gathered himself and put on a mesmerizing performance by winning the golds in the all-around, floor, vault and parallel bars during the Asian championships last May in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.\n\nThat four-gold haul was a sign that he had finally recovered and was primed for redemption.\n\nAt press time, Yulo was bidding to add the vault gold medal.\n\nA victory should make him even more legendary.\n\nBut regardless of what happens, Yulo belongs on the upper echelon of the Philippines' greatest athletes of all time.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.net.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443722805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:11:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:11:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/08/05/2375526/president-marcos-yulo-philippines-stands-proud-you", "title": "President Marcos to Yulo: Philippines stands proud with you", "body": "An electronic billboard congratulates Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo along EDSA in Mandaluyong City yesterday.\n\nMiguel De Guzman\n\nMANILA, Philippines -- President Marcos hailed Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo's gold medal feat at the Paris Olympics, and expressed optimism that the prized athlete would bag more achievements.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics. I am confident that it will not be the last,\" Marcos said in a Facebook post Saturday night.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he added.\n\nFirst Lady Liza Marcos also congratulated Yulo in an Instagram post.\n\n\"Got goosebumps as Lupang Hinirang played at the arena! We are so proud of you!\" she said.\n\nAccording to the official website of the Paris 2024 Olympics, Yulo earned a score of 15.000 after he stuck his three-and-a-half twist dismount cold.\n\nIsrael's Artem Dolgopyat won silver with a score of 14.966 while Great Britain's Jake Jarman bagged bronze after scoring 14.933.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" Yulo was quoted by olympics.com as saying.\n\n\"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well,\" he added.\n\nYulo's victory allowed him to give the Philippines its second Olympic gold medal.\n\nIn 2021, Hidilyn Diaz made history after winning the country's first Olympic gold medal in 97 years during the women's 55 kg weightlifting event in Tokyo.", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Philstar.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alexis_romero@philstar.com", "name": "Alexis Romero", "type": {"uri": "8258242826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "06:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T06:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T06:18:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sports/i-dedicate-this-to-the-filipino-people-yulo-after-winning-historic-olympic-gold", "title": "'I dedicate this to the Filipino people': Yulo after winning historic Olympic gold", "body": "Carlos Edriel Yulo, who produced a spectacular performance to win the men's floor exercise final at the Paris Games on Saturday, earning Philippines their first Olympic medal in gymnastics, said that he dedicates the medal to the Filipino people.\n\nYulo's gold medal is also only the second-ever top prize won by the Philippines across both the Summer and Winter Games, and the first in the men's category. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz struck gold in Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"I don't know what to say,\" the 24-year-old, who just missed the podium at the Tokyo 2020 Games, said.\n\n\"We are a really small country... So to be able to get a gold medal for us is big for us, huge. I dedicate this to the Filipino people also who supported me.\"\n\nSticking most of his landings, Yulo punched the air with both fists after he finished his powerful, clean routine. He scored 15.000 points, edging out Tokyo champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by just 0.034 of a point.\n\nTop qualifier Jake Jarman of Britain settled for third, just 0.067 of a point adrift of the gold medal spot after committing small landing errors on his tumbles.\n\nWhen the final score flashed on the big screen at Bercy Arena, Yulo, overcome with emotion, covered his face with his hands as {"uri": "8257791503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "19:17:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T19:17:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T19:16:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/8/3/hidilyn-diaz-leads-celebration-as-filipinos-go-frenzy-over-yulo-s-historic-gold", "title": "Hidilyn Diaz leads celebration as Filipinos go into frenzy over Yulo's historic gold", "body": "It was already late at night when Carlos Yulo delivered the country's first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics, but the entire nation was very much awake and alive in social media as Filipinos were as ecstatic, shocked and emotional after the momentous win.\n\nIt was already late at night when Carlos Yulo delivered the country's first gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics, but the entire nation was very much awake and alive in social media as Filipinos were as ecstatic, shocked and emotional after the momentous win.\n\nThe Filipinos on social media platforms X (formerly Twitter), Facebook and Instagram erupted as \"Caloy Yulo\", \"Lupang Hinirang\" and \"Laban Pilipinas\" immediately made the top Philippine trends just moments after Yulo topped the floor exercise final in the men's artistic gymnastics.\n\nOf course, leading the congratulatory messages is the country's first ever gold medalist in the Olympics, who took to her Instagram story to congratulate Yulo.\n\n\"Yehey! {"uri": "8259566458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:48:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:48:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:47:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2024/08/05/carlos-yulo-silences-doubters-pushes-past-struggles-in-historic-feat", "title": "Carlos Yulo silences doubters, pushes past 'struggles' in historic feat", "body": "MANILA: Carlos Yulo (pic) brought immense honour and pride to the Philippines by winning back-to-back Olympic gold medals in Paris after years of hard work and sacrifice all the while overcoming his personal battles.\n\nMore than competing against the top gymnasts in the world, Yulo had his battles off the mat, surrounding his world-class talent with doubts when his first Olympic stint in Tokyo three years ago didn't end well coupled with his decision to part ways with longtime Japanese coach Munehiro Kugimiya and bring back his childhood mentor Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda.\n\nBut against all odds, the 24-year-old Yulo immortalised himself in the Olympic history books with a masterful performance in the vault final to add to his floor exercise gold in just 24 hours.\n\nYulo became the only Filipino to win a pair of Olympic championships and the first to win multiple medals in one Summer Games since 1924.\n\n\"All the struggles that brought me down, all the people who didn't believe in me and put me down -- this is for those who truly believed in me,\" Yulo told Olympic broadcaster One Sports, offering his second gold medal to the country through the lens of the camera.\n\nThose challenges, including his gruelling Olympic buildup capped by a camp in Metz, brought Yulo all the way up from a failed Tokyo Games stint to a two-time champion in Paris.\n\n\"It's one of the challenges given to me by the Lord, and I know He gave it to me because He knows I can overcome it. I'm super thankful for the challenges He gave me; I draw strength from Him,\" said the Filipino dynamo.\n\n\"I've learned a lot about myself -- to adjust, to be content with what I have, and of course, to stay humble in what I do and in my personality.\"\n\nLess than 24 hours after ruling the floor exercise with a gold medal-clinching 15.000 points, Yulo admitted he lacked sleep but he came to the vault final, relaxed with nothing to lose and all out.\n\nThat's why Yulo found it hard to wrap his head around what had just transpired following a spellbinding first vault that earned a score of 15.433 -- one of only two routines with a 6.000 difficulty -- and executing a Kasamatsu double twist in his second for 14.800 to finish with an average of 15.116.\n\nYulo's double feat single-handedly fulfilled the Team Philippines' goal to eclipse its previous campaign in Tokyo where the country won its breakthrough gold courtesy of weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz. - Philippine Daily INQUIRER FILES]\n\nSpeaker Ferdinand Martin Romualdez said Monday that Yulo's successive victories at the 2024 Paris Olympics - a gold in the men's artistic gymnastics final on Saturday night and another gold during the men's vault finals on Sunday night - shows the potential of the country's athletes.\n\n\"Caloy's achievements have not only brought glory to the Philippines but have also highlighted the potential of our athletes to excel in the international arena,\" he said.\n\n\"We will continue to support and invest in our sports programs to nurture and develop more world-class athletes like Caloy. His success is a shining example of hope and a source of inspiration for all of us,\" he added.\n\nREAD: Gymnast Carlos Yulo gives PH its second Olympic gold\n\nRomualdez also called Yulo a \"once-in-a-century athlete\" after his double gold at Paris, as this marked only the second and third time that the Philippines got the top spot at the Olympics after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz's victory in Tokyo in 2021.\n\n\"Carlos Edriel Yulo has proven himself to be a once-in-a-century Filipino athlete. Medenilla", "body": "AFTER Carlos Yulo won the gold medal in gymnastics, President Marcos is convinced more members of the Philippine team at the 2024 Paris Olympics can achieve the same feat.\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippine's first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the chief executive said in a brief social media post.\n\n\"I am confident that will not be the last,\" he added.\n\nHe joined the many Filipinos, who congratulated Yulo for winning the country's second gold medal at the Olympics last Saturday.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud of you!,\" Marcos said.\n\nWeightlifter Hidiliyn Diaz became the first Filipino to win an Olympic gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.\n\nMeanwhile, the leadership of the House of Representatives on Sunday hailed champion gymnast Carlos Yulo as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\" for his winning the gold medal in the men's final floor exercise at the Paris Olympics, and promised P3 million in cash incentives and a congressional medal.\n\nSpeaker Ferdinand Martin G. Romualdez and House Committee on Appropriations Chairman Zaldy Co said Yulo's historic victory, marking the Philippines' first-ever Olympic medal in gymnastics and only the second gold medal since joining the Summer Games 100 years ago, \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people.\"\n\nEarlier, the House leadership extended financial assistance to 22 Filipino athletes participating in the Paris Olympics. Romualdez also initiated a fundraising campaign among his House colleagues to provide additional cash incentives to Yulo.\n\n\"Today, we celebrate a monumental achievement that resonates deeply with every Filipino heart. Carlos Edriel Yulo has not only soared to the pinnacle of athletic excellence but has also emerged as a sports hero and national treasure, igniting a beacon of hope and inspiration for all Filipinos,\" Speaker Romualdez declared.\n\nThe House has pledged P3 million for gold medalists, P2 million for silver medalists, and P1 million for bronze medalists.\n\nFilipina boxer Aira Villegas, who hails from Romualdez's home turf in Tacloban City, is already assured of at least a bronze medal after winning against France's Wassila Lkhadiri in the women's 50 kg quarterfinals.\n\n\"With her tenacity and talent, Aira still has a chance to bring home either a silver or gold medal. {"uri": "8259356726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:23:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2024/08/05/marcos-on-yulos-win-weve-witnessed-history", "title": "Marcos on Yulo's win: 'We've witnessed history'", "body": "MANILA: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, first lady Liza Araneta-Marcos and lawmakers paid tribute to Carlos Edriel Yulo for winning the country's second gold and the first gymnastics medal in the Olympics on Saturday (Aug 3).\n\n\"We've witnessed history as Carlos Yulo clinched the Philippines' first gold medal in artistic gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics,\" the President said in a Facebook post.\n\n\"I am confident that it will not be the last.\"\n\nOn Sunday, the President was all out in expressing his delight over Yulo's victory.\n\n\"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\" he said.\n\nThe first lady also took to social media to congratulate Yulo.\n\n\"Got goosebumps as 'Lupang Hinirang' played at the arena! We are so proud of you!\" she said, referring to the national anthem which was played during the men's artistic gymnastics medal ceremony.\n\nYulo, 24, perfectly executed his routine, ending with a sure-footed landing to score 15.000 points.\n\nHe said earlier that he was \"shooting for the stars\" in Paris. But his acrobatic and technically difficult routine proved a hit.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God,\" said Yulo, who competed in the vault final as of this writing.\n\n\"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\"\n\nSpeaker Martin Romualdez on Sunday hailed Yulo as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\" whose victory \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people.\"\n\nRomualdez said the House of Representatives will give Yulo P3 million, as pledged by the Speaker's fellow lawmakers, and also confer on him a congressional medal.\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" Romualdez said.\n\nYulo is also due to receive from the Philippine Sports Commission a P10 million incentive, in accordance with Republic Act No. 10699 or the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act, as well as an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor.\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Bambol Tolentino had also pledged to reward each Olympic winner with a house and lot.\n\nFrom the private sector, property developer Megaworld Corp. said it would award Yulo a fully furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24 million in McKinley Hill, Taguig City.\n\nOther pledges as of this writing include P100,000 worth of furniture from Apollo Home Depot in Cagayan de Oro and a lifetime of free food from several restaurants including Vikings and Tipsy Pig, among others.\n\nRomualdez also cited flyweight boxer and fellow Taclobanon Aira Villegas, who advanced to the quarterfinals on Saturday after winning by split decision over Wassila Lkhadiri of host country France.\n\n\"With her tenacity and talent, Aira still has a chance to bring home either a silver or gold medal. Tacloban City and the entire country are cheering on her every step of the way,\" the Speaker said.\n\nSenators also praised Yulo, with Sen Sherwin Gatchalian saying that his \"historic win brings a special moment of pride for our country and proves that the Olympic gold is no longer elusive for Filipino athletes.\"\n\n\"Our task as a nation is to ensure that future generations of athletes have all the support they need to succeed [in] the world stage,\" Gatchalian also said, adding that the National Academy of Sports was established precisely \"to hone promising young athletes [so they] can achieve their full potential.\"\n\nSen Nancy Binay said \"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster.\" -- Philippine {"uri": "8257860669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "20:44:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T20:44:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T20:43:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/olympic-moment-of-the-day-philippines-carlos-edriel-yulo-gets-his-nation-a-historic-gold/article_37abc660-f9f4-5fa9-b671-44d5185028ce.html", "title": "Olympic moment of the day: Philippines' Carlos Edriel Yulo gets his nation a historic gold - and himself a new house", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Carlos Edriel Yulo might have only been an inch or two taller than his rivals when he stood in the center of the podium Saturday afternoon, but he had just accomplished something that put him head and shoulders above any man from his nation who'd ever competed at the Olympics.\n\nWith his victory in the men's floor exercise final, Yulo on Saturday became the first Filipino man ever to win an Olympic gold medal, the first Filipino to win any medal in gymnastics and the second Filipino to ever win a gold medal.\n\n\"We are a really small country and the portion of athletes is not the same as the US or UK, so to be able to get a gold medal is really big for us,\" he said after. \"I dedicate this to the Filipinos who supported me. I'm really grateful to them. I want to say thank you for watching and praying for me throughout the competition.\"\n\nAnd while the six-time world champion has made a lot of history for his country, it still seemed like long odds for the Manila native to be standing on that center podium with gold around his neck.\n\nJust before the 2023 World Championships, Yulo and his longtime coach Munehiro Kugiyama decided to part ways. Since then, Yulo has worked without a coach and instead has bounced around the world to train with some of the best athletes in his sport. When he's not traveling, he's returned to Manila - a move he's credited with making him feel more connected with his Filipino teammates.\n\nBut those teammates were not on the floor with him on Saturday. Instead it was just the 24-year-old, flipping, twisting and soaring above the floor at the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nHe hardly put a foot wrong from the start, his powerful strides making him appear to glide across the mat and then his explosive twists and flips made it seem like he was a threat to simply burst through the roof and ascend into the clouds.\n\nIt was a tone-setting performance that the rest of the field simply could not match. But Yulo was still forced to sit as performer after performer took to the floor, trying to knock him off the top of the leaderboard.\n\nBut each failed. His score of 15.000 was enough. And the moment hit him like a ton of bricks.\n\nHugely emotional in the moments after winning, Yulo let out an almighty roar and broke into tears. He pumped his fists and, despite that history-making pedigree, looked completely overwhelmed by what he had just done.\n\nThat didn't change when he took to the podium to receive the first gold medal ever put around a Filipino man's neck.\n\nWith the medal hanging above his chest - it's reportedly very heavy thanks to the piece of the Eiffel Tower that is inlaid in every medal at these Games - Yulo raised his hands above his head in triumph. But his eyes were still full of disbelief, and he looked at his medal like it might be taken away from him at any moment.\n\nOh, and he'll get a house from the government for his achievement. Not a bad Saturday.\n\n\"I know that already (that I am going to get a house). But this (pointing at his gold medal) is what really matters to me. My hard work and the people who really helped me. My success is also their success,\" he said. \"I'm so grateful for this experience and to be able to compete in this competition. I am happy that I won a gold medal and also a house.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kyle_feldscher@ktbs.com", "name": "Kyle Feldscher", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8259052266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:07:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:07:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:05:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/paris-olympics/314480500/legendary.html", "title": "LEGENDARY! - Manila Standard", "body": "PARIS (Via PLDT Home) - The Philippines had one gold medal in the Olympics in 97 years.\n\nThree years later, it had two in two days.\n\nOh Carlos Yulo! Look at how you spoil us with your greatness.\n\nAfter being crowned the previous day as floor exercise champion, Yulo put the exclamation point to his intoxicating 2024 Paris Olympics' campaign with yet another flawless routine, this time in the vault, to claim his second gold and put sports-loving Filipinos back home in a state of delirium.\n\nAlready a history maker as the Philippines' first male Olympic champion, and first in his sport, the gymnastics sensation capped off his extraordinary stint with yet another historic victory as he averaged a stellar 15.116 points to secure the top spot in the competition.\n\nYulo's exceptional performance, highlighted by a 15.433-point score on his first vault, solidified his status as the Philippines' newest sporting icon, joining the likes of the country's first Olympic champion Hidilyn Diaz and and eight-division world titlist Manny Pacquiao in the pantheon of all-time greats.\n\nEarlier in the day, President Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. congratulated Yulo for his first gold medal.\n\n\"I am confident that it will not be the last,\" the President said.\n\nHours later, His prediction became a reality.\n\nIn a separate post, First Lady Liza Marcos also congratulated Yulo for giving the Philippines' first gold finish in this year's global tournament.\n\n\"Congratulations, Carlos Yulo!\" she said.\n\n\"Got goosebumps as Lupang Hinirang played at the arena!,\" she said.\n\n\"We are so proud of you!\" she said.\n\nHouse Speaker Martin Romualdez said Yulo \"earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent.\"\n\n\"We celebrate Caloy's outstanding contribution and his role as an inspiration to future generations of athletes. He is not just a champion; he is our sports hero and national treasure whose legacy will inspire countless young Filipinos,\" Romualdez said.\n\nYulo will also be conferred a congressional medal for his exceptional achievement and contribution to Philippine sports.\n\n\"Answered prayers. We already broke the record in the Olympics,\" said Philippine Olympic Committee president Abraham Tolentino of the country's 2 golds in the games, eclipsing the 1 gold-2 silver-1 bronze finish of the delegation in the Tokyo Olympics. Boxing is already assured of two bronze here, too.\n\nArtur Davtyan of Armenia, the Tokyo 2020 silver medallist, remained the runner-up with his 14.966, while Great Britain's Harry Hepworth, just 20 years old in his first Olympiad, bagged the bronze on 14.949.\n\nThe win marked a remarkable redemption story for Yulo, who finished fourth in the same event at the Tokyo games.\n\nLife in the Philippines as an athlete will be totally different now for 24-year-old Yulo, who with his floor exercise gold stands to earn somewhere in the vicinity of P35 million or more (the cash windfall Diaz received for her Olympic gold), including a BGC condo. Now multiply that by two.\n\nMeanwhile, Nesthy Petecio guaranteed herself a second Olympic medal - the color of which will still be determined - after advancing to the semifinals of the women's 57kg division after a dominant 5-0 victory over China's Xu Zichun at the North Paris Arena.\n\nThe 32-year-old Petecio, the Tokyo Olympics silver medalist, secured another unanimous decision win, showcasing her superior boxing skills throughout the match.\n\nHer powerful left hook proved to be a decisive weapon, consistently landing on Xu's head.\n\nWith this victory, Petecio joins an elite group of Filipino athletes who have earned multiple Olympic medals.\n\nNow, with a guaranteed bronze, all eyes are on Petecio as she aims to upgrade her medal color when she takes on Poland's Julia Szeremeta on August 7 at 7:46 p.m.", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", {"uri": "8259617257", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:25:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:25:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:24:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/cash-condo-ramen-philippine-double-070020239.html", "title": "Cash, condo and ramen for Philippine double gold gymnast", "body": "Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo won his second Olympic gold medal in two days, becoming only the second athlete to take home the Games' top prize for his country.\n\nA two-bedroom condo, thousands of dollars and a lifetime of free ramen are among the flurry of gifts that the government and local brands have pledged to reward the 24-year-old with for his historic wins in the men's floor exercise and vault events.\n\nMr Yulo's feat has also made him the country's latest social media sensation.\n\n\"Another gold for the Philippines! History is made again! Ang galing galing mo! [You are incredible!]\" wrote a user on X.\n\nMr Yulo scored an average of 15.116 on the vault on Sunday, ahead of Armenia's Artur Davtyan (14.966) and Britain's Harry Hepworth (14.949).\n\nHe punched his arms into the air and embraced fellow athletes on hearing his score. He went into the competition without high expectations, he had told reporters.\n\n\"I was just hoping to perform well. I didn't really expect a medal,\" Mr Yulo had said.\n\n\"It really felt like a bonus for me. It's crazy, because last night I couldn't sleep. I was so hyped because I had won that gold medal [the day before].\n\nBarely 24 hours ago, Mr Yulo had scooped the gold for the men's floor exercise with 15 points, edging out Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by just 0.034 of a point. Mr Dolgopyat had been the defending Olympic champion and world title holder.\n\nMr Yulo's double gold feat is now the most discussed topic on X, formerly known as Twitter, in the Philippines.\n\n\"It took 100 years for us to hear Lupang Hinirang [the Philippines' national anthem] two nights in a row while the world is watching. Thank you so much for the pride and historic moment!\" wrote an X user.\n\nA century has passed since the Philippines' debut in the Olympics in 1924. Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz earned the country's first Olympic gold medal in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nPhilippine celebrities and public figures, including president Ferdinand Marcos Jr and First Lady Liza Araneta-Marcos, also congratulated Mr Yulo.\n\n\"No words can express how proud we are of you, Caloy. You have achieved GOLD for the Philippines not once, but twice! Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you,\" Mr Marcos wrote on Facebook.\n\nThe Philippine government will hand the gymnast 10 million Philippine pesos ($173,300; \u00a3135,400) - a reward promised to any gold medalists - while a real estate firm has promised him a fully furnished two-bedroom unit at McKinley Hill, the largest condominium development in metropolitan Manila.\n\nThe House of Representatives has pledged to give Mr Yulo an additional 6 million pesos in cash incentives, with speaker of the lower house, Ferdinand Martin Romualdez, describing him as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\".\n\nEven medical clinics and universities have rolled out the red carpet for the national hero - a gastroenterologist have offered Mr Yulo free consultations and colonoscopies for life while the University of Mindanao has pledged free university credits.\n\nAlso awaiting him are lifetime supplies of ramen, mac and cheese and grilled chicken offered by various restaurant chains.\n\nMeanwhile, the capital city Manila, where Mr Yulo was born and raised, is preparing a \"hero's welcome\" for him.\n\n\"The grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians. When we meet him, we will present Carlos Yulo cash incentives, awards and symbols of the eternal gratitude of the proud capital city of the Philippines,\" the city's mayor, Honey Lacuna, said.", He is the second Filipino athlete to bring home a gold medal after Hidilyn Diaz in 2020.\n\nOn his X (formerly Twitter) page, Vice Ganda said Yulo will be granted a \"free entrance\" at the Vice Comedy Club in Quezon City for his win.\n\n\"Congratulations Carlos Yulo for bagging the Gold in Men\"s Floor Exercise!!!!!! Maria congratulated Yulo for representing the Philippines at the Olympics.\n\n\"Waaaah! Ginto para sa Pilipinas! Congratulations at maraming salamat (Gold for the Philippines! Congratulations and thank you very much), Carlos Yulo,\" Sta. Maria said.\n\nIn a series of posts, Miss Grand International 2020 first runner-up Samantha Bernardo praised Yulo for bringing glory to the country.\n\n\"Wow [gold] again for Philippines! He let his nerves get to him, and it felt like the biggest sporting stage in the World engulfed the 21-year-old Caloy,\" she said.\n\nIn Paris 2024, Caloy comes back to the Olympic stage, so much more mature, level-headed, and steady. It was apparent when he didn't try to do the triple twisties in the qualifying, opting for a safer routine. Yet, he saved that for his final moment on the Floor,\" she further added.\n\nThe official X page of the newly debuted P-pop group New:ID said Yulo's win inspired them to do well in their journey.\n\n\"Congrats to Carlos Yulo @c_edrielzxs for winning gold and making all Filipinos proud! Your hard work and success inspire us in our journey as a P-Pop group. Let's continue to bring pride to the Philippines together,\" they wrote.\n\nWith his historic gold in the Olympics, Yulo is set to receive rewards amounting to millions of pesos from various government institutions and private organizations, such as a P24-million condominium unit promised by a real estate property, and, P10-million from the Philippine Sports Commission under Republic Act 10699 or the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act.", "source": {"uri": "entertainment.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "hannah_mallorca@entertainment.inquirer.net", "name": "Hannah Mallorca", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Yulo", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Carlos Yulo"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_Ganda", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Vice Ganda"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_(gymnastics)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Floor (gymnastics)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_(magazine)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Vice (magazine)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Comedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Philippines"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Philippines"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jodi_Sta._Maria", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jodi Sta. {"uri": "2024-08-443171574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "22:33:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T22:33:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T22:19:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://kuwaittimes.com/article/17400/sports/other-sports/yulo-wins-historic-gymnastics-olympic-gold-for-philippines/", "title": "Yulo wins historic gymnastics Olympic gold for Philippines - kuwaitTimes", "body": "PARIS: Carlos Yulo triumphed on Saturday in the men's floor exercise of the gymnastics in Paris for only the second Olympic gold in the history of the Philippines. The 24-year-old broke down in tears after matching the achievement of weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who won gold at the Covid-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games.\n\n\"I just went for it, I didn't hesitate,\" said Yulo. The former world champion perfectly executed his routine, ending with a sure-footed landing to score 15.000 points. It sealed the first gymnastics Olympic medal ever for the Philippines.\n\nDefending champion and world titleholder Artem Dolgopyat of Zionist entity was pushed into silver with 14.966. \"The past months (in general) were hard. I had some problems with my leg and also the training was difficult,\" said the 27-year-old Dolgopyat.\n\n\"It's a hard time in Israel. I tried to do my best in the competition, to show everyone that Israel is very strong and that we can win medals.\" Britain's Jake Jarman, who had scored highest in qualifying a week ago, achieved 14.933 to take bronze at Bercy Arena.\n\nYulo had warned he was \"shooting for the stars\" in Paris after missing out on the podium in Tokyo. And his acrobatic and technically difficult routine proved a hit, scoring higher than the 14.766 he had garnered in qualifying. \"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" said Yulo, who has a chance of another medal in the vault final on Sunday.\n\n\"He gave me the strength to get through this kind of performance and perform this well.\" China's Xiao Ruoteng, the Tokyo floor bronze medallist, slumped to last in the eight-man final after hopping out of bounds after his opening jump to finish with 13.933.\n\nXiao had been bidding for gold to add to his silver in the men's team event and bronze in the all-around competition at the Paris Games. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "kuwaittimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Kuwait And he stayed there on top after all eight finalists were done, the last flash of the scores sparking a rush of emotion for the Filipino champ.\n\nTears were rolling down his face as his rivals were all over him shortly before the awarding ceremony.\n\nFor the second straight Olympics, the Philippine national anthem was played in the greatest sporting show on earth.\n\nYulo ruled his pet event, with a chance to become an Olympic double-gold winner as he's also vying in the vault final Sunday.\n\nIt would have been a brighter golden Saturday for Team Philippines if not for the sorry split decision loss by 57kg boxer Carlo Paalam to an Australian foe over at the Paris North Arena.\n\nAdding to the joy was EJ Obiena overcoming a faulty start and thundering to the pole vault final at the Stade de France.\n\nThe biggest cheers belonged to Yulo, the newest member of a short list of Filipino Olympic medalists, joining fellow gold winner Diaz (also with a silver), silver winners Anthony Villanueva, Onyok Velasco, Nesthy Petecio and Paalam, and bronze holders Teofilo Yldefonso, Simeon Toribio, Jose Villanueva, Miguel White, Leopoldo Serantes, Roel Velasco and Eumir Marcial.\n\nWith Yulo's feat, the Olympic medal streak of the country continued from Diaz' silver feat in 2016 in Rio to the 1-2-1 gold-silver-bronze breakthrough in 2021 in Tokyo and to these Games where Team Philippines is in a good position to even strike harder, punch stronger and soar higher.\n\nEarly Sunday, Aira Villegas will seek a spot in the women's 50kg semifinals for a sure bronze.\n\nPaalam missed the same in a 2-3 loss to Australian Charlie Senior. The Bukidnon bet would have made history as the first Filipino boxer to collect two Olympic medals if not for the shock fall. With two bronzes was swimmer Yldefonso.\n\nYulo, however, quickly soothed the pain and heartaches felt by the Nationals' on Paalam's loss.\n\nA pocket number of Filipinos inside the grand Paris arena by the River Seine and millions watching on television back in the country celebrated with Yulo as he took his place among the best -- a spot in the pantheon of Filipino sporting greats.\n\nBeating Francisco", "body": "After securing the Philippines' first gold medal at the Paris Olympics, Carlos Yulo is set to be showered with numerous rewards and accolades for his remarkable achievement.\n\nYulo, a 24-year-old Filipino gymnast, executed an almost flawless routine, scoring 15.000 points in the final floor exercises and becoming the country's second Olympic gold medalist, following weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo, who won the first gold three years ago in Tokyo 2020.\n\nIn recognition of his victory, Yulo will be awarded several incentives from both private companies and government entities. Under Republic Act 10699, he will receive P10 million and an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor from the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC), along with additional benefits and discounts.\n\nThe House of Representatives, as stated by House appropriations panel chair Ako Bicol Party list Representative Zaldy Co, will grant P3 million.\n\nThe Philippine Olympic Committee has also pledged to provide Yulo with a house and lot, similar to the gesture made to the four Filipino medalists from Tokyo.\n\nAdditionally, Megaworld Corporation will award Yulo a fully furnished 2-bedroom condominium unit valued at P24 million at McKinley Hill in Bonifacio Global City. This follows the company's previous gesture in 2021, when it presented a fully furnished condominium unit worth P14 million to Diaz after her historic weightlifting win.\n\nMeanwhile, Vikings Luxury Buffet has also offered Yulo a lifetime free buffet.\n\nAs of now, various local businesses and restaurants have extended incentives to Yulo, and it is anticipated that he will receive even more It sealed the first gymnastics Olympic medal ever for the Philippines.\n\nDefending champion and world titleholder Artem Dolgopyat of Israel was pushed into silver with 14.966.\n\n\"The past months (in general) were hard. You have achieved GOLD for the Philippines not once, but twice!,\" Marcos said.\n\n\"Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you.\"\n\n\"Aming ipagmamalaki ang tagumpay mong nagniningning! {"uri": "8257762780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "18:42:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T18:42:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T18:41:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/sports/othersports/915831/carlos-yulo-thrilled-to-grant-ph-s-wish-a-second-olympic-gold-medal/story/", "title": "Carlos Yulo thrilled to grant PH's wish: a second Olympic gold medal", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Artistic Gymnastics - Men's Floor Exercise Victory Ceremony - August 03, 2024. Gold medallist Carlos Edriel Yulo of Philippines celebrates on the podium. REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli\n\nCarlos Yulo just etched his name into the history books after flaunting a performance to remember in the men's floor finals of the 2024 Paris Olympics to win a historic gold medal on Saturday.\n\nHowever, it was not just a personal dream the Filipino gymnast was able to accomplish as he also fulfilled a holy grail every Filipino is longing for: another Olympic medal.\n\nKnowing the desire of a medal-hungry nation, Yulo made sure to leave everything on the mat.\n\n\"Alam ko maraming pinagdadaanan 'yung mga tao sa Pilipinas and nagho-hope po talaga na manalo tayo ng medalya dito sa Olympics,\" Yulo told the Philippine Olympic Committee media, including GMA Integrated News' JP Soriano, on the heels of his winning moment at the Bercy Arena.\n\n\"Gusto ko lang pong pasalamatan sila sa pagpupuyat, sa pag-take po ng effort na ipagdasal at panoorin kaming mga atletang Pilipino.\"\n\n(I know the people of the Philippines are going through a lot and I really hoped we win a medal here in the Olympics. I want to thank those who watched late at night, for those who prayed for us Philippine athletes.)\n\nYulo made history as the first-ever gymnast to give the Philippines a medal in the Summer Games and emerged as only the second athlete after Hidilyn Diaz to pluck a gold medal at the quadrennial event.\n\nThe 24-year-old bemedalled athlete did so by putting together a stunning 15.000-point outing that allowed him to edge out seven other competitors, which included two fierce athletes in defending gold medalist Artem Dolgopyat of Israel and qualifying round's top performer Jake Jarman of Great Britain.\n\nLooking back, Yulo was just thankful that he decided to continue when the going got tough.\n\nThree years ago, Yulo made his debut in the Tokyo Olympics but failed to step on to the podium.\n\nIn the floor exercise back then, he scored a dismal 13.566 in the qualification round and missed the finals cut despite flourishing in the same event in other international tournaments prior to his Tokyo trip.\n\nHowever, the Malate-born dynamo persevered and three years after, he already has a gold medal hanging around his neck.\n\n\"Sobrang overwhelming po ng experience na 'yun,\" Yulo shared about his gold medal run.\n\n\"Grabe lahat ng paghihirap, 'yung hard work. Sobrang thankful na hindi ako tumigil and grateful din sa Panginoon na binigyan niya ako ng lakas ng loob at pinrotektahan Niya po ako.\"\n\n(That was an overwhelming experience. All those hardships, hard work. I am thankful I did not stop and I'm grateful to God for giving me the strength and protection.)", "source": {"uri": "gmanetwork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GMA Network"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443759436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:12:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:12:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:05:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/opinion/2024/08/05/2375580/editorial-aiming-more-golds", "title": "EDITORIAL  --  Aiming for more golds", "body": "For just the second time in the Olympics, Filipinos are rejoicing over a gold medal. Carlos Yulo, who already brought honors to the country by bagging World Championship golds and other medals in 2019 and 2021, achieved his dream and won a gold medal in floor exercise last Saturday at the Olympic Games in Paris.\n\nThe 24-year-old Yulo follows in the footsteps of weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who in July 2021 at the Summer Games in Tokyo became the first Filipino to win a gold medal since the Philippines joined the Olympics in 1924, which was also held in Paris.\n\nHaving shown the way, Diaz inspired other Filipino athletes to go for the gold. At the Tokyo Games three years ago, Yulo had faltered in his bid for an Olympic gold. Undeterred, he set his sights on Paris. Both Yulo and Diaz have presented similar formulas for the development of Olympians: determination, discipline and rigorous training.\n\nExcellence in sports also requires considerable resources and support to train in a proper environment over a prolonged period, during which an athlete's livelihood or formal schooling may be seriously disrupted. Hidilyn Diaz did not get that kind of support, and her financial struggles even prompted her to publicly seek training sponsorship in 2019. She was tagged by Malaca\u00f1ang as part of a conspiracy to destabilize and oust then president Rodrigo Duterte. But Diaz persisted on her own and trained abroad to propel herself to the top of her game.\n\nEven boxers, who have reaped honors although no Olympic gold so far for the country, typically depend initially on their own resourcefulness in obtaining what they need to advance in their field.\n\nCarlos Yulo's story highlights the importance of starting them young when it comes to athletics. He began honing his gymnastic skills reportedly at age seven, competing for the first time in a tournament when he was just eight years old. Yulo trained in earnest with support from the Gymnastics Association of the Philippines in Manila before moving to Japan in 2016 on a scholarship sponsored by the Japan Olympic Association. Despite the strenuous training, he was able to obtain a degree in literature from Teikyo University.\n\nWith his gold medal, Yulo can expect a P24-million condominium unit and possibly millions more in cash and kind mostly from the private sector. Apart from providing such incentives, the private sector also supports sports development, but athletics can use more resources. From spotting promising talents at an early age and developing their athletic potential, substantial resources and efficient management are needed for sports development. And in less than 24 hours, he won his second gold, dominating the men's artistic gymnastics vault on Sunday, August 4.\n\nFilipinos online were quick to congratulate Yulo, including local stars who expressed their elation on social media.\n\nIn a series of posts on X (formerly Twitter), Vice Ganda applauded Yulo for bringing immense honor and pride to the Philippines. The host-comedian also offered the athlete a complimentary access to his comedy club as a special treat.\n\nBroadway star Lea Salonga extended her congratulations via Instagram Story, writing, \"Congratulations! Mabuhay ka!\"\n\nActress Iza Calzado also congratulated Yulo in her Instagram story, sharing that she got emotional after hearing the national anthem being played at the Olympics. \"Watching you perform, win, and receive this honor truly made us proud. Thank you for inspiring us,\" she said.\n\nOn X, Actress Jodi Sta. Maria expressed her gratitude to Yulo for taking home a gold medal for the Philippines.\n\nDescribing Yulo's win as the \"most incredible news to start the week,\" host Bianca Gonzalez said that the athlete will serve as an inspiration to many Filipinos.\n\nBeauty queen Samantha Bernardo called Yulo's win as a \"dream come true.\" \"Please support our Filipino athletes more,\" she added.\n\nAfter congratulating Yulo, actress Agot Isidro asked if it would be possible if athletes competing in gymnastics, boxing, and weightlifting would now get more sponsorship and funding as compared to more popular sports in the country.\n\nDirector Tonet Jadaone also pointed out that it would be better if politicians and brands would start investing more on athletes when they're still training, instead of just giving prizes when delegates win the Olympics.\n\nIn a long post on X, host and athlete Gretchen Ho reflected on Yulo's previous Olympic experience, recalling his frustration with his performance on the floor exercise at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Despite being a world champion in his favored apparatus, Ho noted that Yulo let his nerves affect him. But, she said, the Paris 2024 Olympics marked a turning point for Yulo.\n\nMeanwhile, celebrities such as Anne Curtis, Rocco Nacino, Gabbi Garcia, Liz Uy, Rodjun Cruz, Bela Padilla, Carla Abellana, Inigo Pascual, Kim Rodriguez, and Dimples Romana left congratulatory messages on Instagram.\n\nYulo will receive an upgraded incentive package from Megaworld Corporation, including a fully furnished three-bedroom condo in McKinley Hill valued at 32 million pesos, along with a cash bonus of three million pesos.\n\nHe will also be awarded a 10 million pesos cash prize from the Philippine government, as stipulated by Republic Act 10699, and 3 million pesos from the House of Representatives. Additionally, he will receive a house and lot from the Philippine Olympic Committee, the Gold Medal of Valor from the Philippine Sports Commission, and various other incentives, including an unlimited
