after winning the floor exercise in the Paris Olympics.Lionel BONAVENTURE/agence france-presse\n\nGymnastics Association of the Philippines president Cynthia Carrion was right on the money when she predicted that Carlos Yulo will win two gold medals in the gymnastics competition of the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn a message from the French capital last week, Carrion boldly predicted that Yulo is capable of winning the gold medals in floor exercise and the vault apparatus, making him the first Filipino to win two gold medals in the Summer Games.\n\nThe 24-year-old lived up to expectations when he ruled the floor exercise -- his pet event -- with a 15.000 score to win the country's first gold medal in Paris.\n\nThe following day he posted 15.116 points to rule the vault apparatus, giving the Filipinos their second gold medal in the Olympics for the first time ever.\n\n\"He'll win one gold medal in floor exercise, preferably two because he also has good chances in vault,\" said the gymnastics chief, beaming with optimism moments after Yulo advanced to the finals of the two events.\n\nCarrion nailed her prediction and Yulo will go home to an adoring nation carrying the brand-new He scored 15.000 points, edging out Tokyo champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by just 0.034 of a point.\n\nTop qualifier Jake Jarman of Britain settled for third, just 0.067 of a point adrift of the gold medal spot after committing small landing errors on his tumbles.\n\nWhen the final score flashed on the big screen at Bercy Arena, Yulo, overcome with emotion, covered his face with his hands as he broke down in tears and collapsed to the ground.\n\nFilipino athletes at the Paris Games have been promised a fully furnished, two-bedroom condominium in Taguig City if they win a gold medal.\n\nYulo said he was grateful for the reward, but that it was secondary to the world title he had just won.\n\n\"It's just a bonus for me. The Armenian won silver, while Britain's Harry Hepworth took the bronze at the Bercy Arena.\n\nYulo nailed his opening Dragulescu vault in the tuck position, taking just a small step backwards and was rewarded by the judges with a huge score of 15.433 points. His second vault earned him 14.800, giving him an average of 15.116 and after the event's final results were announced, Yulo put his hands on his head and exhaled in disbelief, bowing in gratitude before the crowd.\n\n\"Winning yesterday took away all of my stress,\" the elated Filipino told reporters.\n\n\"Today I was more chilled and relaxed. It helped me give it all because there was nothing to lose anymore. And that's what happened. It's so crazy, I don't know what to feel right now.\"\n\n\"The first vault was really good. I was so shocked that I landed it.\"\n\nThe amiable Yulo said he was bracing himself for the hero's welcome he will undoubtedly receive when he returns home.\n\n\"I'm really excited but I know it's also going to be tough for me because it's kind of outside gymnastics,\" he said.\n\n\"Lots of interviews, lot of media but I'm really excited to do that.\n\n\"I'm really blessed and grateful.\" The 24-year-old's Paris exploits also earned him a new home.\n\nFilipino gold medallists at the Paris Games have been promised a fully furnished, two-bedroom condominium in Taguig City.\n\nAsked if he will now get two houses, one for each gold medal, he said: \"I think so but I should really check if that's true.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Algerian teenager Kaylia Nemour conjured up \"the performance of her life\" to become the first African to win an Olympic gymnastics medal with gold on the uneven bars on Sunday.\n\nThe 17-year-old French-born athlete took the title ahead of China's Qiu Qiyuan, who {"uri": "2024-08-443542472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "11:36:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T11:36:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T11:17:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1147427/overwhelmed-carlos-yulo-wins-gold", "title": "Carlos Yulo \"overwhelmed\" after winning historic Philippines gold", "body": "Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo triumphed in the men's floor exercise on Saturday, winning The Philippines' second Olympic gold in history. Yulo's near-flawless final run, featuring a front full into a three-and-a-half twist, garnered 15.000 points to win his country's first gymnastics gold.\n\nDefending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel settled for the silver this time while Great Britain's Jake Jarman took the bronze.\n\nDolgopyat set the pace with 14.966 points. The unfazed Yulo opened with a two-and-a-half twist to front double pike when his turn came. Then, he went into a front double full to front double tuck.\n\nAfter a full-twisting double, a sure-footed landing made it clear he was the contender to watch. When he stuck his final landing, the double world champion punched the air with both fists, let out a huge roar and then saluted the applauding crowd that had leapt to their feet.\n\nWhen the final score flashed on the big screen at Bercy Arena, the 24-year-old broke down in tears after matching the achievement of weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who won the country's first-ever gold at the Covid-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. I'm feeling grateful for having this medal and for God. He protected me, as always,\" said Yulo in disbelief to be the first man to win gold for The Philippines. Yulo, who trained for seven years in Japan due to a lack of opportunities back home, said he hoped his historic win would help the sport grow in his Southeast Asian country.\n\n\"We are a really small country and the portion of athletes is not the same as the US or UK, so to be able to get a gold medal is really big for us,\" the two-time Olympian said after. \"I dedicate this to the Filipinos who supported me. I'm really grateful to them.\"\n\nHe has a chance to earn another medal in the vault final on Sunday. {"uri": "8258399418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "09:00:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T09:00:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T09:00:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/8/4/even-tough-guys-do-cry", "title": "Even tough guys do cry", "body": "PARIS - After weathering several storms in his young life, gymnast Carlos Yulo thought he would be strong enough not to cry anymore or be emotional.\n\nBut the weight of his Olympic triumph - a gold medal at that - was so heavy and overwhelming that he cried unabashedly before a happy crowd on Saturday, Aug. 3 at the Bercy Arena here.\n\n\"It was hard to stop,\" said Yulo, very thankful that he finally savored the sweetness of what could be his greatest triumph of all time bar none.\n\nHe is set to compete in his third and last finals in the Paris Olympics - in vault - on Sunday afternoon, Aug. 4, with Philippine Olympic Committee President Abraham \"Bambol\" Tolentino and Philippine Sports Commission Chairman Dickie Bachmann looking for another wondrous performance from the proud son of Leveriza in Manila.\n\n\"I am so happy. I remembered all the trials in my life and I thanked God that He never let me down\" said Yulo, his eyes still red due to non-stop crying after winning the gold in the floor exercise - his signature event.\n\nIt was in this event where he first shot into international prominence after winning the gold in the World Championships in 2019 in Stuttgart, Germany\n\nRecalling that brilliance, Yulo produced an eye-popping 15.000 score -- thanks to a 6.6 degree of difficulty and 8.400 in execution.\n\nThe marked improvement in the degree of difficulty - from 6.2 to 6.6 - spelled the difference.\n\nUnlike in the all-around where he ended up 12th among 24 finalists, Yulo performed without hesitation this time around.\n\n\"Actually, I adjusted my score in the qualification for me to qualify safely and because it was really stressful for my body as well as for my mind,\" said Yulo. \"On the final, I just went for it and did not hesitate.\"\n\nBut he admitted having some troubled nights before the big moment, saying: \"I was nervous for two days thinking about my performance.\"\n\nIt was evident in his first landing as he almost wobbled after doing a spectacular routine.\n\nBut as soon he got his rhythm everything went into motion perfectly - smooth like silk.\n\nHis routines - 2.5 twist to front double pike and front double full to double front, triple twist side pass, front layout to full front 2.5 twist - were a joy to watch.\n\nEven those inside the massive arena let out a long and wild applause after he ended his magical performance with a 3.5 twist.\n\nWhat made Yulo's win the more impressive was he dethroned Tokyo Games champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel, who tallied 14.966, and Fil-British Jake Jarman who produced 14.933.\n\nJarman was picked heavily to rule the event after topping the prelims with a score of 14.966, but it was Yulo who delivered the most enthralling show, what with his aerial artistry.\n\nYulo's gold medal was second by the country in 100 years of participation or three years since weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz reigned supreme in the Covid-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games.\n\nThis could be a life-changing feat for Yulo as financial rewards are expected to come left and right when he goes home.", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259676755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:08:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:08:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:07:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/8/5/from-leveriza-to-paris-yulo-has-come-a-long-way", "title": "From Leveriza to Paris, Yulo has come a long way", "body": "From the humble stage of the 2009 Palarong Pambansa in Tacloban City, Leyte to the bright lights at the 2024 Paris Olympics in France, gymnast Carlos Yulo has come a long way to become the most decorated Olympian the country has ever produced.\n\nFrom the humble stage of the 2009 Palarong Pambansa in Tacloban City, Leyte to the bright lights at the 2024 Paris Olympics in France, gymnast Carlos Yulo has come a long way to become the most decorated Olympian the country has ever produced.\n\nThe 24-year-old Manila native showed how resiliency, discipline and perseverance from years of hard work paid off by winning two gold medals in the sports' grandest stage.\n\nWhat made his feat electrifying was the fact that he achieved it within 24 hours, winning the floor exercise on Saturday then coming back the following day to rule the vault apparatus in the men's artistic gymnastics.\n\nBut the road to the pinnacle of his career didn't come easy for Yulo, as he overcame trials and tribulations in his personal and professional life.\n\nThat includes a forgettable showing at the pandemic-delayed Tokyo Olympics three years ago, where he failed to qualify in the floor exercise final and missed the podium in vault.\n\nYet the 4-foot-11 diminutive dynamo didn't rush things and instead, slowly got back into track behind the support of people who believed in him.\n\nAnd look where he is now.\n\nLooking back, Yulo was just like any other active kid. When he was young, his grandfather, Rodrigo Frisco, observed how the then seven-year-old Yulo would do cartwheels and tumbles at a local playground, prompting him to bring Carlos to the Gymnastics Association of the Philippines (GAP) facility in Manila.\n\nYulo started competing in 2008 and joined his first Palarong Pambansa in Tacloban the following year -- a multisport event for elementary and high school students across the country. Representing NCR, Yulo was part of the team that won gold, while claiming silver in floor exercise and fifth in individual all-around. Yulo stated later on that these finishes further fueled his desire to train harder.\n\nAnd the rest, they say, is history. Yulo went on to win multiple medals -- from the Palarong Pambansa, to the Philippine National Games and the ASEAN School Games.\n\nYears passed and the demand to intensify his training that would be par to international standard beckons. Japanese coach Munehiro Kugimiya then took Yulo under his wings in 2016, while also accepting a scholarship program in Japan to further bolster his skills.\n\nKugimiya and Yulo made a great pair as the latter notched high honors in multiple apparatuses throughout the years, including in his pet event - vault.\n\nFrom there, Kugimiya honed Yulo to become an elite athlete, making heads turn in the 2018 Doha world championships with a bronze in floor exercise before winning the historic gold in the floor exercise in the 2019 edition in Stuttgart, Germany.\n\nHis feat in Stuttgart also earned him a berth for the Tokyo Olympics -- becoming the first Filipino gymnast to qualify since Ernesto Beren and Norman Henson in the 1968 Mexico edition.\n\nAfter his failed medal bid in the Tokyo Games, Yulo recovered in time to win the 2021 world championship gold in vault and silver in parallel bars. He also won silver in vault and bronze in parallel bars in the 2022 Liverpool edition. In between these, he also collected multiple medals in the Asian Championships, the Southeast Asian Games and the FIG world Cup.\n\nBut their partnership didn't last when Yulo parted ways with Kugimiya in 2023, and continued to train with his new coach Allen Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda, a Cebuano native.\n\nCasta\u00f1eda, GAP chief Cynthia Carrion and her girlfriend Chloe Anjeleigh San Jose escorted Yulo in Paris, giving him morale boosters and a dose of inspiration.\n\nAnd as Yulo, who armed with an even more matured mindset, rewrote the history, surpassing Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo's golden lift in Tokyo as he will bring home two shiny gold medals -- which has a small portion of the famed Eiffel Tower -- from the glitzy Fashion capital of the world.\n\n\"Kailangan mo talagang aralin 'yong sarili mo, hindi lang basta 'yong gymnastics,\" said Yulo. \"Kailangan maging open ka, flexible ka sa buhay, hindi lang talaga sa sports.\"\n\nYulo made every problem, agony and heartbreak count, so he can be ready for the better days when they come. Indeed. Great things happened for those who wait - while continuing their grind.", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443048047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "18:07:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T18:07:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T18:07:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/577986/gymnast-carlos-yulo-gives-ph-its-second-olympic-gold", "title": "Gymnast Carlos Yulo gives PH its second Olympic gold", "body": "PARIS, France -- Twice, Carlos Yulo let out a roar during the floor exercise finals of men's gymnastics in the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe first came after he stuck a cold landing to cap his routine, a primal yell that let the world know he had done exactly what he had come to do late Saturday evening (Manila time) -- produce an almost perfect run that would be the standard to beat for the title.\n\nThe wait that came after was tense, but it seemed only to prolong a forgone conclusion: Filipino greatness was on the global stage once again.\n\nAfter Hidilyn\n\nYulo produced just the second gold of the Philippines in Olympics history, squeaking past a reigning Olympic champion at Bercy Arena, three years after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz's breakthrough in Tokyo.\n\nYulo capped his routine with a front full into a three-and-a-half twist, which was impressive on its own, but then he stuck the landing emphatically to draw a huge applause from the audience, and an approving nod from the judges: the two-time world champion, who submitted a 6.600 difficulty, cleaned up with a near-flawless execution for a 15.000.\n\nIt was the highest floor score in this year's Games and was just .034 better than Israel's Artem Dolgopyat, the gold medalist in Tokyo.\n\nDolgopyat, who submitted a 6.200 difficulty, finished with a 14.966, holding on to the lead before the 24-year-old Filipino came in and snatched the advantage.\n\nFive other gymnasts followed, including Jake Jarman of Britain, who eventually claimed the bronze with a 14.933.\n\nYulo, who finished 12th in the all-around final, failed to make the medal round in the Tokyo Olympics, after fumbling a landing early in his routine.\n\nThis time, he stuck every landing at every pass emphatically, making it clear that he was back to the form that made him the event's world champion in 2019.\n\nYulo opened with a two-and-a-half twist to front double pike. Then had a front double full to front double tuck. He had slight hops at the end of both. But after a full-twisting double layout, he stuck another landing and it was clear he was in the middle of something special.\n\n\"I did not hesitate. I just went for it,\" Yulo told journalists after the medal ceremony.\n\nMegaworld's gift\n\nIn a statement shortly after Yulo's victory, the property giant Megaworld Corp. gave the first glimpse of the windfall that awaits the latest Filipino sports hero upon his return home.\n\n\"As promised, we are giving Carlos Yulo a two-bedroom condo unit in one of our premier residential properties inside McKinley Hill in Taguig that will come furnished with appliances as well as furniture and fixtures, valued at approximately P24 million,'' said Megaworld Corp. president Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso.\n\n\"We are excited to welcome Caloy to his new home when he comes back!'' Alfonso said.\n\nYulo's triumph overshadowed an earlier victory by Nesthy Petecio, who smoked hometown bet Amina Zidani to reach the quarterfinals of the women's 57kg boxing event.\n\nAfter pawing gingerly at air in the first round, Petecio turned up the heat in the second, battering the No. 3 seed to score what looked like a knockdown that was counted by the referee.\n\n\"When she got hit with my hook, I really felt my fist hit her plus she got hurt with body shots. She really got hurt with those body shots,\" Petecio told local Olympics broadcaster OneSports after the bout at North Paris Arena.\n\nIn between those victories by Yulo and Petecio, EJ Obiena qualified for the pole vault final but Carlo Paalam was shown the door in the men's 57kg division after losing an ultra-tight quarterfinal duel against Australia's Charlie Senior.\n\nObiena cleared 5.75m in the pole vault preliminaries to join 11 other athletes in the final round.\n\nBoxer bows out\n\nThat 5.75 was the same standard cleared by nine other finalists, including world No. 1 and gold medal favorite Mondo Duplantis, but the Filipino will enter the final as the seventh seed via tiebreak.\n\nPaalam lost a 3-2 split decision to Senior after both fighters started out indecisively in the first round.\n\nPaalam began his attack in the second round to seize control of the match, launching combinations and landing clean shots against the game Senior, who managed to land effective but limited counters.\n\nBoth fighters fought evenly in the third, producing the result that would have been debatable even if the Filipino had won.\n\nPaalam was looking to win a second Olympic medal after finishing with a silver in Tokyo. Instead, he joins fellow eliminated boxers Eumir Marcial and Hergie Bacyadan on the sidelines, leaving the Philippines with two fighters left, Petecio and Aira Villegas.", "source": {"uri": He also emerged as the first Filipino gymnast to win it all when he ruled the floor exercise final, edging erstwhile defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel.\n\nThe 24-year-old gymnast's life is about to change as he is set to receive a P10 million incentive from the Philippine Sports Commission -- under Republic Act 10699 or National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act.\n\nREAD: Carlos Yulo wins floor exercise gold medal in Paris Olympics\n\nThe House of Representatives will also hand P3 million to Yulo, while Vikings, Tipsy Pig, and other restaurants have pledged a lifetime of free food.\n\nWhen Diaz ended the 97-year gold medal drought of the Philippines, she received over P50 million in incentives including several houses and lots, condo units, lifetime of free flights, gasoline, and other products.\n\nYulo will also receive an Olympic Gold Medal of Valor from the PSC.\n\nAs incentives are expected to continue to pour in Yulo's victory, he has another chance to win another gold in the vault apparatus final on Sunday.\n\nREAD: Gymnast Carlos Yulo gives PH its second Olympic gold\n\nThe remaining Filipino athletes including semifinalist Aira Villegas and pole vault finalist EJ Obiena have a chance to receive a cash incentive depending on their rankings as P5 million awaits the silver medalist, while P5 million for the bronze finisher.\n\nCoaches of the medalists will also receive a cash incentive as long as they have trained the athlete for more than six months.\n\nFor track and field athletes Obiena and hurdlers John Cabang and Lauren Hoffman, International Container Terminal Services, Inc. It sealed the first gymnastics Olympic medal ever for the Philippines.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nDefending champion and world titleholder Artem Dolgopyat of Israel was pushed into silver with 14.966. \"The past months (in general) were hard. I tried to do my best in the competition, to show everyone that Israel is very strong and that we can win medals.\" Britain's Jake Jarman, who had scored highest in qualifying a week ago, achieved 14.933 to take bronze at Bercy Arena.\n\nYulo had warned he was \"shooting for the stars\" in Paris after missing out on the podium in Tokyo.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAnd his acrobatic and technically difficult routine proved a hit, scoring higher than the 14.766 he had garnered in qualifying.\n\n\"I'm so overwhelmed. He had no doubt about it.\n\nAnd molded and toughened by the crucibles of life, trusting the process and maintaining a positive attitude, Yulo hit his full potential -- and he's now called King Carlos, King Caloy, Golden Boy, Olympic Champ, etc.\n\nYulo's the best from the rest or the greatest from among all hopefuls the country had unleashed to compete in the pinnacle of all sporting wars. Count all of them from the country's very first plunge in the Games back in 1924 to this day in the same adorable French capital.\n\nYulo wrote his name in the annals of Philippine sports with two magical moments in a weekend of Olympic gymnastics medal plays, claiming the floor exercise and vault championships at the Bercy Arena.\n\nBefore Yulo, there's no Philippine bet who had won a gymnastics medal and no Philippine male athlete in any sport who had nailed an Olympic gold. Today, there's no other who can answer to a call \"Olympic Double-Gold Winner!\"\n\n\"It's just so overwhelming,\" said Yulo.\n\nBut the nagging question is what makes Yulo different? What sets him apart from the rest?\n\nIt's not thrown at him exactly in his hours of triumphs as he has always got a ready answer -- enduring trials of life, making the most of his experiences and accepting anything God has to give.\n\n\"I did not give up on the challenges. I am thankful to the Lord that he gave me this experience, this life and this opportunity to play in such big competition,\" said Yulo after winning his first gold.\n\n\"(I've gone through) lots of experiences that are pretty tough for me, not only in gymnastics but in personal life. I'm grateful that God gave me the power to enjoy this kind of journey,\" Yulo shared after completing his amazing double-gold feat.\n\nHe's in the zenith of sporting success and he's automatically bound to receive millions in incentives, but there's the sad part of his thorny relationship with his family. There's also his split with his Japanese coach Munehiro Kugiyama.\n\nAll these that he'd rather not discuss.\n\n\"I'm just grateful to God. I'm grateful I didn't stop and grateful He gave me hope and He gave me people who truly believe and trust me,\" he said, making special mention of his partner Chloe San Jose and her family.\n\n\"I really need to work on my personality not just in gymnastics but on how I view life. I need to work on myself to learn and accept what I can do and trust the process for me and my mental health,\" he added.\n\nRedemption from Tokyo slip?\n\n\"It's not revenge anymore like in 2022. It's more like 'let's do it and let's find out,'\" said Yulo.\n\nHe did it and found great success, ending his Paris campaign with two shining gold medals dangling on his neck.\n\nAt 24, Yulo is an {"uri": "2024-08-443023085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "17:23:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T17:23:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T17:11:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/08/04/2375351/king-carlos-yulo-delivers-olympic-gold-philippines", "title": "King Carlos Yulo delivers Olympic gold for Philippines", "body": "GOLDEN BOY: Carlos Yulo of the Philippines celebrates after his performance in the artistic gymnastics men's floor exercise final (inset) of the 2024 Olympic Games at the Bercy Arena in Paris yesterday.\n\nAFP\n\nPARIS - Three years after his Tokyo slip, gymnast Carlos Yulo emerged as an Olympic golden boy, coming through with the performance of his life and delivering a triumph for the ages in the floor exercise final at the Bercy Arena here Saturday.\n\nAnd Yulo, a two-gold winner in the World Championships, is now also an Olympic gold medalist - the second for the Philippines after the breakthrough feat by weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz in the last edition in 2021 in the Japanese capital.\n\nWith perfect somersaults to finish his routine, Yulo clenched his right fist and punched the air, already celebrating, confident he's got a winning show.\n\nThird in the order of performers in the program, the 24-year-old Manila pride, with a score of 15.000, bettered those of Spain's Rayderley Zapata (14.333) and Israeli titleholder Artem Dolgopyat (14.966). And he stayed there on top after all eight finalists were done, the last flash of the scores sparking a rush of emotion for the Filipino champ.\n\nTears were rolling down his face as his rivals were all over him shortly before the awarding ceremony.\n\nFor the second straight Olympics, the Philippine national anthem was played in the greatest sporting show on earth.\n\nYulo ruled his pet event with a chance to become an Olympic double-gold winner as he's also vying in the vault final Sunday.\n\nIt would have been a brighter golden Saturday for Team Philippines if not for the sorry split decision loss by 57kg boxer Carlo Paalam to an Australian foe over at the Paris North Arena.\n\nAdding to the joy was EJ Obiena overcoming a faulty start and thundering to the pole vault final at the Stade de France.\n\nThe biggest cheers belonged to Yulo, the newest member of a short list of Filipino Olympic medalists, joining fellow gold winner Diaz (also with a silver), silver winners Anthony Villanueva, Onyok Velasco, Nesthy Petecio and Paalam, and bronze holders Teofilo Yldefonso, Simeon Toribio, Jose Villanueva, Miguel White, Leopoldo Serantes, Roel Velasco and Eumir Marcial.\n\nWith Yulo's feat, the Olympic medal streak of the country continued from Diaz' silver feat in 2016 in Rio to the 1-2-1 gold-silver-bronze breakthrough in 2021 in Tokyo and to these Games where Team Philippines is in a good position to even strike harder, punch stronger and soar higher.\n\nAt night, Aira Villegas was to seek a spot in the women's 50kg semifinals for a sure bronze.\n\nPaalam missed the same in a 2-3 loss to Australian Charlie Senior. The Bukidnon bet would have made history as the first Filipino boxer to collect two Olympic medals if not for the shock fall. With two bronzes was swimmer Yldefonso.\n\nYulo, however, quickly soothed the pain and heartaches felt by the Nationals' on Paalam's loss.\n\nA pocket number of Filipinos inside the grand Paris arena by the River Seine and millions watching on television back in the country celebrated with Yulo as he took his place among the best - a spot in the pantheon of Filipino sporting greats.\n\nBeating other finalists Jake Jarman of Great Britain, Illia Kovtun of Ukraine, Milad Karimi of Kazakhstan, Luke Whitehouse also of Great Britain, and Zhang Boheng of China, Yulo's name will now live in the hearts of Filipinos and in Philippine sports lore for a long, long time.\n\nDolgopyat took the silver while Jarman, a Fil-British, snared the bronze.\n\nFor the second straight Olympics, the Philippine national anthem was played in the greatest sporting show on earth.\n\nYulo ruled his pet event with a chance to become an Olympic double-gold winner as he's also vying in the vault final Sunday.\n\nIt would have been a brighter golden Saturday for Team Philippines if not for the sorry split decision loss by 57kg boxer Carlo Paalam to an Australian foe over at the Paris North Arena.\n\nAdding to the joy was EJ Obiena overcoming a faulty start and thundering to the pole vault final at the Stade de France.\n\nThe biggest cheers belonged to Yulo, the newest member of a short list of Filipino Olympic medalists, joining fellow gold winner Diaz (also with a silver), silver winners Anthony Villanueva, Onyok Velasco, Nesthy Petecio and Paalam, and bronze holders Teofilo Yldefonso, Simeon Toribio, Jose Villanueva, Miguel White, Leopoldo Serantes, Roel Velasco and Eumir Marcial.\n\nWith Yulo's feat, the Olympic medal streak of the country continued from Diaz' silver feat in 2016 in Rio to the 1-2-1 gold-silver-bronze breakthrough in 2021 in Tokyo and to these Games where Team Philippines is in a good position to even strike harder, punch stronger and soar higher.\n\nAt night, Aira Villegas was to seek a spot in the women's 50kg semifinals for a sure bronze.\n\nPaalam missed the same in a 2-3 loss to Australian Charlie Senior. {"uri": "8259710763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:31:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:31:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:30:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/05/houses-reward-for-yulo-swelled-to-p6-m", "title": "House's reward for Yulo swelled to P6-M", "body": "A congratulatory message to Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo is seen at the Quantum Skyview of Gateway Mall 2, Araneta City in Quezon City, on 5 August 2024, for his two-gold-medal win in the Paris 2024 Olympics men's artistic gymnastics floor exercise and men's vault. Yulo is the first male and second gold medalist in the country's Summer Olympics history.ANALY LABOR\n\nThe House of Representatives' reward to gymnast Carlos Yulo has swelled to P6 million after he clinched his second gold medal in the men's vault at the 2024 Paris Olympics, just a day after he captured his first mint in the men's floor exercise.\n\nIn an ambush interview on Monday, Speaker Martin Romualdez confirmed that the House would double the initial P3 million cash incentive to Yulo in conformity with the chamber's commitment to reward Filipino Olympic gold medalists P3 million, while P2 million for silver, and P1 million for bronze.\n\n\"We feel that it's important to support and inspire all our athletes and to recognize their achievements. We're very, very proud of our medalists and we look forward to more medals during this Olympics and we're very inspired as [a] nation,\" Romualdez told reporters.\n\nThe 24-year-old Yulo made history by becoming a two-time gold Olympic medalist.\n\nFollowing a flawlessly executed routine in the men's floor exercise, he bagged his first gold on Saturday night (Philippine time), scoring 15.000 points. He outperformed Tokyo 2020 champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by merely 0.034 points and Great Britain's Jake Jarman -- a half-blooded Filipino -- who earned 14.933 points.\n\nKeeping the momentum, Yulo then wowed the crowd in Bercy Stadium in a stunning performance late Sunday in the men's vault, scoring 15.166 points, pushing vault's main man Artur Davtyan for the silver with 14.966 points.\n\nIn addition to the P6 million reward from the House, Yulo will also receive additional cash incentives from a fundraising campaign initiated by Romualdez among his colleagues in the chamber.\n\n\"We will continue to support and invest in our sports programs to nurture and develop more world-class athletes like Caloy. His success is a shining example of hope and a source of inspiration for all of us,\" Romualdez remarked.\n\nThe House chief also disclosed that he ordered the concerned committees to initiate discussions on passing a bill that would institutionalize the grant of more financial incentives and other benefits to Filipino Olympic medalists, including lifetime pension when they hit the retirement age of 40.\n\nA day after Yulo's back-to-back monumental victory, the House Committee on Ways and Means approved a consolidated bill providing tax exemptions for donations to national athletes competing in international sports competitions.\n\nPanel chairperson, Albay Rep. Joey Salceda, one of the measure's proponents (House Bill 421), highlighted the hardships and challenges that Filipino athletes, including Yulo, hurdled before reaching the pinnacle of their careers.\n\n\"A 12-year-old Carlos Yulo once gave an interview where he said that his dream was to win a gold medal for the Philippines in the Olympics. It took him more than a decade to reach that goal in the grandest manner possible,\" he said.\n\n\"What that teaches us is that the prize is never won on the day of the competition itself but years before. Hard work, determination, and sheer grit through many years of training wins over talent.\"\n\nAccording to Salceda, the panel-approved bill, which he called the \"Hidilyn Diaz Act\" last Congress, exempts not just the prizes handed out by brands and companies after the win but also exempts donations toward their training one year before the competition.\n\nApart from exempting donations one year prior to the date of the competition, Salceda proposed that donations through the Philippine Sports Commission or the Philippine Olympic Committee be made exempt from tax regardless of time.\n\n\"In fact, I would like to forward to you an additional proposal: that we not just exempt donations towards their training for one year, but to exempt donations from tax for their entire training, provided that such donations are made through the Philippine Olympic Committee or the Philippine Sports Commission,\" the economist-lawmaker said.\n\n\"At the proper time, that can be introduced in the plenary. But let me emphasize this once again: it is mere tokenism, it is mere public relations, to ride the bandwagon when the victory has already been achieved. What we need to incentivize is the investments being made on the athletes who are still working on winning medals for the country.\"", "source": {"uri": "tribune.net.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-08-444021150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:23:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:23:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:14:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/sports/2024/08/05/2375596/philippines-hauls-medals-2-straight-golden-days", "title": "Philippines hauls medals in 2 straight 'golden' days", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - The Philippines waited a hundred years for this Olympic moment.\n\nThis moment spanned two days, August 3 and 4. Gymnast Carlos Edriel Yulo delivered two straight Olympic golds. (Yes, you've read that sentence right.)\n\nTwo female boxers, flyweight Aira Villegas and featherweight and Tokyo Olympics silver medalist Nesthy Petecio, got assured bronze medals given their quarterfinal victories, while Yulo was scooping golds for two straight days.\n\nNever in the history of the quadrennial Olympic Games that this underdog Southeast Asian country enjoyed two straight days of winning Olympic gold medals -- of hauling multiple medals -- to outleap itself as a sporting nation.\n\nDifficult routines as gold mines\n\nAugust 3 and 4 did belong to the 24-year-old Yulo, whose 6.600 and 6.000 start-up difficulty scores in the floor exercises and the vault, respectively, led to his homeland's best Olympic Games outing ever.\n\nSince Yulo started winning world-level medals at the 2018 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships in Doha, Paris 2024 saw Yulo reach his peak -- exactly what former Japanese coach Munehiro Kugiyama predicted some five years ago.\n\nYulo's 15.116 in the vault is his highest score ever in the apparatus, propelled by a 15.433 on his first vault.\n\n\"First vault is amazing,\" said International Gymnast Magazine on its annotation. Yulo did a \"Ri II\" (named after North Korean vaulter Ri Se Gwang), which is \"a piked\" version of the Dragulescu -- a handspring double somersault, with one's legs tucked to a gymnast's chest area, and ending with a half-twist upon landing.\n\nRi II, a front handspring front double-piked somersault with a half twist, was what Yulo did. Upon falling down, Yulo held his piked position \"strongly,\" as the Olympic Games broadcast commentators noticed. His left foot just barely touched the center line in a nice landing.\n\n\"Good form, good height, good landing, just a tiny hop - the score should be big,\" IGM annotated.\n\nNobody came close to Yulo's first vault score, that being the push to just make ensure that he lands nicely in his final vault. The 15.433 is Yulo's best-ever vault.\n\nCome his final vault, Yulo did a Kasumatsu (beginning with a quarter-turned position prior to thumping the vault happening on his right, then he made two twists even if his right knee got slightly bent toward landing).\n\nBut the landing of Yulo, even with a hop \"holds it there, to make sure it is just a single step,\" IGM said.\n\nThe total's 14.800, just enough for his 15.116 average and the second gold medal.\n\nDifficulty in outleaping Olympic nerves\n\nThe first gold's the nail-biter. Given Yulo's 6.600 difficulty start-up score, he started off with a 2 \u00bd twist then a double pike, with just a small hop. Then he made a front double full-to-front double tuck, even if Yulo made a bigger hop.\n\nThe middle part of the routine then saw Yulo do a neat full-twisting double layout stuck, then he upped the ante with a triple twist on the side. The second-to-the-last pass saw Yulo do a full Randi, then got that tiny hop on his left side.\n\nThe final pass was a 3 \u00bd twist and he thudded the floor with his feet straight. \"Argh!,\" Yulo said, raising both clenched fists to the air.\n\n\"We are going to have a new Olympic champion here!\" IGM annotated.\n\n\"Before I came here, this routine wasn't that consistent. In the qualifications, I played it very safely,\" Yulo told International Gymnast Magazine after his performance.\n\n\"Today, I felt I couldn't hold back and hesitate. If I really wanted to win, I needed to give my everything... I really wanted to achieve this.\"\n\nYulo's years of doing that 6.600 floor routine, after the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and the 2021 World Championships, finally hit paydirt.\n\nJust when most Filipinos in the motherland slept given a six-hour time difference, Aira Villegas confronted a raucous hometown crowd and got a sure bronze medal in a 3-2 upset of seventh seed Wassila Lkhadiri of France to end August 3.\n\nNerves came after round two scores were flashed: a judge apiece, and three similar 19-all scores for Villegas and Lkhadiri. When the 3-2 verdict was howled, Villegas jumped twice in the air, then pounded the middle of the ring twice, in relief and in glee.\n\nPetecio gets the ball rolling\n\nNesthy Petecio then started off the August 4 medal haul by dominating Zichun Xu of China, 5-0.\n\nXu upset tournament top seed Irma Testa of Ireland in the round-of-32. But Petecio showed the class of her boxing that won the silver in Tokyo 2020.\n\nAnd the Philippines' Olympic boxing odyssey, currently taken over by women, continues with now 10 medals -- even if there's no gold medal yet.\n\nTo earn silver medals, Villegas must overcome Buse Naz \u00c7akiroglu of Turkey this August 6, while Petecio needs to stop Julia Szeremeta of Poland on August 7.\n\nThe women's flyweight finals are set for August 9, and that of the featherweight class August 10 -- two straight days that Villegas and Petecio hope to make it.\n\nA third straight Philippine Olympic medal day?\n\nIf World No. 2 pole vaulter Ernest John Obiena lands a medal in his final round on August 5 (Paris time), that's another Philippine Olympic first: three straight days of medal hauling, and a fifth Olympic medal.\n\nWhat's a third feat for the Philippines is three straight Olympic Games editions of winning a medal: 1928-1932-1936 being the first one (five bronzes), and 1988-1992-1996 being the second one (a silver and two bronzes, plus a gold and two bronzes in non-counted demonstration sports).\n\nThe nation was in euphoria over weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz's silver medal in Rio de Janeiro 2016 and her dramatic 2020 gold medal feat in Tokyo, with the latter complementing silver medals from Petecio and Carlo Paalam and a bronze medal from Eumir Felix Marcial (all boxers).\n\nThen Paris 2024 came along, the centennial of the Philippines' first Olympic participation.\n\nBut for now, two straight days of medal hauling -- and gold medal scooping by Southeast Asia's best gymnast Yulo -- is the Philippines' greatest memory at the Olympic Games.", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Philstar.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli\n\nPresident Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos, Jr. on Monday congratulated Philippine gymnast Carlos Yulo for winning his second Olympic gold medal.\n\nYulo ruled the men's vault finals on Sunday at the 2024 Paris Olympics to take home another gold medal from the Summer Games.\n\n\"No words can express how proud we are of you, Caloy. You have achieved gold for the Philippines not once, but twice,\" the caption of his social media post read.\n\n\"Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you.\n\n\"Aming ipinagmamalaki ang tagumpay mong nagniningning! {"uri": "8260058797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:12:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:12:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:11:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/mendoza-yulo-a-warrior-like-no-other", "title": "Mendoza: Yulo: A warrior like no other", "body": "CARLOS \"Caloy\" Yulo did not only make history in the ongoing Paris Olympics. He also opened our eyes to the beauty of gymnastics.\n\nBefore Yulo blitzed his two unprecedented gold medals in spectacular fashion -- he did it in two straight days, mind you -- we had but a mere glimpse of what the sport is really all about.\n\nAfter 16 years of being a gymnast from age 8, Yulo's dream of winning an Olympic gold was finally fulfilled.\n\nBefore Yulo, no one has won two Olympic gold medals in 100 years of Philippine participation in the quadrennial Games, putting him in a pedestal too hard to surpass, let alone equal.\n\nAfter winning the floor exercise on Aug. 3, he cried unabashedly like a toddler losing his balloon to the wind.\n\nHe kept crying all the way to the awarding ceremony so that every note of \"Lupang Hinirang\" while the Philippine national anthem was being played gnawed at every single vein, valve, of his heart.\n\nSurely, each tear shed was for joy and self-fulfillment to someone savoring his first taste of Olympic victory. Its impact more than amounted to his world title triumphs in 2019 and 2021.\n\nThe intense feeling can compare, perhaps, to the feeling of having finally speared the love of your life.\n\nTo every athlete, nothing beats Olympic glory.\n\nEqually dramatic was when Yulo won his second gold in the vault events the next day, coming after a tension-filled wait for his last four opponents to complete their performances.\n\nPerforming fourth among eight finalists, Yulo took the lead after his two smashing vault executions, both coming in near-flawless fashion.\n\nThere was an anxious moment when the last performer appeared to have nailed the winning act.\n\nBut when the final scores showed Yulo the winner, euphoria erupted in the Filipino's camp, with our ace gymnast embracing his Filipino coach, Aldrin Casta\u00f1eda, amid cheering and hoopla.\n\n\"I'm so happy I made it as I am still in celebration mode after yesterday's win,\" said Yulo in Filipino. \"I haven't almost slept a wink last night.\"\n\nSee? Yulo went through a gut-wringer not fit to anyone with a faint heart. He also delivered the Philippines' first medal in the Paris Olympics, and still has a chance to capture another one on Sunday in the vault finals.\n\n\"Deserve niya 'yan. "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578492/incentives-continue-to-pour-for-carlos-yulo-after-his-golden-feat", "title": "Incentives continue to pour for Carlos Yulo after double gold feat", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Team Philippines gymnast Carlos Yulo is set for a major windfall with his unprecedented success in the Paris Olympics, becoming the first Filipino to win a pair of gold medals in the Summer Games.\n\nHis incentives from his gold medal haul are expected to continue to increase, if not double, as more private companies pitch in to reward the most successful Olympian the Philippines has ever produced after his gold medal win in vault Sunday night.\n\nAs of Monday, Yulo is already guaranteed P32 million in cash incentives -- with P26 million from the government and P6 million from private companies -- and a three-bedroom condo unit.\n\nYulo Earned himself another P10 million incentive-on top of the first P10 million from his first gold-and the Olympic Gold Medal of Valor from the Philippine Sports Commission under the Republic Act 10699 or National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act.\n\nHe also doubled his incentive from the House of Representatives as he is now to receive a total of P6 million-P3 million for each of the gold medals he won-according to House Speaker Martin Romualdez.\n\n\"We want to make sure that they are equally inspired and equally acknowledged and rewarded for their achievements,\" Romauldez told the beat reporters.\n\nMegaworld, which had promised to give an Olympic medalist a fully-furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24 million in McKinley Hill, upgraded Yulo's prize into a three-bedroom unit worth a million with appliances, furniture, fixtures, two balconies, and a parking slot.\n\nThe company also pledged a P3 million cash bonus for his exceptional achievement.\n\n\"Since this is a very significant milestone in the history of Philippine sports to have two gold Olympic medals during our 100th year participation as a country in the Olympics, which also coincides with our company's 35th anniversary this year,\" said Megaworld president Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso in a statement.\n\nBounty Fresh Group Holdings Inc. and Chooks-to-Go also committed to gift Yulo P3 million in cash bonus.\n\nAs a Filipino brand, we believe in celebrating and supporting our homegrown talent, and this reward is a testament to our admiration for Carlos. We hope his success will inspire the next generation of Filipino athletes to pursue their dreams with the same passion and determination,\" said Bounty Fresh executive Patricia Cheng-Lim.\n\nBounty has been supporting Filipino athletes since 2016 including Tokyo Games bronzed medalist and boxer Eumir Marcial and gave Chooks-to-Go stores to former Olympians Onyok Velasco and Roel Velasco.\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Bambol Tolentino is also rewarding the the winners in Paris Olympics with a house and lot like what he did for Diaz and 2020 Tokyo Olympics silver medalists Nesthy Petecio and Carlo Paalam, and bronze medalist Eumir Marcial.\n\nYulo may also get a \"Senate Medal of Excellence\" as filed by Senate Majority Leader Francis Tolentino on Monday.\n\nLifetime benefits await Yulo with restaurants like Vikings and Tipsy Pig extending free meals.\n\nMore are expected to pour in the coming days for Yulo, who stands alone in the country's history, with other brands like Milo, which has been supporting grassroots sports in the country, posting a heartfelt message about the gymnast's greatness.\n\nWhen Tokyo 2020 weightlifting champion HidilynDiaz ended the 97-year gold medal drought of the Philippines, she received over 50 million in incentives including several houses and lots, condo units, lifetime of free flights, gasoline, and other products.\n\nAside from monetary incentives, Yulo is also set for a hero's welcome in his hometown in Manila.\n\nThe remaining Filipino athletes including semifinalists Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas and pole vault finalist EJ Obiena have a chance to receive a cash incentive depending on their rankings as P5 million awaits the silver medalist, while P5 million for the bronze {"uri": "8258436122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "09:35:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T09:35:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T09:34:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/showbitz/celebrity-profiles/314480239/incentives-rewards-await-as-carlos-yulo-wins-phs-2nd-olympic-gold-medal.html", "title": "Incentives, rewards await as Carlos Yulo wins PH's 2nd Olympic gold medal - Manila Standard", "body": "Carlos Edriel Yulo has etched his name in Philippine sports history with a golden performance at the Paris Olympics on Saturday, August 3, clinching the country's first-ever gymnastics gold medal.\n\nMore than bringing the country's second Olympic gold medal, Yulo's success also served as his redemption from the painful 2021 Tokyo Olympics, where he was eliminated before the finals.\n\nAfter his historic win, Yulo is expected to receive numerous pledges for bringing pride to the Philippines, including millions in cash incentives from both the government and private companies, in addition to various other rewards. So far, here are some of the incentives and rewards that Caloy will receive for winning gold in the Olympics, as of this writing.\n\nAside from his gold medal, the Philippine Sports Commission is also set to honor Yulo with the Olympic Gold Medal of Valor.\n\nThe 4-foot-11 Yulo is entitled to a substantial cash prize of P10 million under Republic Act 10699 or the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act. This, along with other government-mandated benefits, serves as a token of the nation's gratitude for Yulo's exceptional achievement.\n\nOn Friday, the House of Representatives announced that it will also grant the Olympic gold medalist P3 million in recognition of his historic achievement, according to Zaldy Co, chair of the House appropriations panel and AKO Bicol representative.\n\nYulo has also been promised a fully furnished two-bedroom condominium unit in McKinley Hills from property developer Megaworld, valued at P24 million. The Philippine Olympic Committee will also be giving the 24-year-old Olympian a house and lot.\n\nBuffet restaurant Vikings also pledged a lifetime free buffet for Caloy, while Kuhmeal offered free baked mac for life. Tipsy Pig shared that he will be entitled to free food and drinks at any branch.\n\nMeanwhile, automotive parts store Orion said that it would give Yulo a free set of headlights and fog lights for his vehicle. Eyewear store Peculiar is set to provide Caloy's OOTD eyewear.\n\nComedian Vice Ganda extended his congratulatory message to Yulo, offering free entrance to his Vice Comedy Club with free nachos and You have achieved gold for the Philippines not once, but twice. Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you,\" said Mr. Marcos.\n\nMr. Yulo's milestone vaulted him as the greatest Filipino gymnast of all time -- if not the greatest athlete already -- with a breakthrough that also made him the only multi-medalist Pinoy in a single Olympics at only 24 years of age.\n\nAnd for that, even the world's only eight-division boxing champion and No. 1 Asian Athlete this millennium as per the ESPN was in complete awe as Mr. Yulo catapulted the Philippines to Top-20 in the Olympic medal tally for the first time after 100 years of participation.\n\n\"Another historic win for the Philippines. Congratulations again Carlos Yulo for winning your 2nd gold at the Paris 2024 Olympics. We, the Filipinos, are truly proud of you. Thank you, Caloy,\" said Mr. Pacquiao.\n\nWeightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who snapped a 97-year wait for the Philippines, three years back in the Tokyo Olympics, also doubled down on congratulating Mr. him up to his last tumbling.\n\nHis teammate Aleiah Finnegan herself watched Mr. Yulo's golden feat at the Bercy Arena, along with close pal and Team USA ace gymnast Suni Lee, a gold and two-bronze Long live you! Our nation honors you!\" Senate Majority Leader Francis Tolentino said.\n\nMeanwhile, Senator Bong Go, who chairs the Senate Sports and Youth Committees, said Yulo's win served as a challenge to the government to continue supporting Filipino athletes.\n\n\"Your journey from the playgrounds of Malate to the Olympic stadium in Paris is a true inspiration for every Filipino,\" Senator Alan Peter Cayetano said. \"Along the way you have shown what sacrifice, commitment, and the Filipino spirit can achieve.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Senator Juan Miguel Zubiri called Yulo a \"golden boy\" as he thanked the Filipino gymnast for showing \"the world the heart of a Filipino champion.\"\n\n\"You are a shining example of what hard work and dedication can do!\" Senator Pia Cayetano said.\n\nSenators Aquilino Pimentel III, Nancy Binay, Senator JV Ejercito, Sherwin Gatchalian, Pia Hontiveros, Loren Legarda, Imee Marcos, Grace Poe, and Bong Revilla likewise congratulated Yulo in Facebook posts.\n\nMeanwhile, Senator Joel Villanueva congratulated the Olympian as he shared a throwback photo with him.\n\nSenator Cynthia Villar said she had goosebumps as the Philippine National Anthem was played in the Olympics.\n\nIn his statement, Senator Robin Padilla congratulated Yulo and hoped other Filipino athletes also win gold in the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nPresident Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos Jr. and First Lady Liza Araneta-Marcos earlier congratulated Yulo.\n\nYulo will have a chance to grab another gold medal as he is set to compete in the vault final on Sunday. -- DVM, GMA Integrated News", {"uri": "8258389486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "08:51:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T08:51:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T08:50:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/sport/paris-olympics-2024/asia/article/3273146/philippines-rejoices-yulo-gold-gymnast-gets-hk135-million-house-free-food-reward", "title": "Rewards rain down for Yulo, with cash, house, free food for life after gold win", "body": "Carlos Yulo took home gold in the men\u2019s floor exercise in Paris, only his country\u2019s second gold medal ever at the Games\n\nBeyond just elevating himself to Philippines national hero status, Carlos Yulo\u2019s historic Olympic gold has triggered a cascade of rewards from the public and private sector.\n\nYulo earned the country its inaugural Olympic gold in gymnastics and only the second gold ever, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz at the Tokyo Games.\n\nIn recognition of his unparalleled accomplishment, a slew of local brands and even national institutions have showered Yulo with lavish rewards.\n\nThe Philippine government has said it would award the 24-year-old PHP 10 million (HK$1.35 million), fulfilling its pledge to any athlete who brought home a gold.\n\nThe country\u2019s restaurants are rolling out the red carpet, offering their hero lifetime free buffets. Vikings, tabbed for its elaborate global cuisine spreads, has made one offer, while Yulo could also savour limitless food and drinks at Tipsy Pig branches and free meals at a number of other restaurants if he wants.\n\nYulo will also get a fully-furnished two-bedroom condo unit \u2013 worth PHP 24 million \u2013 in McKinley Hill, the largest development in Metro Manila.\n\nAnd with free furniture worth up to 100,000 pesos from Apollo Home Depot, he\u2019ll have a luxurious haven in which to bask in his Olympic glory.\n\nIn fact, he might not even need the house and lot the Philippine Olympic Committee is offering him.\n\nYulo\u2019s holistic rewards encompass every need, with renowned medic Dr Virgil Lo vowing to provide the gymnastics ace with free gastro consults and colonoscopies for life.\n\nExtending into all possible facets of his life, Yulo has also earned a lifetime free engineering design from Nexa Engineering and university credits from the University of Mindanao.\n\nTo top off his already stellar haul, the Philippines House of Representatives is adding a PHP 3 million cherry on top for Yulo.\n\n\u201cIn recognition of his historic accomplishment, the House of Representatives is honoured to award Carlos Yulo P3,000,000. This reward reflects our support for his continued success and our commitment to fostering Filipino talent on the international stage,\u201d chairman of the House Committee Elizaldy Co said.\n\nWith new rewards still rolling in, Yulo\u2019s list might continue to lengthen \u2013 reminiscent of the ongoing pledges Diaz received after her historic win in Tokyo.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", {"uri": "8258793258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:14:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:14:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:13:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/04/sports/carlos-yulo-claims-historic-2nd-gold-in-paris/1961868", "title": "Carlos Yulo claims historic 2nd gold in Paris", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Gymnast Carlos 'Caloy' Yulo just cemented his status as arguably the greatest, if not totally the greatest Filipino Olympian ever.\n\nAbout 24 hours after ruling the floor exercise final, Yulo conquered the vault competition at the Paris Olympics men's artistics gymnastics, emerging as the first Filipino Olympic multi-gold medalist at the Bercy Arena on Sunday night, August 4 (Manila time).\n\nHis confidence through the roof after delivering the Philippines first gymnastics Olympic medal on Saturday, the 4-foot-11 dynamo unleashed his magic anew to top the vault with an average score of 15.116 points.\n\nThe 24-year-old dazzled with a high-level execution of dragulescu pike in his first vault, just needing a little hop to gain balance after his landing and netting 15.433 points -- 6.000 in difficulty and 9.433 in execution.\n\nFourth to perform in the final, Yulo then executed a kasamatsu double in his second vault which was not as good as his first vault but still solid for 14.800 points -- 5.600 in difficulty and 9.200 in execution.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nAfter each vault, Yulo, as he has been all tournament, threw his fists into the air in high satisfaction of his performance.\n\nWhen the last four performers wound up with lower scores, Yulo was once again in disbelief after pulling off an Olympic feat no other Filipino athlete has done before.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWith Yulo's two-gold haul, the Philippines will finish the Paris Games with at least four medals, the other two being guaranteed bronzes - one each for Nesthy Petecio and He had no doubt about it.\n\nAnd molded and toughened by the crucibles of life, trusting the process and maintaining a positive attitude, Mr. Yulo hit his full potential and he's now called King Carlos, King Caloy, Golden Boy, Olympic Champ, etc.\n\nMr. Yulo's the best from the rest or the greatest from among all hopefuls the country had unleashed to compete in the pinnacle of all sporting wars. Count all of them from the country's very first plunge in the Games back in 1924 to this day in the same adorable French capital.\n\nMr. Yulo wrote his name in the annals of Philippine sports with two magical moments in a weekend of Olympic gymnastics medal plays, claiming the floor exercise and vault championships at the Bercy Arena.\n\nBefore Mr. Yulo, there's no Philippine bet who had won a gymnastics medal and no Philippine male athlete in any sport who had nailed an Olympic gold. Today, there's no other who can answer to a call \"Olympic Double-Gold Winner!\"\n\n\"It's just so overwhelming,\" said Mr. Yulo.\n\nBut the nagging question is what makes Mr. Yulo different? What sets him apart from the rest?\n\nIt's not thrown at him exactly in his hours of triumphs as he has always got a ready answer -- enduring trials of life, making the most of his experiences and accepting anything God has to give.\n\n\"I did not give up on the challenges. I am thankful to the Lord that he gave me this experience, this life and this opportunity to play in such big competition,\" said Mr. Yulo after winning his first gold.\n\n\"(I've gone through) lots of experiences that are pretty tough for me, not only in gymnastics but in personal life. I'm grateful that God gave me the power to enjoy this kind of journey,\" Mr. Yulo shared after completing his amazing double-gold feat.\n\nHe's in the zenith of sporting success and he's automatically bound to receive millions in incentives, but there's the sad part of his thorny relationship with his family. There's also his split with his Japanese coach Munehiro Kugiyama.\n\nAll these that he'd rather not discuss.\n\n\"I'm just grateful to God. I'm grateful I didn't stop and grateful He gave me hope and He gave me people who truly believe and trust me,\" he said, making special mention of his partner Chloe San Jose and her family.\n\n\"I really need to work on my personality not just in gymnastics but on how I view life. {"uri": "8258529519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "11:01:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T11:01:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T11:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.bworldonline.com/sports/2024/08/04/612029/filipinos-were-up-to-their-seats-to-witness-history/", "title": "Filipinos were up to their seats to witness history - BusinessWorld Online", "body": "INSTEAD of going to bed at the late hours of rainy Saturday night, millions of Filipinos back home were up to their seats on all available platforms, live and on-demand, to witness history -- or not.\n\nThe gamble -- and the wait -- paid off as Carlos \"Caloy\" Yulo, albeit thousands of miles away, did not disappoint in tumbling his way to a coveted gold medal in the floor exercise event of the Paris Olympics men's gymnastics.\n\nAlready the greatest Filipino gymnast of all time with a bevy of titles in the Asian and world championship levels, Mr. Yulo became only the second Filipino Olympic gold medalist and first Southeast Asian gymnast to ever scale the Mt. Olympus.\n\nAnd who else stood at the forefront of the congratulatory list but his predecessor, Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo, gold winner of weightlifting in Tokyo in 2021 to snap a 97-year wait for the Philippines.\n\n\"For you, Caloy. I'm proud of you. Enjoy it,\" beamed Ms. Diaz-Naranjo in the wee hours of Sunday when the Philippines was wide awake after Mr. Yulo secured his place in the books after a couple of misses and heartbreaks.\n\nIt was only two years ago when Ms. Diaz-Naranjo finally shattered the floodgates for the sports-crazed Filipino nation, fueling the drive of local athletes.\n\nIt did not take long for a follow-up on that trail with Mr. Yulo, after a heartbreaking fourth-place finish in Tokyo to miss the podium by 0.017 point, taking care of business in the Philippines' 100-year anniversary of Olympic participation.\n\nIn Paris, even the members of the 22-strong Philippine delegation tuned in, either from the Athletes Village or at the venue proper, to Mr. Yulo's golden leap.\n\n\"Our first Paris Olympics Gold Medal. Congratulations,\" said Mr. Marcial, a bronze medalist in Tokyo but had an early exit in Paris.\n\nFollowing his glory in France that became a trending topic on all social media platforms worldwide, Mr. Yulo became a rockstar with lines of foreigners trying to get a photo opportunity and secure a photograph.\n\nBack home where a truckload of rewards await him, he's a hero for an army of closing his campaign with two gold medals on Sunday at the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nThe 24-year-old Yulo is on the verge of becoming a multi-millionaire after ruling the floor exercise and vault events of the Summer Games.\n\nAccording to Republic Act No. 10699 or the Athletes and Coaches Incentives Act, a gold medalist in the Olympics stands to receive P10 million.\n\nWith Yulo cornering two gold medals, he is expected to pocket P20 million from the government.\n\nAside from that, other donors, including senators, congressmen, and President Ferdinand \"Bongbong\" Marcos, are also expected to provide cash incentives, as well as contributions from the private sector.\n\nIn fact, real estate titan Megaworld Corporation already dangled a two-bedroom condominium unit worth P24 million to whoever will win an Olympic gold medal.\n\nWith Yulo winning not one, but two medals, there is a strong possibility that he could surpass the more than P50-million windfall enjoyed by weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz when she ruled the Tokyo Olympics three years ago.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.net.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Tribune"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-444208270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/08/05/2375612/senate-medal-excellence-sought-carlos-yulo", "title": "Senate Medal of Excellence sought for Carlos Yulo", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Multiple resolutions have been filed seeking to award two-time Olympic gold medalist Carols Yulo the Senate Medal of Excellence.\n\nOver the weekend, Yulo made history by clinching two gold medals for men's gymnastics, one in the floor exercise and another one in the vault -- the first Filipino to win multiple gold medals in the Olympics.\n\nSen. Francis Tolentino filed Senate Resolution Numbers (SRN) 1102 and 1106. SRN 1102 would hail Yulo for winning the gold medal twice while SRN 1106 would give Yulo the Senate Medal of excellence.\n\n\"Ito ay mahalagang hakbang upang kilalanin at ipagdiwang ang tagumpay ng bansa. Ang tagumpay ni Caloy ay hindi lamang patunay ng kanyang dedikasyon at kahusayan, kundi pati na rin ng galing at talento ng mga Pilipino sa pandaigdigang entablado!\" Tolentino said in a Facebook post.\n\n(This is an important state to recognize and celebrate the country's victory. Caloy's win is not just proof of his dedication and greatness, but also of Filipinos' excellence and talent when it comes to the world stage!)\n\nSenate President Pro Tempore Jinggoy Ejercito Estrada filed similar resolutions.\n\n\"Yulo's outstanding achievement at the world's biggest sporting event should be celebrated by the entire nation as it is a testament to the excellent skill and unyielding spirit of the Filipinos. His glorious success is a shining example of what hard work, discipline, perseverance, and commitment to excellence can accomplish,\" Estrada said SRN 1103.\n\nEstablished in 2021, the Senate Medal of Excellence is awarded for Filipinos with exceptional achievements in the following international bodies: Nobel Prize, Pulitzer Prize, the A.M. Turing Award, the Ramon Magsaysay Award and the Olympics.\n\nLast Saturday, senators took to social media to greet Yulo during his first win, and had to greet him the next day when he won again.\n\n\"Our golden boy. Maraming salamat, Carlos Yulo, para sa dangal at saya na binibigay mo para sa Pilipinas! Mabuhay ka!,\" Sen. Risa Hontiveros said when Yulo won his second gold.\n\n(Our golden boy. Many thanks, Carlos Yulo, for the honor and joy that you gave to the Philippines. Mabuhay ka!)\n\nSen. Bong Go posted a video of him watching Yulo get his second win on Facebook.\n\n\"Galing, sabi ko, go, go go for gold! (Excellent! I said go, go go for gold!)\" Go said.\n\nSen. Pia Cayetano also congratulated Yulo.\n\n\"You are a shining example of what hard work and dedication can do! Proud to be your supporter since your training for the 2019 SEA (Southeast Asia) Games,\" Cayetano said.\n\nAccording to the Philippine Sports Commission, three senators pledged financial support for Paris-bound Filipino athletes. Go pledged P30 million, Hontiveros pledged P22 million and Cayetano gave an undisclosed amount of money.\n\nMeanwhile, Filipina boxers Aira Villegas and Nesthy Petecio were both guaranteed at least bronze medals in women's boxing. This marks the first time that the Philippines will bring home multiple medals in consecutive Olympics bouts.\n\nIn the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, the Philippine team brought home four medals (one gold, two silver and one bronze). It also marked the first time that a Filipino won gold, with weightlifter Hidlyn Diaz bringing home the gold medal.", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Philstar.com"}, {"uri": "8258869951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:31:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:31:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:31:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/04/diaz-lauds-yulos-feat", "title": "Diaz lauds Yulo's feat", "body": "Hidilyn Diaz gladly welcomes Carlos Yulo to the ulta-exclusive circle of Filipino Olympic medalists following his back-to-back victories in the gymnastics competition of the Summer Games over the weekend.\n\nDiaz, the country's first ever Olympic gold medalist, congratulated Yulo, saying that he is proud of him for overcoming all the hardships he went through.\n\n\"Congratulations ulit Caloy. Ang galing!\" Diaz said in a social media post.\n\n\"I am proud of you not only for your medals but for the hardships you went through to achieve success for yourself and, more importantly, for the nation.\"\n\nLike Diaz, Yulo also came from a poor family who worked hard and made a lot of sacrifices until becoming successful in the international arena.\n\nHe started to compete early until landing a scholarship to train and study in Japan when he was 14 years old.\n\nUnder the guidance of Japanese coach Munehiro Kugimiya, Yulo became a gymnastics powerhouse, winning the world title in floor exercise in 2019 and vault in 2021.\n\nHe, however, had a forgettable performance in the Tokyo Olympics three years ago, but he used the setback as a motivation to work hard and prepare for the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn Paris, his star power shone even brighter as he ruled the floor exercise on Saturday and the vault on Sunday, making him the greatest Filipino athlete to compete in the Summer Olympics.\n\nDiaz couldn't help but be proud of the achievement of Yulo.\n\n\"See you there, Caloy and a tight hug from your Ate Haidie. {"uri": "8258646929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "12:53:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T12:53:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T12:51:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/yulo-plucks-olympic-gold", "title": "Yulo plucks olympic gold", "body": "MANILA - Carlos Edriel Yulo was the smallest competitor but he stood tallest to deliver just the second gold for the Philippines in its 100-year participation in the Olympics.\n\nThe 24-year-old Yulo delivered what the country expected of him after a near-flawless routine in his pet event, floor exercise, at the Bercy Arena of the Paris Olympics late Saturday (PH time).\n\nHe crashed out in the finals three years ago in Tokyo but finally hit perfection to win it all.\n\n\"A final of the very highest quality,\" the international gymnastics federation said.\n\nThe wunderkind performed third in order and scored exactly 15 points, enough to edge Israeli Artem Dolgopyat, the 2021 Tokyo champion who came right before him.\n\nDolgopyat tallied 14.966 points for silver, while Great Britain's Jake Jarman, whose mother hails from Cebu province, captured the bronze with 14.933 points.\n\n\"I am confident that it will not be the last,\" President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. posted on social media. \"Congratulations, Caloy! The entire country stands proud with you!\"\n\n\"Thanks to Carlos Yulo, we have another golden moment to celebrate. His dedication and skill have not only brought us immense pride but also highlighted the incredible talent of our nation. Thank you, Carlos, for making us proud and inspiring us with your success. Your achievements are a testament to your hard work and the spirit of our people. Here's to making history and celebrating many more triumphs!\" the Philippine Olympic Committee, for its part, said.\n\nThe 4-foot-9 Yulo rose to prominence after winning the 2019 Germany world championship, also on the floor. He plucked another gold in vault two years later in Japan.\n\nWeightlifter Hidilyn Diaz delivered the Philippines' first-ever Olympic gold in Tokyo.\n\nHours earlier, Ernest John \"EJ\" Obiena booked his place in the finals of men's pole vault following the tension-filled qualifications at Stade De France.\n\nExpected to make the next stage, the world No. 2 pole vaulter almost missed the cut after an early struggle but bounced back to seal his place in the last 12. The medal round is scheduled early Tuesday (PH time).\n\nYulo capturing the gold made up for boxer Carlo Paalam's farewell from medal contention at Paris North Arena in the nearby city of Villepinte.\n\nPaalam could not sustain a solid first round and fell prey to Australian opponent Charlie Senior in the men's 57-kilogram quarterfinals.\n\nThe bout was tight almost all nine minutes with Paalam showing his accuracy and solid evasion and Senior making good use of his height and reach advantage.\n\nThe verdict, though, was ultimately decided by Irish judge Ben McGarrigle, who gave Round 3 to Senior after scoring it 19-all in the other rounds, sending Paalam home without a medal after a silver in Tokyo.\n\nVillegas enters semis\n\nAira Villegas assured the Philippines of a second medal in the Paris Olympics after stunning host country's Wassila Lkhadiri in a tight women's flyweight boxing quarterfinal battle early Sunday (PH time) at the Paris North Arena in Villepinte.\n\nVillegas exerted enough effort to convince the judges that she was better than Lkhadiri en route to a razor-thin split decision win.\n\nShe earned the nod of three judges (29-28, 29-28, 29-28) while the other two scored for the French (30-27, 29-28).\n\nVillegas said all her matches will be for teammates Carlo Paalam, Eumir Marcial, and Hergie Bacdayan, who are out of medal contention.\n\n\"Inaalay ko rin 'to sa mga kasamahan ko, kina Eumir, Hergie, tapos kay Carlo kanina. Nalungkot ako pero sabi ko kailangan ko siyang gawing motivation para ibawi 'yung kasamahan ko (I dedicate this to Eumir, Hergie, and Carlo. I feel sad for them but I'm using it as my motivation to make up for their losses),\" Villegas told One News.\n\nAssured of at least a bronze hours after Yulo got the Philippines to the medal board with his floor exercise gold, Villegas can upgrade her medal to a sure silver if she beats Turkey's Buse Naz Cakiroglu in the semifinals early Wednesday (PH time) as action shifts to the iconic Roland Garros Stadium in downtown Paris.\n\nUnlike Villegas, Cakiroglu entered the semifinals smoothly with a unanimous decision win over Finland's Pihla Kaivo-Oja.\n\nYulo's gold enabled the Philippines to beat all its Southeast Asian neighbors to the medal table.\n\nIt was the Philippines' first medal in Paris and the first of any color from a gymnast.\n\nA total of 58 nations were already on the medal board as of 3 a.m. Sunday - from leader China's 16-11-9 gold-silver-bronze to a lone bronze apiece by bottom countries Austria, Egypt, Jamaica, Lithuania, Portugal, and Slovakia.\n\nThe Philippines was in the company of Argentina, Ecuador, Slovenia, Serbia and Uganda with a lone medal (gold) to show since the quadrennial Games opened on July 26.\n\nThe United States had climbed to No. 2 with 12-21-20, France to No. 3 with 12-14-15 and Australia dropped to fourth from No. 2 with 12-7-5.\n\nGreat Britain remained fifth at 10-10-12, while Asian nations Republic of Korea (9-7-5) and Japan (8-5-9) occupy sixth and seventh.\n\nHero's welcome\n\nThe City of Manila, meanwhile, is preparing a hero's welcome for the Filipino Paris Olympics gold medalist.\n\nMayor Honey Lacuna said Sunday the city will give a huge welcome for Yulo, an Outstanding Manilan awardee.\n\n\"The City of Manila is already preparing a hero's welcome for Carlos Yulo because we are immensely proud of our Manile\u00f1o from Leveriza, Malate,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe city government will also award the golden boy financial reward and other recognition.\n\n\"The grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians. When we meet him, we will present Carlos Yulo cash incentives, awards, and symbols of the eternal gratitude of the proud Capital City of the Philippines,\" she said.\n\nLast May, the City Council adopted Resolution No. 388, recognizing Yulo and his younger brother, Karl Eldrew, for their victories at the Artistic Gymnastics Asian Championships in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. / PNA", "source": {"uri": Carlos Edriel Yulo of Philippines reacts after performing in the floor exercise finals.\n\nCarlos Yulo has a chance to achieve what no one has done before in Philippines' Olympic history: bag two gold medals in a single Summer Games appearance.\n\nThe 24-year-old Filipino gymnast, who is probably still on a high following his gold medal run in the floor finals just last night, will attempt to secure another medal when he sees action in the men's vault finals on Sunday at 10:24 p.m. at the Bercy Arena.\n\nA little over 24 hours removed from his breathtaking 15.000-point showing on the floor, Yulo will look to further etch his name in the history as he plunges into the vault finals, which will see him go up against tough competitors.\n\nYulo finished sixth during the qualification round with 14.683 markers, but enough to qualify for the finals alongside seven other gymnasts, which include Filipino-British Jake Jarman.\n\nJarman, who bagged the bronze medal during the floor
