{"uri": "8258849476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:10:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:10:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:09:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/paris-olympics/314480433/yulo-set-for-windfall-after-golden-performance-in-paris-olympics.html", "title": "Yulo set for windfall after golden performance in Paris Olympics - Manila Standard", "body": "Carlos Yulo stands to receive an impressive array of incentives, potentially totaling up to P47 million in cash and other rewards, following his historic performance at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nYulo made history by becoming the first Filipino gymnast to secure a podium finish and the second Filipino athlete to bag a gold at the Summer Games.\n\nYulo's gold medal in the men's floor exercise, earned with a score of 15.000 points at the Bercy Arena, entitles him to P10 million under Republic Act 10699, the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits Act. In addition, the Manny V. Pangilinan Sports Foundation is expected to award him another P10 million in cash bonuses for his stellar performance.\n\nBeyond the monetary prizes, Yulo will receive a fully furnished two-bedroom unit in McKinley Hill, valued at P24 million, from Megaworld. The 24-year-old gymnast, who triumphed over defending gold medalist Artem Dolgopyat of Israel and Great Britain's Jake Jarman, will also receive P3 million from the House of Representatives.\n\nMoreover, Yulo is set to enjoy free meals for life, courtesy of Vikings Buffet and Restaurant, which offers a lifetime buffet to any Filipino medalist in the Paris Games. His association with sports betting app Arena Plus, where he serves as a brand ambassador, could also bring additional surprise rewards.\n\nHe is also set to receive cash incentives from the Philippine Olympic Committee and a personal gift of a house and lot in Tagaytay from POC president Bambol Tolentino.\n\nThe scale of Yulo's incentives mirrors the significant rewards received by previous Filipino Olympic champions. Weightlifting star Hidilyn Diaz, for instance, accumulated over P50 million in rewards following her gold medal win at the Tokyo Games in 2021. Her prizes included cash, properties, and a lifetime of free flights, with contributions from notable figures such as San Miguel Corp.'s Ramon Ang and businessman Dennis Uy.\n\nYulo isn't finished yet as he looks forward to another podium finish in the vault apparatus.\n\nBoxer Aira Villegas is also set to receive cash incentives and other bonuses since she is already assured of a boxing bronze. Villegas earned a close victory over France's Wassila Lkhadiri in the women's flyweight boxing quarterfinals, with three judges scoring the match 29-28 in her favor. She will receive her rewards under Republic Act 10699. Villegas will go for the finals or a sure silver medal if she hurdles the semifinals.", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Standard"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8259955331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:07:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:07:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:06:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/manila-homecoming-parade-paris-olympics-gold-medalist-carlos-yulo/", "title": "'Hero's parade' awaits Olympic champion Carlos Yulo in hometown Manila", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - The city of Manila is preparing to roll out a grand parade to welcome home Carlos Yulo, the country's newest sporting hero who wrote history by winning two gold medals in gymnastics at the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn a statement on Monday, August 5, Manila Mayor Honey Lacuna announced that the city government was planning a \"hero's parade for Caloy Yulo,\" a native Manile\u00f1o who grew up in Leveriza Street in Malate.\n\nLacuna said Manila's anticipated red-carpet welcome for the Olympic champion was \"our way of paying tribute to Caloy's greatness.\"\n\nIt was a weekend to remember for Yulo and the Philippines as the 24-year-old athlete clinched the country's first gold medal at the Paris Games on Saturday, August 3, during the men's artistic gymnastics floor exercise final. Then claimed another gold less than 24 hours later on Sunday, August 4, during the vault final event.\n\n\"Wala po kaming pagsidlan ng tuwa para kay Carlos Edriel Yulo sa kanyang pambihirang tagumpay sa pagkamit ang dalawang gintong medalya sa Paris Olympics 2024 (We can't contain our happiness for Carlos Edriel Yulo for achieving an outstanding victory of winning two gold medals at the Paris Olympics 2024),\" Lacuna said.\n\n\"By achieving this incredible feat, Carlos Yulo has forever etched his name in the annals of Philippine and Asian sports,\" she added.\n\nThe date and route for the homecoming parade have yet to be finalized, said the mayor.\n\nBut in the city's initial plan, Lacuna said the parade may start at Leveriza Street in Malate, \"where it all began...where Caloy grew up.\" The parade may then traverse near Malaca\u00f1ang and the University Belt, and end at the Manila City Hall, where the city will honor Yulo with cash incentives and the like.\n\nThe city government also plans to coordinate with the Department of Education and private schools in Manila so students can witness the parade.\n\n\"This way, what they only see on TV, they can experience up close,\" Lacuna said. \"Caloy's victory will serve as an inspiration for them to discover more Carlos Yulos among the youth of Manila and the entire Philippines.\"\n\nYulo was born and raised in the capital city. He grew up in Leveriza St, a stone's throw from the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex (RMSC).\n\nAt seven years old, after being discovered tumbling at a playground, Yulo was brought by his grandfather to the Gymnastics Association of the Philippines inside the RMSC to train formally. The prodigy started competing in 2008.\n\nYulo would then win several gold medals at the Palarong Pambansa, the Southeast Asian Games, the Asian Artistic Gymnastics Championships, the World Artistic Carlos Edriel Yulo of Philippines in action. REUTERS/Hannah Mckay\n\nCarlos Yulo is no doubt the Philippines' greatest gymnast after winning two gold medals in a single Olympic appearance during the ongoing 2024 Paris Games.\n\nBut the country's golden boy is hoping he won't be the last one.\n\nThe 24-year-old gymnast said he is expecting that his recent feats -- gold medals in the men's floor exercise and men's vault events -- will inspire the younger generation to try the sport and emerge as the future stars who can follow the trail he blazed.\n\n\"Syempre sa gymnastics, mas gusto ko na lumaki 'yung gymnastics sa Pilipinas,\" Yulo shared shortly after receiving his second Olympic gold medal on early Monday.\n\n\"Gusto ko i-try ng mga kids po 'yung gymnastics. Gano'n po 'yung gusto ko.\"\n\n[Of course, I want gymnastics to grow in the Philippines... I want kids to try gymnastics, that's what I would like.]\n\nThe future of Philippine gymnastics is actually already in good hands.\n\nAside from Yulo, several young talents have started to show off their wares in various international tournaments, including the 2023 Southeast Asian Games where the country copped three gold medals and two silvers.\n\n21-year-old Ivan Cruz, a second cousin of Yulo, impressed in his SEA Games debut last year in Cambodia and won the floor gold medal while another budding gymnast Juancho Miguel Besana ruled the vault event.\n\nTogether, they also teamed up with Yulo to bag the silver medal in the men's team all-around event.\n\nAside from them, Yulo's own younger brother, Eldrew, is also starting to make a name for himself after completing a six-gold medal sweep during the 2023 Palarong Pambansa. {"uri": "8259368134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:38:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:38:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:37:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/philippine-gymnast-carlos-yulo-secures-historic-olympic-gold-rewarded-with-hk1-75m-apartment-and-luxuries/", "title": "Philippine gymnast Carlos Yulo secures historic Olympic gold, rewarded with HK$1.75m, apartment and luxuries - Dimsum Daily", "body": "5th August 2024 - (Manila) Beyond just elevating himself to Philippines national hero status, Carlos Yulo's historic Olympic gold has triggered a cascade of rewards from the public and private sector. Yulo earned the country its inaugural Olympic gold in gymnastics and only the second gold ever, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz at the Tokyo Games.\n\nIn recognition of his unparalleled accomplishment, a slew of local brands and even national institutions have showered Yulo with lavish rewards.\n\nThe Philippine government has said it would award the 24-year-old PHP 10 million (HK$1.35 million), fulfilling its pledge to any athlete who brought home a gold.\n\nThe country's restaurants are rolling out the red carpet, offering their hero lifetime free buffets. Vikings, tabbed for its elaborate global cuisine spreads, has made one offer, while Yulo could also savour limitless food and drinks at Tipsy Pig branches and free meals at a number of other restaurants if he wants. The engineering construction company NEXA committing to providing him with a lifetime of free engineering design services.\n\nYulo will also get a fully-furnished two-bedroom condo unit - worth PHP 24 million - in McKinley Hill, the largest development in Metro Manila.\n\nAnd with free furniture worth up to 100,000 pesos from Apollo Home Depot, he'll have a luxurious haven in which to bask in his Olympic glory.\n\nIn fact, he might not even need the house and lot the Philippine Olympic Committee is offering him.\n\nYulo's holistic rewards encompass every need, with renowned medic Dr Virgil Lo vowing to provide the gymnastics ace with free gastro consults and colonoscopies for life.\n\nExtending into all possible facets of his life, Yulo has also earned a lifetime free engineering design from Nexa Engineering and university credits from the University of Mindanao.\n\nTo top off his already stellar haul, the Philippines House of Representatives is adding a PHP 3 million cherry on top for Yulo.\n\n\"In recognition of his historic accomplishment, the House of Representatives is honoured to award Carlos Yulo P3,000,000. This reward reflects our support for his continued success and our commitment to fostering Filipino talent on the international stage,\" chairman of the House Committee Elizaldy Co said.\n\nAccording to the Philippines' \" National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act,\" athletes who secure a gold medal are entitled to 10 million pesos (approximately 1.35 million Hong Kong dollars), while silver and bronze medalists receive 5 million and 2 million pesos respectively. Additionally, the Philippine House of Representatives has announced that they will award Carlos Yulo with a bonus of 3 million pesos (around 400,000 Hong Kong dollars).", "source": {"uri": Elizaldy Co (Ako Bicol).\n\nRELATED: Epic prize for an epic feat: P35.5M, house and lot await Olympic gold medalist Hidilyn Diaz\n\nApart from this, Yulo will also be granted with P10 million as mandated by Republic Act 10699 or the Sports Benefits and Incentives Act of 2001.\n\nEnacted in 2015, the act mandates a P10 million cash prize and Olympic Gold Medal of Valor for gold medalists at the Olympic Games.\n\nRELATED: ICTSI offers P5 million for athletics gold\n\nReal estate giant Megaworld Corp. said on its Facebook page shortly after Yulo's win that he would be given with a fully furnished two-bedroom condominium unit in McKinley Hill in Taguig worth P24 million.\n\nYulo is expected to get more prizes, just like weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who bagged the Philippines' first-ever gold during the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.\n\nDiaz's prizes after winning the gold in 2020 included P10 million as mandated by law and additional pledges from various individuals, including business tycoons and sports patrons Manny V. {"uri": "8260126148", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:54:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:54:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:53:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/filipino-olympian-carlos-yulo-showered-with-luxury-condo-cash-rewards-for-historic-double-gold/", "title": "Filipino Olympian Carlos Yulo showered with luxury condo, cash rewards for historic double gold", "body": "5th August 2024 - (Paris) Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo has secured two gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics, cementing his status as a national hero and inspiring a wave of pride across the Philippines.\n\nThe 24-year-old gymnast's historic achievement has earned him a flurry of rewards and accolades from the government and local brands, including a three-bedroom condominium, thousands of dollars in cash incentives, and a lifetime supply of free ramen.\n\nYulo's first gold medal came in the men's floor exercise, where he edged out defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel by a mere 0.034 of a point. His second gold followed in the men's vault event, where he scored an average of 15.116, outperforming Armenia's Artur Davtyan and Britain's Harry Hepworth.\n\n\"I was just hoping to perform well. I didn't really expect a medal,\" Yulo had told reporters prior to the competition, reflecting his humble approach. \"It really felt like a bonus for me. It's crazy, because last night I couldn't sleep. I was so hyped because I had won that gold medal the day before.\"\n\nYulo's double gold feat has sparked a nationwide celebration, with the Philippine government and local brands rushing to shower the young gymnast with rewards and recognition. The government has pledged to award him 10 million Philippine pesos (approximately $173,300), while the House of Representatives has promised an additional 6 million pesos in cash incentives.\n\nFurthermore, a real estate firm has offered Yulo a fully furnished three-bedroom condominium unit at the prestigious McKinley Hill development in metropolitan Manila. Medical clinics and universities have also joined the bandwagon, offering him free lifetime consultations and university credits.\n\nThe capital city of Manila is preparing a \"hero's welcome\" for Yulo, with Mayor Honey Lacuna stating, \"The grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians. When we meet him, we will present Carlos Yulo cash incentives, awards and symbols of the eternal gratitude of the proud capital city of the Philippines.\"\n\nYulo's achievement has also made him a social media sensation, with his countrymen expressing their pride and adoration on the platform formerly known as X. \"Another gold for the Philippines! History is made again! girlfriend", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Team Philippines' Carlos Yulo savored his gold medal in the Paris Olympics 2024 men's artistic gymnastics floor exercises with someone dear to him.\n\nChloe Anjeleigh San Jose, Yulo's girlfriend, posted a fun interaction between her and the Philippines' first Olympic gymnastics gold medalist following the \"Uy, Philippines!\" trend.\n\n\"We did it all in God's name!\" wrote San Jose with a gold medal emoji to match.\n\nSan Jose has been highly supportive of Yulo, serving as his number one fan in the stands.\n\nSaturday at Bercy Arena was no different as San Jose was in attendance to watch Yulo's crowning moment as Team Philippines' first gold medalist in the Paris Games.\n\nMore than just a partner, San Jose also served as Yulo's best friend in Paris, even posting how Yulo spends a day in Paris en route to his historic performance.\n\nSan Jose will continue to support her Olympian partner on Sunday night (Manila time).\n\nYulo gets a crack at finishing with double medals later this evening when he competes in vault.", "source": {"uri": "sports.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8258948183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:58:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:58:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:57:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/05/news/headlines-yulo-gifts-ph-with-2nd-gold-august-5-2024/1961887", "title": "HEADLINES: Yulo gifts PH with 2nd gold | August 5, 2024", "body": "UN ramps up assistance to survivors of Papua New Guinea massacre\n\nGood day. Here are the stories for The Manila Times for Monday, August 5, 2024.\n\nToday's episode is brought to you by Wilcon Depot, The Philippines' leading home improvement and construction supplies retailer -- your Trusted Building Partner.\n\nREAD: Yulo gifts PH with 2nd gold\n\nGYMNAST Carlos \"Caloy\" Yulo has cemented his status as the greatest Filipino Olympian. About 24 hours after ruling the floor exercise final, Yulo conquered the vault competition at the Paris Olympics men's artistics gymnastics, emerging as the first Filipino Olympic multi-gold medalist at the Bercy Arena on Sunday night, Aug. 4 (Manila time). His confidence through the roof after delivering the Philippines first gymnastics Olympic medal on Saturday, the 4-foot-11 dynamo unleashed his magic anew to top the vault with an average score of 15.116 points. The 24-year-old dazzled with a high-level execution of dragulescu pike in his first vault, just needing a little hop to gain balance after his landing and netting 15.433 points -- 6.000 in difficulty and 9.433 in execution. Fourth to perform in the final, Yulo then executed a kasamatsu double in his second vault, which was not as good as his first vault but still solid for 14.800 points -- 5.600 in difficulty and 9.200 in execution. After each vault, Yulo, as he has been all tournament, threw his fists into the air in high satisfaction of his performance. When the last four performers wound up with lower scores, Yulo was once again in disbelief after pulling off an Olympic feat no other Filipino athlete has done before. With Yulo's two-gold haul, the Philippines will finish the Paris Games with at least four medals, the other two being guaranteed bronzes - one each for Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas. When Yulo comes home to the Philippines, he will get more than a hero's welcome -- he stands to receive at least 23 million pesos in incentives from the government and a posh condominium worth 24 million pesos from real estate giant Megaworld. A day before winning his second gold, Yulo delivered a dazzling performance that netted him 15.0 points and the gold medal at the Paris Olympics men's gymnastics floor exercise at the Bercy Arena on Saturday evening, August 3 (Manila time). The gold was the first medal for the Philippines in Olympic gymnastics.\n\nSPORTS: Obiena vies for medal in Paris Games\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nERNEST John \"EJ\" Obiena of the Philippines shoots for a medal as he competes at the Paris Olympics men's pole vault final at the Stade de France early Tuesday, August 6 (Manila time). The championship round is set at 1 a.m. here in Manila as Obiena tries to become the first Filipino medalist in Olympic athletics in 88 years. Miguel White was the last Filipino to have clinched a medal in Olympic athletics, claiming a bronze in the men's 400-m hurdles at the 1936 Berlin Games. Obiena also looks to follow the lead of gymnast Carlos Yulo who clinched the men's floor exercise gold medal on Saturday night, August 3, and boxer Aira Villegas who secured a bronze medal in the women's 50 kg after her quarterfinal victory early Sunday, August 4.\n\nREAD: Garcia dares critics: Shed parliamentary immunity\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn other news, Commission on Elections (Comelec) Chairman George Erwin Garcia has challenged his critics to shed their parliamentary immunity by putting their allegations under oath. Sagip party-list Rep. Rodante Marcoleta and former Caloocan City representative Edgar Erice claimed that a Comelec official they did not name has 49 offshore accounts in 18 banks where supposed bribe money amounting to almost 1 billion pesos was deposited. They also alleged that the same official owned accounts in six local banks. Last week, Marcoleta named Garcia as the owner of two accounts in a New York bank where he claimed they were able to have deposited $100 each in two separate offshore accounts in the name of the Comelec chief.\n\nREAD: PCSO chief sues vlogger in US court\n\nPHILIPPINE Charity Sweepstakes Office (PCSO) General Manager Melquiades Robles has filed defamation and invasion of privacy charges against vlogger Claire Contreras, known as \"Maharlika,\" before a United States court. In a press conference on Sunday, Robles said he decided to file the cyber complaints before the Central District Court of California after Contreras allegedly maligned his family in her vlogs. Robles said he and his wife, Sherwil, went to the US late last June to sue Contreras to \"stop her from continuously harassing and maligning\" them through her online vlog. Contreras, said to be a US citizen, has been dubbed as the \"queen of fake news\" by many social media users because of her criticisms against the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and other government officials. Robles said that for almost a year now, he and his family have been subjected by Contreras \"to an almost daily barrage of vicious, unjustifiable and blatantly false attacks through her YouTube channel called 'Boldyak' TV.\"\n\nREAD: 'Govt spends nearly P500M for VP security'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTHE government has spent nearly 500 million pesos for Vice President Sara Duterte's 433 security details, Presidential Adviser on Poverty Alleviation Larry Gadon said Sunday. He claimed that the vice president has maintained 433 security personnel for the past two years, each earning an estimated salary of 50,000 pesos monthly. Gadon also cited online data showing that the Office of the Vice President (OVP) spent 55 million pesos from 2022 to 2024 on special duty allowances for military and uniformed personnel. The presidential anti-poverty adviser told The Manila Times that he would have kept quiet on this issue if not for the \"ridiculous exaggeration of some people like Sen. Ronald 'Bato' de la Rosa calling on private citizen groups to augment the security of VP Sara as if there is a constant, imminent grave threat and danger to her life.\"\n\nBUSINESS: Growth likely higher in Q2\n\nOver to business, healthy domestic demand and increased government spending likely boosted economic growth in the second quarter, analysts said, while inflation could have breached the target last month due to higher energy and food costs. Consumer price growth figures for July will be released by the Philippine Statistics Authority on Tuesday, to be followed by preliminary gross domestic product (GDP) growth data for the April to June period on Thursday. Both indicators will be considered by monetary authorities when they meet next week to discuss whether to start cutting key interest rates. The median GDP growth estimate is 6.0 percent for the April to June period, an improvement from the first quarter's 5.7 percent and within the government's downwardly revised 6.0- to 7.0-percent target for this year. Inflation, meanwhile, is expected to have risen to 4.1 percent in July from 3.7 percent a month earlier.\n\nREAD: Opinion and editorial\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRigoberto Tiglao, Fr. Ranhilio Aquino and Francisco Tatad are today's front page columnists. Tiglao cited a close friend's former partner that President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is an actual cocaine user, Fr. Aquino talks about the start of a new school year, and Tatad asks for a peace plan.\n\nToday's editorial believes that gender is not the issue in the latest women's boxing controversy at the Paris Olympics. {"uri": "8260165113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:19:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:19:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:18:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/incentives-continue-to-pour-for-philippine-gymnast-carlos-yulo-after-double-gold-feat", "title": "Incentives continue to pour for Philippine gymnast Carlos Yulo after double gold feat", "body": "MANILA - Philippine gymnast Carlos Yulo is set for a major windfall with his unprecedented success in the Paris Olympics, having become the first Filipino to win a pair of gold medals in the Summer Games.\n\nHis incentives from his gold medal haul are expected to continue to increase, if not double, as more private companies pitch in to reward the most successful Olympian the Philippines has ever produced after his gold medal win in vault on Aug 4.\n\nAs of Aug 5, Yulo is already guaranteed 32 million pesos (S$732,000) in cash incentives - with 26 million pesos from the government and 6 million pesos from private companies - and a three-bedroom condo unit.\n\nHe also doubled his incentive from the House of Representatives as he is now to receive a total of 6 million pesos - 3 million pesos for each of the gold medals he won - according to House Speaker Martin Romualdez.\n\n\"We want to make sure that they are equally inspired and equally acknowledged and rewarded for their achievements,\" Mr Romauldez told the beat reporters.\n\nProperty developer Megaworld, which had promised to give an Olympic medalist a fully-furnished two-bedroom unit worth P24 million in McKinley Hill, upgraded Yulo's prize to a three-bedroom unit worth a million pesos with appliances, furniture, fixtures, two balconies, and a parking lot.\n\n\"Since this is a very significant milestone in the history of Philippine sports to have two gold Olympic medals during our 100th year participation as a country in the Olympics, which also coincides with our company's 35th anniversary this year,\" said Megaworld president Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso in a statement.\n\nOther corporations also committed to gift Yulo 3 million pesos in cash.\n\nAs a Filipino brand, we believe in celebrating and supporting our homegrown talent, and this reward is a testament to our admiration for Carlos. We hope his success will inspire the next generation of Filipino athletes to pursue their dreams with the same passion and determination,\" said chicken wholesaler Bounty Fresh executive Patricia Cheng-Lim.\n\nBounty has been supporting Filipino athletes since 2016 including Tokyo Games bronze medallist and boxer Eumir Marcial and gave Chooks-to-Go roast chicken stores to former Olympians Onyok Velasco and Roel Velasco.\n\nPhilippine Olympic Committee president Bambol Tolentino is also rewarding the the winners in Paris Olympics with a house and lot like what he did for Diaz and 2020 Tokyo Olympics silver medalists Nesthy Petecio and Carlo Paalam, and bronze medalist Eumir Marcial.\n\nYulo may also get a \"Senate Medal of Excellence\" as filed by Senate Majority Leader Francis Tolentino on Aug 5.\n\nLifetime benefits await Yulo with restaurants like Vikings and Tipsy Pig extending free meals.\n\nMore is expected to pour in the coming days for Yulo, who stands alone in the country's history, with other brands like Milo, which has been supporting grassroots sports in the country, posting a heartfelt message about the gymnast's greatness.\n\nWhen Tokyo 2020 weightlifting champion Hidilyn Diaz ended the 97-year gold medal drought of the Philippines, she received over 50 million in incentives including several houses and lots, condo units, lifetime of free flights, gasoline, and other products.\n\nAside from monetary incentives, Yulo is also set for a hero's welcome in his hometown in Manila.\n\nThe remaining Filipino athletes including semi-finalists Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas and pole vault finalist EJ Obiena also have a chance to receive a cash incentive depending on their rankings.\n\nCoaches of the medallists will also receive a cash incentive as long as they have trained the athlete for more than six months. {"uri": "8259671810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:04:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:04:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:03:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/news/314480593/carlos-yulo-to-receive-medal-of-excellence-from-the-senate.html", "title": "Carlos Yulo to receive 'Medal of Excellence' from the Senate - Manila Standard", "body": "Senate President Pro Tempore Jinggoy Estrada on Monday sought the Senate commendation for 'Golden Boy' Carlos Yulo after winning two consecutive gold medals in the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nEstrada filed Senate Resolution 1103 conferring Yulo with the \"Senate Medal of Excellence,\" the highest expression of national appreciation for his outstanding achievement of being the first-ever Filipino athlete to achieve such a feat in the world's biggest sporting event.\n\nApproved on August 23, 2021, Senate Resolution No. 1103 created the Philippine Senate Medal of Excellence. This medal is intended to express the nation's gratitude to Filipinos for their exceptional achievements and the honor they have brought to the country, such as an Olympic medal.\n\nThe resolution noted that Yulo's outstanding achievement at the 2024 Paris Olympics should be celebrated by the entire nation as it is a testament to the excellent skill and unyielding spirit of the Filipinos.\n\n\"His glorious success is a shining example of what hard work, discipline, perseverance, and commitment to excellence can accomplish,\" Estrada said in his resolution.\n\nEstrada stressed Yulo's outstanding performances in various international competitions consistently demonstrate his expertise in the sport, prolific artistry, and resilience.\n\nHe added that the world-class gymnast brought immense pride, joy, and honor to the Filipino nation, truly deserving of the Senate's highest commendation.\n\nBefore his historic achievement in the Paris Olympics, Yulo was already a two-time world champion.\n\nHe won gold medals in the men's vault event at the FIG Artistic Gymnastics World Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan in 2021, and in the men's floor exercise in Stuttgart, Germany in 2019.\n\nDubbed as the \"Golden Boy,\" he has won the Asian championship 10 times and the Southeast Asian (SEA) Games nine times.\n\nYulo is the second Filipino to ever win an Olympic gold medal, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics. Furthermore, he is the first Filipino athlete to win multiple medals in a single Summer Games appearance.\n\nYulo cemented himself as one of the most successful and accomplished athletes in Philippine sports, rightfully earning his spot in the pantheon of the nation's greatest sports heroes, said Estrada.\n\nThe 24-year-old decorated gymnast from Manila is the first Filipino to win a gold medal in the ongoing Summer Olympics in Paris, ruling the men's artistic floor exercise finals in Bercy Arena on August 3, 2024, Estrada said in a separate Senate Resolution No. 1098.\n\nYulo bagged another gold medal in the men's artistic gymnastics vault finals the following day, besting competitors from Armenia, Great Britain, Croatia, Ukraine, and Iran.\n\nHis back-to-back wins significantly elevated the Philippines' standing in the Games of the XXXIII Olympiad from rank 32nd to the top 19 best-performing country as of August 4, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", His glorious success is a shining example of what hard work, discipline, perseverance, and commitment to excellence can accomplish,\" Estrada said in his Senate Resolution No. 1103.\n\nEstrada said Yulo's outstanding performances in various international competitions consistently demonstrate his expertise in the sport, prolific artistry, and resilience.\n\nHe added that the world-class gymnast has brought immense pride, joy, and honor to the Filipino nation, truly deserving of the Senate's highest commendation.\n\nBefore his historic achievement in the Paris Olympics, Yulo had already become a two-time world champion. He won gold medals in the men's vault event at the FIG Artistic Gymnastics World Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan in 2021, and in the men's floor exercise in Stuttgart, Germany in 2019.\n\nDubbed as the \"Golden Boy,\" he has won the Asian championship ten times and the Southeast Asian (SEA) Games nine times.\n\nYulo is the second Filipino to ever win an Olympic gold medal, after weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz-Naranjo in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics. Furthermore, he is the first Filipino athlete to win multiple medals in a single Summer Games appearance.\n\nYulo cemented himself as one of the most successful and accomplished athletes in Philippine sports, rightfully earning his spot in the pantheon of the nation's greatest sports heroes, said Estrada.\n\nApproved on August 23, 2021, Senate Resolution No. 110 created the Philippine Senate Medal of Excellence. decorated gymnast from Manila is the first Filipino to win a gold medal in the ongoing Summer Olympics in Paris, ruling the men's artistic floor exercise finals in Bercy Arena on August 3, 2024, Estrada said in a separate Senate Resolution No. 1098.\n\nYulo bagged another gold medal in the men's artistic gymnastics vault finals the following day, besting competitors from Armenia, the United Kingdom, Croatia, Ukraine, and Iran.\n\nHis back-to-back win significantly elevated the Philippines' standing in the Games of the XXXIII Olympiad from rank 32nd to the top 19 best-performing country {"uri": "8259694554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:19:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:19:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/inside-track/after-last-supper-row-filipino-catholics-celebrate-carlos-yulo/", "title": "After 'Last Supper' row, Filipino Catholics celebrate Carlos Yulo", "body": "'All God,' says Carlos Yulo, the first Olympic double-gold medalist in this predominantly Catholic country\n\nMore than a week ago, it seemed like the 2024 Paris Olympics heralded the Apocalypse.\n\nRemember when Catholics lashed out over a controversial Olympics skit that was said to resemble the Last Supper? It was a mockery of the Christian faith, they protested, condemning the presentation that included drag queens and a transgender model.\n\nWell, who doesn't like a redemption story -- how a young David can avenge their faith for all the world to witness?\n\nAfter raising hell over the Last Supper controversy, many Filipino Catholics hailed one of their own -- 24-year-old gymnast Carlos Yulo -- who won two gold medals over the weekend. He was the first double-gold medalist from Asia's biggest predominantly Catholic country, where more than 85 million people, or nearly 79% of the population, belong to the Catholic Church.\n\nThey pointed out how Yulo prayed before the Olympic games, made the sign of the cross, and attributed his victory to Divine Providence, declaring it was \"all God.\" In an interview with ABS-CBN News, Yulo said, \"God is really great, I'm so blessed by Him, and I'm well-protected and guided.\"\n\nThe famous National Shrine of Saint Padre Pio in Santo Tomas, Batangas, called Yulo a \"champion in God's heart.\"\n\nYulo, whom the shrine described as a \"proud Catholic,\" is \"an example of a faithful servant who always returns his glory to God.\" They said, \"May all of us continue to glorify God in all our battles in life.\"\n\nThe Facebook page Servant Chronicles, which has 302,000 followers, declared in a tribute to Yulo, \"To god be all the glory!\"\n\nThe page Millennial Catholics, which has 229,000 followers, said blessings abound for people like Yulo who know how to thank God. They also reposted a video of Yulo holding his second gold medal and pointing to the heavens: \"All God, all God. All God, all Him.\"\n\nThe Secular Male Institute of the Two Hearts of Jesus and Mary quoted the book of the Prophet Isaiah (60:22): \"When the time is right, I, the Lord, will make it happen.\"\n\nIndividual users, in public Facebook posts, also celebrated Yulo's victory while recalling the controversial Olympic skit.\n\nRyan Borja Capitulo said he \"was ready to forget about the Paris 2024 Olympics due to its numerous controversies,\" but the sign of the cross made by Yulo \"changed all that.\" He said, \"Thank you, Caloy, for giving honor to God and our Catholic faith on the Olympic stage! Thank you for giving honor to the Philippines! We are proud of you!\"\n\nWema Mojar praised Yulo's victory \"despite how woke and pagan\" the Olympics can be. \"All by the grace of God!\"\n\nCharles Legaspi also pointed out how Yulo made the sign of the cross. He said that in the face of \"the circus and controversy\" during the 2024 Olympics, \"it is truly refreshing to see a man who gratefully reveres the Lord winning the gold.\"\n\nIncidentally, the Philippines' first Olympic gold medalist, Hidilyn Diaz, is also known for her deep Catholic faith. {"uri": "8258062384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "02:13:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T02:13:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T02:09:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/filipino-gymnast-carlos-yulo-makes-history-with-gold-in-mens-floor-exercise-at-2024-paris-olympics/", "title": "Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo makes history with gold in men's floor exercise at 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "4th August 2024 - (Paris) Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo etched his name in Olympic history by clinching the gold medal in the men's artistic gymnastics floor exercise final. The 24-year-old athlete's emotional victory at the Bercy Arena marked a significant milestone for the Philippines, securing only the second Olympic gold in the country's history.\n\nYulo's triumphant performance on Saturday resonated deeply as he tearfully celebrated his achievement, mirroring the elation felt across his nation. His flawless routine culminated in a confident landing, earning him a commendable score of 15.000 points and securing the Philippines' first-ever gymnastics Olympic medal.\n\nThe victory was particularly poignant as Yulo's gold medal mirrored the success of weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, who had triumphed at the delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Yulo's dedication and unwavering focus were evident as he executed his routine with precision and grace, surpassing his qualifying score with a remarkable display of athleticism.\n\nIn a competitive field that included defending champion Artem Dolgopyat of Israel and Britain's Jake Jarman, Yulo's performance shone brightly, capturing the hearts of spectators and judges alike. Dolgopyat, who clinched the silver medal, acknowledged the challenges he had faced in preparation, emphasizing the resilience and determination required to excel at the highest level of competition.\n\nAs Yulo basked in the glory of his gold medal win, he expressed gratitude for the support he had received and credited his faith for guiding him through his remarkable performance.", {"uri": "8257910716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "21:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T21:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T21:55:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/08/03/yulo-triumph-sends-phl-to-no-33", "title": "Yulo triumph sends Phl to No. 33", "body": "Philippines' Carlos Edriel Yulo celebrates winning the gold medal during the podium ceremony for the artistic gymnastics men's floor exercise during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Bercy Arena in Paris, on August 3, 2024. Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP\n\nCarlos Yulo's golden triumph in the final round of the men's floor exercise event had sent the Philippines flying into the medal table of the Paris Olympics.\n\nAt the close of the eighth day of action on Saturday, the Filipinos climbed to No. 33, becoming the first Southeast Asian country to win an Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe Filipinos share the 33rd spot with Argentina, Ecuador, Slovenia, Serbia and Uganda, while other Asian countries like North Korea (No. 40), Mongolia (No. 45), India (No. 50), and Tajikistan and Chinese Taipei (No. 51) are several notches below.\n\nChina remains at the top with 16 gold, 11 silver, and nine bronze medals, while host France and Australia hold the second and third spots with 12 mints apiece in this 206-nation competition.\n\nThe United States, the reigning Olympic champion, is at fourth with 11 gold, 20 silver, and 20 bronze medals for a tournament-leading 51 total medals.\n\nSouth Korea and Japan round out the Asian invasion in the top 10 with eight and six gold medals, respectively, while Hong Kong is at No. 17 with two mints.\n\nYulo's gold medal is the country's second in its 100 years of participation in the Summer Games.\n\nIn the previous Olympics in Tokyo three years ago, the Filipinos finished their campaign with a gold medal from weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, silver medals from boxers Nesthy Petecio and Carlo Paalam, and bronze medal from boxer Eumir Marcial to emerge at No. 50 in the medal ranking.\n\nThe Philippines, however, still has a chance to further increase its medal production in the ongoing Games as Yulo still has a chance for a golden double when he sees action in the vault, while boxers Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas, as well as pole vaulter Ernest Pangilinan Sports Foundation will double, if not add more, to the P10-million incentive a Filipino Olympic gold medalist will receive from the government by law through the Expanded Athletes' Incentives Act, which means that's instantly an easy P20 million for Yulo.\n\n\"In the past, MVPSF has matched the government incentive,\" a source told The STAR Sunday.\n\nThe same source said it will be no less than Filipino businessman and avid sports patron Manny V. {"uri": "2024-08-444008447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:58:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:58:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:58:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578373/senator-wants-medal-of-excellence-for-yulo-hails-his-golden-wins", "title": "Senator wants 'medal of excellence' for Yulo", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo may just get the prestigious \"Senate Medal of Excellence\" for his historic golden victories at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics.\n\nThis is because Senate Majority Leader Francis Tolentino filed on Monday a resolution seeking to bestow upon Yulo the medal of excellence from the upper chamber to honor his accomplishments. He also filed another resolution hailing Yulo.\n\nIn his Senate Resolution No. 1106, Tolentino said the Senate Medal of Excellence recognizes, honors, and commends outstanding Filipinos for their exemplary service, exceptional achievements, and invaluable contributions to nation-building.\n\nThe other measure - Senate Resolution No. 1102 - acknowledged Yulo's victory as a \"historic first\" for Philippine Gymnastics.\n\n\"[The] Senate Medal of Excellence can be conferred upon Filipinos like Carlos Edriel Poquiz Yulo for his exceptional achievement [of] winning two Olympic gold medals,\" Senate Resolution No. 1106 states.\n\nTolentino, however, pointed out that even before Yulo's momentous Olympic wins, the Filipino gymnast already made history by being the first Filipino and male Southeast Asian gymnast to get a medal at the World Artistic Gymnastics Championships in 2018 and the first Filipino and Southeast Asian to win a gold medal in the same criteria in 2019 also at the World Artistic Gymnastics Championships.\n\nREAD: Carlos Yulo's Olympic gold medal haul caps decade of struggle\n\n\"Yulo's skills, consistency, and determination are exceptional qualities that would serve as an inspiration and good example not only to our youth but for every Filipino to continue striving for growth and development to become the best in their chosen field,\" Senate Resolution No. 1102 stresses.\n\nYulo earned his two gold medals at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics' Men's Floor Exercise Finals with a score of 15.00; and in the Men's Vault Finals with a score of 15.116.\n\nIn separate statements, several senators likewise expressed their support for Yulo.\n\nSen. Sherwin Gatchalian said this historic win \"brings a special moment of pride for our country and proves that the Olympic gold is no longer elusive for Filipino athletes.\"\n\nBut according to Gatchalian, this should not stop here, leaving a huge task for Filipinos as a nation.\n\n\"Our task as a nation is to ensure that future generations of athletes have all the support they need to succeed the world stage. This is why we created the National Academy of Sports where promising young athletes will be honed to achieve their full potential,\" he said.\n\nREAD: Carlos Yulo's Olympic gold medal haul caps decade of struggle\n\nSen. Nancy Binay, meanwhile, considered Yulo as an example that \"we can strive to achieve balance in our lives despite the pursuit of glory.\"\n\n\"[H]indi kailangan isakripisyo ang pamilya at kaligayahan, na sa katotohanan ay makatutulong ang mga ito upang bigyan tayo ng kapanatagan, lakas, at tibay ng loob para harapin ang pinakamatinding hamon na hinaharap natin,\" she said.\n\n(There is no need to sacrifice family and happiness, which in fact can help give us comfort, strength, and courage to face the greatest challenges we face.)\n\n\"We all await your victorious return, and we will be sure to welcome you with all the warmth and pride that we can muster,\" she added.\n\nFor Sen. Lito Lapid, Yulo is a golden boy. He likewise deemed the Filipino gymnast as an \"inspiration for our nation thirsty for heroism.\"\n\n\"Taas noo nating ipagmalaki sa buong mundo ang talento ng mga Pilipino,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "8260176033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:27:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:27:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:26:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/08/05/a-yulo-comes-once-in-a-hundred-years/", "title": "A Yulo comes once in a hundred years | Jun Lomibao", "body": "PARIS -- The King. The Greatest. With two gold medals, Carlos \"Caloy\" Yulo can be the King and Greatest Filipino athlete at the same time.\n\n\"What Caloy did for Philippine sports happened only once in a hundred years,\" said an ecstatic Philippine Olympic Committee (POC) president Abraham \"Bambol\" Tolentino. \"He will be on top of the conversation as the Philippines' greatest athlete.\"\n\nParis 2024 marked the 100th year anniversary of Philippines Olympic participation which, interestingly, was also in Paris 1924 with swimmer David Nepomuceno as the country's sole representative.\n\nHidilyn Diaz-Naranjo broke the gold medal drought with her victory in weightlifting in Tokyo 2020, but missed Paris because the women's 55 kgs is not in the Olympic program this time.\n\nYulo was a first-timer in Tokyo and failed to impact. Three years later, he did twice over and he couldn't forget that July 27 evening in 2021 at the Tokyo Olympic Village when he felt and touched every millimeter of Diaz-Naranjo's gold medal, even its lanyard.\n\n\"I won't forget that moment, when I was with Ate Hidilyn at the village and requested her to allow me to feel her gold medal,\" Yulo said. \"That stuck in my heart and mind and I told myself 'someday, it will be my turn, someday it will be me with a gold medal.\"\n\nExactly 1,104 days after Diaz-Naranjo triumphed at the Tokyo Dome, Yulo won the floor exercise for his first gold medal. After another sleepless night, he won his second in vault.\n\n\"Prayers answered,\" Tolentino said.\n\n\"God loves Caloy, Gods loves us all,\" said Cynthia Carrion-Norton, president of the Gymnastics Association of the Philippines.\n\n\"I'm very grateful to God, He gave me this one, He made me strong and healthy for these gold medals,\" Yulo said.\n\nWith Yulo's golds -- plus the guaranteed bronze medals of Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas which could be gold medals, too, if they win two more times in boxing -- the Philippines already overachieved from the Tokyo yield of one gold and the two silvers from Petecio and Carlo Paalam and bronze from Eumir Felix Marcial in boxing.\n\nThe Philippines shared 21st place in the medals table -- pending the two boxing medals -- with Azerbaijan and Serbia, the first time to see the country close to the top of the tally board.\n\nThe Philippines also is the best-placed Southeast Asian country with Malaysia and Indonesia having clinched a bronze medal each and Thailand and Singapore still to hit the tally board.\n\nSeventy of the 204 participating countries at Paris 2024 are on the board, including the Individual Neutral Athletes (Russia and Belarus), have at least a bronze medal nine days into the Olympics that closes on Monday.\n\n\"It was destiny shaped by everyone's efforts,\" Philippine Sports Commission chairman Richard Bachmann said Monday. \"We thank everyone's support as the nation celebrates these milestones.\"\n\nVillegas, meanwhile, goes for the gold medal bout when she fights Turkey's Buse Naz Cakiroglu at 10:18 p.m. Aurelio \"Oyie\" Umali on Monday disowned a social media post using his name and image to congratulate two-time Olympic gold medalist Carlos Yulo who made history at the Summer Games in Paris, France.\n\nThe politician said that the congratulatory post, which has since become viral, was from a \"fake Facebook account\" which he said was being maintained by his \"political detractors.\"\n\nThe viral post allegedly showed a huge image of Umali while a significantly smaller picture of Yulo was placed on the right side.\n\nThe image allegedly came from the Facebook page \"Governor Aurelio 'Oyie' Umali\" which has the username @BestGovOyie.\n\nA look at the page reveals another post that was \"edited\" due to the widespread criticism it has earned from online Filipinos.\n\nIt featured a larger image of Yulo while Umali's picture was placed below and edited to a smaller size.\n\n\"CONGRATULATIONS! Carlos Yulo. PS: Edited na. Bash nyo ko eh,\" the page said on August 3.\n\nThe following day, the page posted another congratulatory post that featured a bigger image of Yulo.\n\n\"2nd GOLD. Congratulations! Carlos Yulo PS: Nilakihan ko na po s'ya. PSS: Nagsama pa ako ng iba para mas masaya,\" it said on August 4.\n\nUmali warned the public about the \"fake\" account on his Facebook page \"Aurelio Oyie Matias Umali\" which has the username @governoroyieumali.\n\n\"Yesterday, the social media was saturated with posts and shares of greetings to Carlos Edriel Yulo for his success in the 2024 Paris Olympics, among them politicians that included me,\" he wrote on August 5.\n\n\"While I am one with the Filipino people in celebrating Carlos's success, the post pretending to be mine, maliciously framed in a way to enhance my political image, is from a fake Facebook account being maintained by my political detractors for their own political gain,\" Umali added.\n\n\"But let us not allow these political opportunists to spoil and taint our pride and joy for the great accomplishment of Carlos Yulo, now a double gold medalist, a true Filipino champion!\" he continued.\n\n\"Mabuhay ka, Carlos! Mabuhay ang Pilipinas! Nueva Ecija is very proud of you!\" the governor added.\n\nAnother congratulatory post that caught attention of online users was that of Sen. exercise in artistic gymnastics on Saturday (Philippine time) and another gold at the men's vault final on Sunday (Philippine time).\n\nREAD: Olympics, Gymnastics: Philippines' Yulo wins men's floor Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz earned the country's first Olympic gold medal in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nPhilippine celebrities and public figures, including president Ferdinand Marcos Jr and First Lady Liza Araneta-Marcos, also congratulated Mr Yulo.\n\n\"No words can express how proud we are of you, Caloy. You have achieved GOLD for the Philippines not once, but twice! Filipinos all over the world stood united, cheering and rooting for you,\" Mr Marcos wrote on Facebook.\n\nThe Philippine government will hand the gymnast 10 million Philippine pesos ($173,300; \u00a3135,400) - a reward promised to any gold medalists - while a real estate firm has promised him a fully furnished two-bedroom unit at McKinley Hill, the largest condominium development in metropolitan Manila.\n\nThe House of Representatives has pledged to give Mr Yulo an additional 6 million pesos in cash incentives, with speaker of the lower house, Ferdinand Martin Romualdez, describing him as a \"sports hero\" and \"national treasure\".\n\nEven medical clinics and universities have rolled out the red carpet for the national hero - a gastroenterologist have offered Mr Yulo free consultations and colonoscopies for life while the University of Mindanao has pledged free university credits.\n\nAlso awaiting him are lifetime supplies of ramen, mac and cheese and grilled chicken offered by various restaurant chains.\n\nMeanwhile, the capital city Manila, where Mr Yulo was born and raised, is preparing a \"hero's welcome\" for him.\n\n\"The grandest welcome will greet him and all our Paris Olympians. Pangilinan Sports Foundation (MVPSF) will double, if not add more, to the P10 million incentives a Filipino Olympic gold medalist will receive from the government by law through the Expanded Athletes' Incentives Act, which means that's instantly an easy P20 million for Mr. Yulo.\n\n\"In the past, MVPSF has matched the government incentive,\" a source yesterday told The STAR.\n\nThe same source said it will be no less than Filipino businessman and avid sports patron Manny V. P10 million that Yulo was already entitled for after winning the gold medal in the floor exercise, another P10 million should also be added into his haul after bagging the gold in the vault finals and becoming the very first Filipino athlete to win multiple gold medals in a single Olympics.\n\nThose are still under the Republic Act 10699 or National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act along with a medal of valor to be given\n\nOn top of that, property giant Megaworld, which initially pledged a fully furnished two-bedroom condominium unit worth P24 in Mckinley Hill in Bonifacio Global City, upgraded the package into a three-bedroom unit amounting to P32 million on top of a P3 million cash incentive following Yulo's double gold feat.\n\n\"Since this is a very significant milestone in the history of Philippine sports to have two gold Olympic medals during our 100th year participation as a country in the Olympics, which also coincides with our company's 35th anniversary this year, we are boosting our reward for Carlos Yulo now totaling P35 million,\" said Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso, president of Megaworld.\n\n\"He truly deserves this and we will always be proud of him for taking Filipino excellence to the next level,\" she added.\n\nLikewise, the House of Representatives, which first announced a P3 million incentive, also doubled its reward to P6 million.\n\nBounty {"uri": "8258418343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "09:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T09:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T09:17:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/sports/314480232/romualdez-hails-yulo-villegas-as-sports-heroes-national-treasures-after-successful-paris-2024-bids.html", "title": "Romualdez hails Yulo, Villegas as 'sports heroes, national treasures' after successful Paris 2024 bids - Manila Standard", "body": "Speaker Martin Romualdez on Sunday hailed artistic gymnast Carlos Yulo as a sports hero and national treasure for his extraordinary and electrifying triumph after winning the gold medal in the men's final floor exercise at the Paris Olympics 2024.\n\nYulo's historic victory, marking the Philippines' first-ever Olympic medal in gymnastics and only the second gold medal since joining the Summer Games 100 years ago, \"symbolizes the indomitable spirit and resilience of the Filipino people,\" he said.\n\nFor bringing immense pride and honor to the Filipino nation, the House of Representatives is honoring its commitment by providing a P3-million cash incentive to Yulo, according to the Speaker.\n\n\"Carlos Edriel Yulo has not only soared to the pinnacle of athletic excellence but has also emerged as a sports hero and national treasure, igniting a beacon of hope and inspiration for all Filipinos,\" the Speaker said in a statement.\n\n\"His tireless commitment to his sport, his relentless pursuit of excellence, and his ability to rise above challenges make him a true embodiment of the Filipino spirit. His achievements remind us all of the heights we can reach with perseverance and hard work,\" he added.\n\nRomualdez extended financial assistance to 22 Filipino athletes participating in the Paris Olympics. He initiated a fundraising campaign among his House colleagues to provide additional cash incentives to Yulo.\n\n\"Caloy has earned this reward through sheer hard work and unmatched talent. This incentive is a testament to our unwavering support for Filipino athletes who strive for greatness on the global stage,\" he noted.\n\nYulo will also be conferred a congressional medal for his exceptional achievement and contribution to Philippine sports.\n\n\"We celebrate Caloy's outstanding contribution and his role as an inspiration to future generations of athletes. He is not just a champion; he is our sports hero and national treasure whose legacy will inspire countless young Filipinos,\" Romualdez said.\n\nHe pledged P3 million for gold medalists, P2 million for silver medalists and P1 million for bronze medalists.\n\nFilipina boxer Aira Villegas, who hails from Tacloban City, is already assured of a bronze medal after winning against France's Wassila Lkhadiri in the women's 50kg quarterfinals.\n\n\"As a fellow Taclobanon, I am incredibly proud of Aira, our Tacloban champion, for securing at least a bronze medal after her hard-earned victory against a French rival,\" Romualdez said.\n\n\"With her tenacity and talent, Aira still has a chance to bring home either a silver or gold medal. Tacloban City and the entire country are cheering on her every step of the way,\" he noted.\n\n\"Their victories are our victories. It is my personal pledge to support them in every way possible,\" he said.\n\nHe called on all Filipinos to unite in celebrating this historic achievement.\n\n\"Let us come together to honor Caloy, whose dedication and excellence have brought us immense pride and joy. Carlos Yulo wins 2nd gold medal at Paris 2024", "body": "CARLOS \"Golden Boy\" Yulo has made history once again at the 2024 Paris Olympics, securing his second gold medal in the Men's Artistic Gymnastics Vault event on Sunday, August 8, 2024.\n\nThis triumph follows his previous victory in the Floor Exercise Saturday, cementing his status as one of the most remarkable gymnasts in Philippine history.\n\nYulo's performance in the vault was nothing short of spectacular, showcasing his exceptional skill, precision, and athleticism.\n\nThe gymnast then followed a double twist, scoring 14.800.\n\nHis gold medal in the vault adds to his earlier win in the floor exercise, bringing his total Olympic golds to two.\n\nYulo is the first and only Philippine athlete to win two gold medals at the Olympics.\n\nAlongside Yulo's two gold medals, Hidylyn Diaz clinched the country's first gold in the Women's Weightlifting 55kg category during the Tokyo Olympics 2020.\n\nWith these victories, the Philippines now proudly holds a total of three gold medals in the history of the Olympics. Carlos Yulo to P6 million", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- The House of Representatives will grant Carlos Yulo P6 million in cash incentives after his double gold-medal finish at the 2024 Paris Olympics -- up from the P3 million initially promised when the gymnast snagged his first gold on Saturday.\n\nYulo, the first Filipino to bring home two medals from an Olympics, will also receive a congressional medal \"for his exceptional achievement and contribution to Philippine sports,\" House Speaker Martin Romualdez said.\n\nThe lower house had initially pledged P3 million for gold medalists, but Yulo's second gold in the men's vault exercises final on Sunday, following his win in the men's floor exercise final the day before, doubled his incentive.\n\nThe doubled P3-million prize from the House is separate from the P10-million incentive that Filipino Olympic gold medalists are entitled to by law.\n\nHouse Speaker Martin Romualdez also initiated a fundraising campaign among lawmakers to provide additional cash incentives for Yulo.\n\nRomualdez praised Yulo's win, saying it \"highlighted the potential of our athletes to excel in the international arena.\"\n\nMore medals for Philippines\n\nAt least two other athletes have also been assured of a medal in the Olympics, namely female boxers Aira Villegas and Nesthy Petecio.\n\nVillegas is guaranteed at least a bronze after a split decision victory over home bet Wassila Lkhadiri of France in the women's 50 kg quarterfinal bout on Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, Petecio has secured at least a bronze medal after a unanimous decision victory over China's Zichun Xu in the women's 57 kg quarterfinals on Sunday.\n\nVillegas' next bout in the semifinals will take place on Tuesday, while Petecio's quarterfinal match {"uri": "8259709021", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:30:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:30:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:29:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/8/5/stress-free-approach-can-do-wonders", "title": "Stress-free approach can do wonders", "body": "PARIS - Carlos Yulo's first Olympic gold medal was awesome, but his second one was mind-boggling.\n\n\"It was a big bonus, I did not expect it, \" a smiling Yulo said. \"All I wanted is to perform my routines the way I wanted it to be. At ang importante, safe ako at walang injury at the end of the competition.\"\n\n\"I'm really blessed and grateful for that.\"\n\nThough his chances for a podium were high, only few believed he would win again 24 hours after becoming the first Filipino to capture an Olympic gymnastics title in the floor exercise.\n\nAnd he credited his second gold to a very relaxed approach - free of any distractions and troubles that beset his personal life back home.\n\n\"Mas chilled at relaxed ako ngayon kasi I have nothing to lose. Nanalo na ako ng gold sa floor so di ko alam ang sasabihin ko,\" added Yulo.\n\nHe encountered some troubled nights before the finals of the floor exercise - an event where he won his first world championship in 2019.\n\nAfter ruling that event, everything went into proper places, reason why Yulo managed to give it his all - his first vault was jaw-dropping.\n\n\"Nawala lahat ang stress sa katawan ko after winning the floor exercise,\" said Yulo.\n\nCalled Dragulescu, Yulo landed almost in perfect position though he made slight step backwards, thus earning 15.433 points.\n\nHis second vault was equally spectacular, coming through with a Kasamatsu double twist for a14.800 and a whopping average of15.116.\n\nFully satisfied with his performance, he bowed gently to the cheers of the happy crowd.\n\nThe cheers got louder when his scores were flashed on a giant monitor above, confirming that he had overtaken Armenian Artur Davtyan and British Harry Hepworth, who eventually finished second and third respectively with 14.966 and 14.949.\n\nFil-British Jake Jarman wound up fourth with14.933.\n\nSo chilled and relaxed Yulo was he congratulated all his rivals each time they completed their vaults.\n\n\"It's our own way to show respect to one another. Carlos Edriel Yulo, of the Philippines, celebrates after winning the gold medal during the men's artistic gymnastics individual vault finals at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France. It was his second gold medal after ruling the men's floor exercise. Francisco Seco/AP\n\nCarlos Edriel Yulo's homecoming as a double gold medalist at the Paris 2024 Olympics is made even sweeter with at least P42 million in cash incentives, a brand new P32 million fully-furnished three-bedroom condominium at McKinley Hill, a house and lot in Tagaytay, and a host of other perks as of August 5, 2024.\n\nAfter his second gold medal victory in the men's artistic gymnastics vault finals at the Paris 2024 Olympics gymnastics competition at Bercy Arena on Sunday, August 4, the 24-year-old Yulo is set to receive P20 million from the Philippine government under the Republic Act (RA) 10699, also known as the National Athletes and Coaches Benefits and Incentives Act.\n\nRA 10699 mandates awarding incentives of P10 million for every gold medal won in the Olympics, P5 million for silver, and P2 million for bronze.\n\nYulo will also claim P10 million from the International Container Terminal Services, Inc. (ICTSI), which has pledged to award P5 million for every Olympic gold medal, P3 million for silver, and P2 million for bronze.\n\nThe House of Representatives doubled his incentives to P6 million after committing to award him P3 million for his first gold medal in the men's floor exercise on Saturday, August 3.\n\nChooks To Go also announced on Monday morning, August 5, that they would reward Yulo with P3 million.\n\nMegaworld also upgraded its reward for Yulo's historic feat to a P32-million fully-furnished three-bedroom condominium unit from a P24-million two-bedroom condominium unit. However, with Carlos Yulo ruling the Paris Olympics' men's floor exercise final on Saturday, August 3, he continues to challenge these long-held beliefs and inspire a new generation.\n\nGymnastics, often associated with grace and flexibility, is a sport where men are traditionally underrepresented. Growing up in a country where basketball and boxing take the lead in Philippine sports, Yulo showed his great passion in pursuing to become a world-class gymnast.\n\nJust like in his recent win, Yulo showcased that athleticism, power, and artistry know no gender. From his exceptional talent in his field to his dynamic routines, Yulo has redefined the image of a male gymnast -- that a female-dominant sport can also be a sport among men.\n\nBreaking gender stereotypes is also not new for weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz. With her historic win at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, Hidilyn defied expectations by clinching the country's first-ever Olympic gold medal. Traditionally viewed as a male-dominated sport, weightlifting has been associated with brute strength and physical power.\n\nDiaz shattered expectations and proved that strength, determination, and athletic prowess are not exclusive to any gender.\n\nFellow Olympians Nesthy Petecio and Margilyn Didal have been very vocal about being part of the LGBTQIA+ community and used their time in the spotlight as an opportunity to proudly embrace their identities.\n\nThis only proves that conventional gender norms surrounding sports are not a hindrance among athletes from pursuing their passions {"uri": "2024-08-443999614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:35:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:35:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:29:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/sports/2024/08/05/2375591/yulo-admits-not-expecting-win-2nd-olympic-gold", "title": "Yulo admits not expecting to win 2nd Olympic gold", "body": "MANILA, Philippines -- It was so nice that Carlos Yulo had to win twice.\n\nAfter taking home the Philippines' first gold medal in the Paris Olympics via the floor exercise, the Golden Boy went back 24 hours later and snagged another through the vault.\n\nAfter winning the historic second gold medal, Yulo admitted that he did not expect the result.\n\n\"Hindi ko in-expect na ganun yung kalalabasan. 'Di talaga ako makapaniwala kanina,\" he said in an interview as posted by One Sports.\n\n\"Relax lang ako kanina kasi, parang 'Sige, kahit ano na to, walang mawawala sa akin, all out na to.' Ganun na po yung feeling ko kanina,\" he added.\n\nThe Filipino battled immense pressure from his opponents, who notched scores that may be difficult to top if you were a normal Olympic athlete.\n\nUkraine's Nazar Chepurnyi kicked off the competition with an average score of 14.899. Harry Hepworth of Great Britain upped the ante with 14.949, while his countryman Jake Jarman recorded 14.933.\n\nThis would make any other athlete's skin crawl with pressure.\n\nBut Caloy is no ordinary athlete.\n\nYulo showed nerves of steel, ran toward the vault, launched himself into the stratosphere, and just went for broke.\n\nDisplaying power and grace, he struck a near-perfect landing that gave him 15.433, the highest thus far.\n\nHis second vault was scored a little lower at 14.800, but it was enough to put him at 15.116.\n\nWith four other gymnasts set to perform, the Philippines anxiously waited with Yulo as one by one finished their routines.\n\nArtur Davtyan, the Tokyo bronze medalist, came in last, and gave the Filipino a scare after a 14.966 in the first vault.\n\nWhen the Armenian had the exact same score in the second vault, it solidified Yulo's gold medal as the Filipino basked in the applause of the audience.\n\n\"Crazy, crazy experience talaga ito. Grabe.\"\n\nWith his performance, the gymnast's name is now cemented in Philippine history, giving him a strong case as one of the greatest Filipino athletes ever.\n\nAnd at just 24 years old, the {"uri": "8260155287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:12:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:12:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:11:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sports/these-filipina-teens-in-uae-want-to-be-the-next-carlos-yulo-after-historic-olympic-double-gold", "title": "These Filipina teens in UAE want to be the next Carlos Yulo after historic Olympic double gold", "body": "Thirteen-year-old Haifa Niegas stayed up past her bedtime on Sunday to watch Filipino gymnast Carlos Yulo compete in the Olympics. And when the athlete bagged his second gold, her home in Abu Dhabi erupted in cheers, with her mum jumping while holding a huge Philippine flag in their living room.\n\n\"Seeing Carlos win two gold medals made me want to train harder, work harder,\" Niegas told Khaleej Times.\n\nWithin just 24 hours, Yulo went from making history as the first Filipino gymnast to win in the Olympics to breaking his own record with another gold medal. His first gold was for the floor exercise final and the other was for the vault at the Paris Olympics.\n\nNiegas, a Filipino-Iraqi Year 9 student, is also a gymnast who has been winning tournaments around the world. Just last month, she won a gold medal for the UAE in an international competition in Egypt.\n\nThe next time she takes the floor, though, the rhythmic gymnast will be bearing the Philippine flag. Niegas has just joined the Philippine national team early this year, opening up new opportunities for her to enter bigger competitions that could eventually lead her to the Olympics.\n\nShe hasn't met Yulo yet but when she does, she said she would immediately ask him the big question: \"How did you do it?\"\n\nWatching from Dubai, another young Filipina gymnast was also cheering for Yulo.\n\nGabrielle Anne Opida Ramos, also 13, was holding her breath as she watched the Olympian do his routine.\n\n\"My stress level was through the roof because of how intense and close the scores of the other athletes were,\" Ramos told Khaleej Times.\n\n\"When I saw Carlos Yulo score 15.116, I was so happy and proud to see an amazing team player representing the Philippines. As a rhythmic gymnast, I would feel as joyful as he did seeing his hard work paying off,\" she said.\n\nRamos, an incoming Grade 9 student in Dubai, has loved gymnastics since she was 3 years old. She first learnt ballet and eventually moved to gymnastics. In 2022, she won a scholarship that allowed her to attend regular training sessions.\n\n\"Gymnastics motivates me to have a stronger, healthier immune system, flexible body and discipline. This sport also improved my confidence,\" Ramos said.\n\nLike Niegas, she has also won several competitions in the UAE and abroad. \"Seeing myself win a spot in the top three serves as a reminder that in the end, trying my best always counts.\"\n\nThe two teenage gymnasts train hard in the UAE every single day, even on school days.\n\nNiegas travels from Abu Dhabi to Dubai and practises her skills for four hours every day on weekdays and five on Saturdays.\n\n\"After Carlos' win, I am motivated to do more. Perhaps I will now do five hours a week, and squeeze in some more training on my day off, which is Sunday,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khaleej {"uri": "2024-08-443857447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:22:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:22:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:22:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/578254/yulo-gold-seals-a-first-for-ph-in-long-games-participation", "title": "Carlos Yulo gold seals first for PH in Olympics participation", "body": "Carlos Yulo's golden moment in gymnastics and the sure medal finish of boxer Aira Villegas have secured another first for the Philippines in its century-long Olympic participation.\n\nNever has the country produced more than one medal in back-to-back Olympics until the pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo edition three years ago, which saw weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz break through with the first gold medal and the ongoing Paris Games where Yulo won the men's floor exercise.\n\nVillegas reached the semifinals of the women's 50-kilogram category hours after Yulo got the job done, assuring a repeat scenario from Tokyo that had the Philippines pocket Diaz's gold plus three medals -- silvers from Nesthy Petecio and Carlo Paalam and one bronze from fellow slugger Eumir Marcial.\n\nIt will also be the third time that the Philippines has gotten multiple medals in a single Olympics. Swimmer Teofilo Yldefonso, boxer Jose Villanueva and high jumper Simeon Toribio won a bronze each in the 1932 Los Angeles Games.\n\nThe Philippines also won a medal for the third consecutive Olympics, a period that began with Diaz's silver finish in Rio in 2016, marking the third time that the Philippines has done it in the cycle.\n\nFirst streak\n\nThe first was from the period of the 1928 Amsterdam, 1932 Los Angeles and 1936 Berlin Olympics with a combined haul of five bronzes. Yldefonso was the country's first medalist during the 1928 edition while Miguel White placed third in the men's 400-meter hurdles in 1936.\n\nIt was the boxers who achieved the similar feat in the 1988 Seoul, 1992 Barcelona and 1996 Atlanta Games. Leopoldo Serantes and Roel Velasco claimed bronze medals in 1988 and 1992, respectively.\n\nMansueto \"Onyok\" Velasco came close to a gold in 1996, settling for a silver after his highly disputed loss in the final to Bulgaria's Daniel Petrov.\n\nThe last three Olympics have seen the Philippines secure a total of seven medals, including the pending one from Villegas.\n\nAnd there could possibly be more before the conclusion of the Paris Olympics, with Yulo slated to take another crack in men's vault and Petecio in the quarterfinals of her women's featherweight class, both at press time, and EJ Obiena in men's pole vault.\n\nSeven is a remarkable haul considering that the Philippines had a total of nine between its Olympic debut in 1924 until 2016, which probably changes the old trend of being satisfied with seeing a Filipino athlete get one medal at a single Olympics, regardless of color outside of gold. {"uri": "8259497577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:50:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:50:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:49:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/news/314480568/romualdez-olympic-gold-medalist-carlos-yulo-is-a-once-in-a-century-athlete.html", "title": "Romualdez: Olympic gold medalist Carlos Yulo is a 'once-in-a-century athlete' - Manila Standard", "body": "Speaker Martin Romualdez described gymnast Carlos Edriel Yulo as a \"once-in-a-century Filipino athlete\" following his exceptional double gold victory at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nYulo first clinched a gold medal in the men's floor exercise on Saturday and followed it up with another one in the men's vault on Sunday at the ongoing Olympics.\n\nThese victories marked the Philippines' first and second Olympic medals in gymnastics and the country's second and third gold medals since joining the Summer Games a century ago, which were also held in Paris.\n\nRomualdez praised Yulo's achievements for \"bringing immense pride and joy to the nation and showcasing the unparalleled talent and dedication of Filipino athletes on the global stage.\"\n\n\"Carlos Edriel Yulo has proven himself to be a once-in-a-century Filipino athlete,\" Romualdez said. \"His remarkable performance at the Paris Olympics, winning double gold in both the floor exercise and vault, is a testament to his hard work, perseverance, and exceptional skill.\"\n\nYulo's victories, according to Romualdez, \"have not only made the Philippines proud but also inspired millions of Filipinos, especially the youth, to pursue their dreams with passion and determination.\"\n\nThe seasoned lawmaker out of Leyte emphasized the significance of these accomplishments in elevating the status of Philippine sports internationally, as he reaffirmed his commitment to supporting Filipino athletes.\n\n\"Caloy's achievements have not only brought glory to the Philippines but have also highlighted the potential of our athletes to excel in the international arena,\" Romualdez said.\n\n\"We will continue to support and invest in our sports programs to nurture and develop more world-class athletes like Caloy. His success is a shining example of hope and a source of inspiration for all of us,\" he added.\n\nThe House chief also extended his congratulations to Yulo's coaches, family, and the entire Philippine gymnastics community.\n\n\"Behind every successful athlete is a team of dedicated coaches, supportive family members, and a community that believes in them. I extend my heartfelt congratulations and gratitude to everyone who has been part of Caloy's journey to greatness,\" he said.\n\nAs the nation celebrates Yulo's historic victories, Romualdez called on {"uri": "8259838594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:54:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:54:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/08/05/sports/psc-chief-extolls-all-supporters-behind-ph-success-in-paris/1961973", "title": "PSC chief extolls all supporters behind PH success in Paris", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - Philippine Sports Commission (PSC) Chairman Dickie Bachmann on Sunday, extolled the concerted efforts extended by various individuals and sectors for the success of gymnast Carlos Yulo in the Paris Olympics here.\n\nYulo further galvanized his status as perhaps the greatest Filipino Olympian by winning his second gold medal on Sunday - a day after nailing his first gold at the Bercy Arena.\n\nYulo's rare double-gold showing, Bachmann said, won't be possible without the help of Team Yulo - coach Aldrin Castaneda, a therapist and even the indefatigable gymnastics president Cynthia Carreon. \"It was a destiny shaped by everyone's efforts,\" said Bachmann. \"Thanks to everyone's support, the nation celebrates the milestones we've achieved. In just two days, Carlos Yulo brought home two gold medals, but we're not stopping there.\" Boxers Nesthy Petecio and Aira Villegas are already assured of a bronze medal each advancing to the semis of their respective events while EJ Obiena is competing in pole vault finals at presstime.\n\n\"We commend everyone's involvement in bringing the country back to glory. I am confident that all Filipinos are celebrating this special achievement like never before,\" added Bachmann. Among these athletes is Tokyo 2021 bronze medalist boxer Eumir Marcial, who has benefited from Bounty's unwavering support.\n\nThe company's dedication to Philippine sports was further exemplified in 2021 when they honored previous Olympic heroes, including Mansueto \"Onyok\" Velasco and Roel Velasco, by awarding them their very own Chooks-to-Go stores. Chloe, originally a fan of Yulo, initiated contact through a direct message on X (formerly Twitter), which blossomed into a significant emotional cornerstone for the athlete.\n\nTheir story began with a simple message from Chloe in April 2020, expressing admiration for Yulo's career. The casual interaction quickly escalated into a deep connection, underpinned by mutual respect and support. Despite geographical distances - Chloe studying in Melbourne and Yulo training in Japan - their relationship endured through digital communication, illustrating the modern dynamic of long-distance relationships.\n\nChloe's unwavering support was evident as she travelled to various competitions, including the Southeast Asian Games in Vietnam and the FIG Artistic Gymnastics World Cup series in Qatar. Her presence at these events not only provided moral support but also reinforced Yulo's psychological resilience, a crucial element in sports where mental fortitude is as essential as physical prowess.\n\nTheir interactions, often shared on social media, reveal a genuine partnership, with Yulo publicly acknowledging Chloe's sacrifices and support. This modern love story, thriving amid the pressures of competitive sport and personal sacrifice, not only humanises the Olympic experience but also exemplifies the profound impact of emotional support
